questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic, reporting that she is late for her period by one day. She has been married for 4 years and has 2 children. She has no significant gynecological history. She has had regular periods. Her urine pregnancy test is negative. She is advised to wait for another few days and gets her period the next day. Which mechanism is responsible for menstrual bleeding in the absence of pregnancy?

choices.text: The involution of the corpus luteum causes estradiol and progesterone levels to fall dramatically.
Estradiol levels are not involved in the LH surge phenomenon
Estradiol inhibits the induction of the progesterone receptor in the endometrium

questions.solution:
Option A: The involution of corpus luteum causes estradiol and progesterone levels to fall dramatically

  • The woman in question has had a normal period. The normal cycle length can vary from 21-35 days.

  • A corpus luteum is a mass of cells formed in an ovary. It leads to the production of progesterone during early pregnancy. The role of the corpus luteum varies whether or not fertilization occurs.
  • Without progesterone, the uterus lining does not undergo the changes supporting pregnancy. Instead, the lining would shed.
  • LH is the stimulus for the corpus luteum to continue its function of progesterone production. Apoptosis can occur by changes in hormone levels in the ovarian cycle. When there is no fertilization of the ovum, the endometrial cells die because LH production stops after the 10th day of its formation in the absence of pregnancy.
  • As the corpus luteum involutes, the levels of estrogen and progesterone fall and lead to a withdrawal bleed due to the absence of progesterone supporting the estrogen-primed endometrium.
  • Once pregnancy ensues, the hCG made from the syncytiotrophoblast is the stimulator for continuous corpus luteum function till around the 12th week of gestation, after which the placenta takes over the function of pregnancy maintenance.

Option B: LH levels rise after ovulation

  • LH levels fall after ovulation due to rising Progesterone which gives feedback inhibition to the production of LH from the pituitary.
  • So, it's a false statement.

Option C: Estradiol levels are not involved in the LH surge phenomenon

  • The rising estrogen from the developing follicle continues to increase through the proliferative phase and causes the production of LH, which in turn is responsible for ovulation. So, it's not a true statement regarding the question asked above.

Option D: Estradiol inhibits the induction of the progesterone receptor in the endometrium

  • Estrogen is responsible for the production of progesterone receptors in the endometrium. Progesterone is produced from the corpus luteum, acts on the endometrium, and causes secretory changes. So, it's not a true statement.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient with heart failure currently on digoxin therapy presents to the emergency department with blurred vision and yellow-green distortion. The plasma digoxin level is 4 ng/ml(normal 0.8- 2.0). Renal function is normal; this patient's plasma t1/2 for digoxin is 1.6 days. How long should digoxin be withheld to reach a safer yet probably therapeutic level of 1 ng/ml?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- 3.2 days:

  • Patient has digoxin toxicity with visual disturbances.
  • Digoxin elimination follows first-order kinetics, i.e., a constant fraction of drugs is eliminated per unit of time, and the half-life remains constant.
  • Time to decrease the plasma concentration of digoxin from 4 ng/ml to 1 ng/ml ≈ 2 half-lives. Thus, the time required will be two × t½, i.e., two × 1.6 = 3.2 days.
  • Half-life is the time required to change the drug in the body by half during elimination. For drugs following first-order kinetics, the clearance and plasma half-life remain constant.
  • In such drugs, nearly complete drug elimination occurs in 4-5 half-lives.

Number of half-lives

1

2

3

4

Percentage of drug remaining

50%

25%

12.5%

6.25%

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and D: Refer to explanation of Option C

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the Lower esophageal sphincter?

choices.text: Has a tone that is provided by the sympathetic System
Relaxes ahead of the peristaltic wave

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Relaxes ahead of the peristaltic wave:

  • The Lower Esophageal Sphincter (LES) relaxes ahead of the peristaltic wave to allow food to pass from the esophagus into the stomach. This relaxation is mediated by VIP and NO during primary peristalsis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Has no tonic activity: The LES does have tonic activity, maintaining a resting pressure of about 20 mm Hg to prevent reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus.

Option B - Has a tone that is provided by the sympathetic system: The basal tone of the LES is primarily mediated by vagal cholinergic fibers (parasympathetic) rather than the sympathetic system.

Option C - Relaxes on increasing abdominal pressure: Contraction of the diaphragm or increased intra-abdominal pressure increases the pressure in the LES, rather than causing relaxation. Relaxation of the LES occurs in response to peristaltic waves in the esophagus.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male presents with a lesion on his toe that has doubled in size in the past year. It is non-tender and does not bleed, but his wife says it’s getting bigger and darker on one side. On examination, the macule is 7mm in diameter. Which of the following is the best next step?
questions.solution:
Option A: Excisional biopsy

  • The lesion in the above-mentioned patient is suspicious of malignant melanoma. The most important next step is to perform an excisional biopsy.

The following points should be kept in mind:

  • Any pigmented cutaneous lesion that has changed in size or shape or has other features suggestive of Malignant melanoma is a candidate for biopsy.
  • An excisional biopsy with a 1-3 mm margin is suggested.
  • Accurate measurement of thickness if the lesion is melanoma and constitutes definitive treatment if the lesion is benign.
  • For large lesions or anatomic sites where excisional biopsy is not feasible (such as the face, hands, and feet), an incisional biopsy through the most nodular or darkest area of the lesion is acceptable.

Option B: Topical imiquimod cream

  • Topical imiquimod cream is used for actinic keratosis. This patient’s lesion is suspicious of melanoma. The diagnosis must be confirmed first with a biopsy.

Option C: Liquid nitrogen cryotherapy

  • Liquid nitrogen cryotherapy is used to treat warts. This patient’s lesion is suspicious of melanoma. An excisional biopsy should be performed to diagnose it first.

Option D: Reassurance and observation

  • Reassurance and observation are recommended for benign lesions. This patient’s lesion is suspicious of malignancy. Therefore, this is not the right choice.

questions.text: Which of the following is risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma?

choices.text: Fair skin(skin type I and II)

questions.solution:
Option C: Viral hepatitis B

Viral hepatitis B is the most common risk factor associated with hepatocellular carcinoma followed by hepatitis C virus.

Option A: Fair skin(skin types I and II)

  • It is a risk factor for Basal cell carcinoma

Option B: Barrett's Esophagus

  • It is a risk factor for Esophageal adenocarcinoma

Option D: Human papillomavirus(HPV)

  • It is a risk factor for Cervical cancer

questions.text: A 45-year-old female is being posted for a right-modified radical mastectomy under general anaesthesia. Induction of anaesthesia is done with Inj. Propofol and endotracheal intubation is facilitated with Inj. Atracurium. While doing mask ventilation after administering muscle relaxant, the monitor showed a blood pressure reading of 75/40 mmHg, a pulse rate to be 130/minute, and flushing of the face, which was treated with intravenous fluid bolus and Inj. Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV. Which of the following is the underlying mechanism of these observed findings?

choices.text: Effects mediated by autonomic nicotinic cholinergic receptors
Reduced peripheral vascular resistance by propofol

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Histamine release:

  • Histamine release by benzylisoquinolinium compounds such as mivacurium, atracurium and tubocurarine can cause skin flushing, decreases in blood pressure and systemic vascular resistance and tachycardia.
  • Histamine has positive ionotropic and chronotropic effects on the myocardial H2 receptors. The clinical effects of histamine are seen when the drug administration is rapid.
  • Cisatracurium, vecuronium or rocuronium may be appropriate for patients with hemodynamic instability due to less or no histamine release.
  • Slow administration of benzylisoquinolinium compounds over 60 seconds and prophylaxis with combined H1 and H2 blockers maintain cardiovascular stability.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Effects mediated by autonomic nicotinic cholinergic receptors:

  • Neuromuscular blocking agents interact with nicotinic and muscarinic cholinergic receptors within the autonomic nervous system and at the nicotinic receptors of the neuromuscular junction.
  • Tubocurarine causes marked ganglionic blockade resulting in hypotension due to peripheral venous and arteriolar dilatation via stimulation of the vascular H1 and H2 receptors.
  • Pancuronium produced a profound vagolytic response by blocking the sympathetic postganglionic nerve terminals. It is characterised by tachycardia, reduction in heart rate variability and baroreflex sensitivity. It may also stimulate the catecholamine release from adrenergic nerve terminals.

Option C - Reduced peripheral vascular resistance by propofol:

  • It may result in hypotension, but the observed findings of flushing do not particularly occur secondary to propofol administration.

Option D - Preoperative use of antihypertensives:

  • Antihypertensives are used preoperatively in some patients with elevated blood pressure readings to keep their blood pressure within a suitable range for the induction of anaesthesia.
  • Flushing is particularly not expected secondary to this intervention.

questions.text: At which of the following blood pressure readings will the the baroreceptors be inactive?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 50 mm Hg:

  • The baroreceptor function is inactive at 50 mmHg and active when > 200mmHg.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option B,C and D are explained above.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman was admitted for appetite loss, nausea, and back pain. A physical examination revealed right hypochondriac tenderness and obvious jaundice.  MRCP revealed dilated intrahepatic and common hepatic bile ducts, distended gallbladder, and erosion of less than 1/3 of the circumference of common hepatic duct. What is the best next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Partial cholecystectomy with choledochoplasty

The given clinical scenario suggests type II Mirizzi syndrome and the best treatment for Mirizzi syndrome type II is partial cholecystectomy with choledochoplasty.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Conservative management

  • The most common complication of Mirizzi syndrome is cholecystobiliary or cholecysto-enteric fistula formation due to prolonged inflammation.
  • Therefore, surgical management is required.

Option C: Partial cholecystectomy alone is the treatment of choice for type I choledochal cysts.

Option D:  Bilioenteric anastomosis is the treatment of choice for type IV and V Mirizzi syndrome.

questions.text: The case that is being followed by the entire community is that of a young man who has claimed his rightful property. He alleges that he is the posthumous child of the late owner of a bungalow in that town. The court has begun an investigation into the matter. While claiming to be a posthumous child, he is claiming to be?

choices.text: Child delivered after death of his mother.
Child delivered after death of biological father
Born after death of both parents

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Child delivered after death of biological father:

  • Posthumous child is one who is born after the death of his/her father.

Incorrect options:

Option A,C,D are incorrect due to the above given reason

questions.text: A 48-year-old alcoholic man comes in with a 6-day history of productive cough and fever. The temperature is 38.7°C (103°F), the heart rate is 32 beats per minute, and the blood pressure is 126/86 mm Hg. The patient's cough worsens, and he starts coughing up a lot of foul-smelling sputum. An X-ray of the chest reveals an infiltrate in the right upper and middle lobes. A CBC reveals leukocytosis (WBC = 38,000/mL), with 80% of neutrophils being slightly immature and toxic granulation. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of leukocyte alkaline phosphatase. Which of the following best describes the hematologic condition of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Options:

Option D: Leukemoid reaction

  • Neutrophilia is defined as an absolute neutrophil count greater than 7,000/L.
  • In acute infections, neutrophilia can be so severe that it can be misdiagnosed as leukaemia, particularly chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML), which is referred to as a leukemoid reaction.
  • The following are clues to the benign (or reactive) nature of a leukemoid reaction:
    • The cells in the peripheral blood smear are more mature than myelocytes, and
    • Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase activity is high in benign conditions but low in CML patients.
    • Large blue cytoplasmic inclusions known as "Dohle bodies" or toxic granulation are common in benign neutrophils.

The above image shows Dohle's bodies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Acute myelogenous leukemia

  • More than 20% of blast cells on bone marrow or peripheral blood smear suggest AML.

  • The scenario is suggestive of leukemoid reaction 

Option B: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

  • CLL is a slowly progressive malignancy of blood cells in which there is an increased number of leukocytes in the lymphoid tissue.
  • In CLL, abnormal leukocytes, also called leukemic cells, are produced instead of healthy white blood cells and accumulate over time.
  • CBC showing more than 10,000 lymphocytes/mm3 is highly suggestive of CLL, but definitive are needed for confirmatory diagnosis.

Option C: Chronic myelogenous leukaemia

  • LAP score is low in patients with CML.
  • More immature cells are present in CML.
  • Hypogranular leukocytes are present in CML.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true about the brachial plexus?

A. Lower trunk is formed by root C8 and T1

B. Lateral cord is formed by the upper and middle trunk

C. Posterior cord is formed by posterior divisions of all three trunks

D. Anterior division of the lower trunk continuous as medial cord and give rise to the radial nerve.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:  A, B & C only

True statements A,B,C

  • The C5 and C6 form the upper trunk. The middle trunk is the continuation of C7. C8 and T1 form the lower trunk.
  • The cords are formed by the confluence of divisions:
    • The lateral cord from the anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunk;
    • The posterior cord by all three posterior divisions;
    • The medial cord by the anterior division of the lower trunk and sometimes by a branch from the anterior division of the middle trunks.

False statement D

  • Anterior division of the lower trunk continuous as medial cord and give rise to ulnar nerve not the radial nerve
  • Posterior division of upper, middle, lower trunk joins to form the posterior cord and gives rise to radial nerve.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presents to the gynaecology clinic for counselling regarding contraception. She desires to start COCPs. She is a well-controlled diabetic patient. She smokes one pack (of 20) of cigarettes daily. She is also hypertensive, and her blood pressure is 140/90 on drugs and known case of Arterial thrombosis. Total serum cholesterol is 275 mg/dL. COCPs are contraindicated in her more strongly due to which of the following factors in her history?
questions.solution:
Option D: Arterial thrombosis

  • The most appropriate answer is smoking since it is the only absolute contraindication mentioned.
  • This is the most important contraindication for combined oral contraceptive pills

Other options

Option A: Diabetes

  • Diabetes in this patient is well controlled and COCs can be used in well controlled diabetics.

Option B: Cholesterol

  • Since low dose OCPs do not alter the lipid metabolism too much, it is not the most important contraindication.

Option C: Hypertension

  • Hypertension too in this patient is well controlled, and forms only a relative contraindications to COCs.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female visits the clinic with a complaint of fever, painful swelling of the vulva, and dysuria for the last three days. On examination, multiple red vesicles are found on the genital area. There is a history of new sexual contact seven days back. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
Option D: Acyclovir

  • This patient, with fever, painful swelling of the vulva, dysuria, multiple red vesicles on the genital area, and a history of new sexual contact, most likely suffers from herpes genitalis.
  • The most common pathogen involved is HSV-2.
  • Painful lymphadenopathy may also be seen.
  • Punched-out lesions appear that ulcerate later.
  • Diagnosis is made clinically. However, a Tzanck smear of the lesions, PCR, or viral culture can be used for confirmation.
  • Acyclovir is the first-line treatment option.
  • Recurrences are common

Option A: Fluconazole

  • It is used in the management of vaginal candidiasis, which is typically associated with a curdy white vaginal discharge.
  • Vaginal burning and pruritus are also a feature of this condition.

Option B: Metronidazole

  • It helps manage vulvovaginitis associated with an infection caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • Trichomoniasis is typically characterized by a foul-smelling yellow-green vaginal discharge and strawberry cervix.

Option C: Oseltamivir

  • It is an antiviral neuraminidase inhibitor, helpful in managing influenza virus infection.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of eye pain for 5 days. She gave a history of using contact lenses which she usually stores in tap water. After a complete evaluation, a diagnosis of severe retinitis was made. If we culture the water she was using for contact lens storage and the vitreous, the probable pathogen that can be isolated would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option D: Acanthamoeba

  • This is a case of retinitis in which the patient presents with complaints of severe eye pain.

  • It is caused by acanthamoeba.

  • Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba.

  • Acanthamoeba is commonly isolated from contact lens fluid and patients with retinitis who do not store their lenses under sterile conditions.

  • Causes of contact lens keratitis·:

    • Aerosol route → Lungs → Hematogenous spread → Brain → Granulomatous Encephalitis

    • Spread can occur even though the Optic route

Lab diagnosis:

CSF Examination:

  • Cysts & Trophozoites are seen

  • lymphocytes are present

  • Acanthamoeba can be grown on non-nutrient agar plates using Escherichia coli as a food source.

Other Options

Option A: Naegleria

  • Naegleria fowleri is a parasite that lives in the soil.

  • It can cause primary amoebic meningoencephalitis.

Option B: Pneumocystis

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii can cause pnemocystic pneumonia.

  • Its symptoms include productive cough, shortness of breath, and fever.

Option C: Babesia

  • Babesia is a tiny parasite that causes babesiosis.

  • Babesiosis is a life-threatening infection of red blood cells.

questions.text: A woman with eclampsia delivers a baby at 32 weeks of gestation. She was given magnesium sulfate. As the delivery is prolonged and the umbilical cord becomes wrapped around the baby's neck, it leads to perinatal asphyxia; his APGAR score is calculated and shifted to the NICU. What are the essential criteria for defining the condition mentioned above?

choices.text: Persistence of APGAR score of 5-7 for >5 minutes
Presence of neurological manifestations in the long neonatal period
Evidence of single organ dysfunction in the long neonatal period

questions.solution:
Option B: Prolonged umbilical arterial blood pH <7.0

  • In the above-diagnosed case of perinatal eclampsia asphyxia, the main criteria is prolonged umbilical arterial blood pH<7.0
  • Essential criteria for defining perinatal asphyxia include:
    • APGAR score of 0–3 persists for >5 minutes
    • Prolonged acidemia (pH <7.0) on an umbilical arterial blood sample
    • Neurological manifestations, e.g. seizures, coma, hypotonia, or HIE in the immediate neonatal period
    • Evidence of multi-organ dysfunction in the immediate neonatal period

Option A: Persistence of APGAR score of 5-7 for >5 minutes

  • The Apgar score is used to evaluate neonates quickly. Low five-minute Apgar scores have been linked to an increased chance of catastrophic neurologic sequelae, but there is long-term data on milder consequences.
  • We investigated the relationship between the five-minute Apgar score and the prevalence of neurologic impairment and cognitive performance in early adulthood.

Option C: Presence of neurological manifestations in the long neonatal period

  • After a long time, the neurological manifestations in the neonatal period are immediate.
  • It's all due to neonatal bacteremia, which causes these manifestations.

Option D: Evidence of single organ dysfunction in the long neonatal period

  • It involves multi-organ dysfunction.
  • And it is also an immediate neonatal period.

questions.text: A healthy 25-year-old gravida 2 para 1 at 38 weeks of gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labour. Shortly after hospital admission, epidural analgesia is initiated at the patient's request. Three hours later, she was fully dilated and gave birth via normal spontaneous vaginal delivery to a healthy baby boy. The umbilical cord is clamped after 30 seconds of birth. What is the advantage of delayed cord clamping?

choices.text: Elevated levels of bilirubin in the blood

questions.solution:
Option C: Lesser chances of shock

  • The umbilical cord is clamped after 30 seconds of the delivery; this is termed delayed cord clamping
  • In delayed cord clamping, transitional circulation is improved.
  • It helps in the formation of more red blood cell volumes.
  • It decreases the need for blood transfusion.
  • It lowers the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis.
  • It decreases the risk of interventricular hemorrhage.
  • It decreases the risk of shock.
  • As more blood is supplied to the muscles and tissues
  • Good tissue perfusion.
  • Better supply to the tissues will decrease the risk of ischemia
  • Advantages of delayed cord clamping:
    • Lesser chances of anaemia
    • Higher blood pressure
    • Lesser chances of shock
    • Lesser intraventricular haemorrhage
  • Immediate resuscitation of the newborn can save the baby from lifetime disability or death.

Option A: Early hemolysis of RBC

  • Hemolysis of RBCs will lead to hemodilution.
  • Hemodilution will lead to anaemia.

Option B: Release of bilirubin

  • Bilirubin is a product of RBC breakdown.
  • Bilirubin is released when RBCs undergo hemolysis.
  • It may also be elevated in case of liver disorders or defective hepatic metabolism.

Option D: Elevated levels of bilirubin in the blood 

  • In delayed cord clamping, the clamped RBCs are broken down in the circulation.
  • RBC breakdown causes the release of excessive bilirubin.
  • Levels of bilirubin are thus elevated in the bloodstream.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, G1P0, at 24 weeks of pregnancy, presents to the outpatient department for a routine prenatal visit. The pregnancy was planned. She takes no medications except folic acid and iron tablets. On examination, S2 and S3 are easily audible, and a systolic ejection murmur is greater during inspiration. Which of the following is true regarding these findings in the patient?

choices.text: The presence of S3 is abnormal
The systolic ejection murmur is unusual in a pregnant woman at term
Wide pulse pressure is rare in pregnant women
All findings recorded are normal changes in pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: All findings recorded are normal changes in pregnancy.

In Pregnancy

  • Heart rate increases by about 10 to 15/min.
  • Exaggerated splitting of the first heart sound
  • Increased loudness of both S1 & S2 components,
  • A loud, easily heard S3
  • >95% develop systolic murmur which disappears after delivery
  • >20% have a transient diastolic murmur.
  • 10% develop continuous murmur due to increasing mammary blood flow.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: The presence of S3 is abnormal

  • The presence of an audible S3 is normal in pregnancy due to a hyperdynamic state, and this resolves as soon as the baby is delivered

Option B: The systolic ejection murmur is unusual in a pregnant woman at term

  • The presence of an ejection systolic murmur is normal in pregnancy due to a hyperdynamic state, which resolves as soon as the baby is delivered.

Option C: Wide pulse pressure is rare in pregnant women

  • Wide pulse pressure is not an uncommon finding in pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following types of mutation is seen in sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Point Mutation:

  • Sickle cell anemia results from a point mutation in the β-globin gene (HBB) on chromosome 11.
  • Specifically, adenine (A) to thymine (T) change in the DNA sequence replaces glutamate codon (GAG) with valine codon (GTG) at the 6th position of the β-chain of hemoglobin.
  • This mutation leads to abnormal hemoglobin, causing rigid, sticky, distorted red blood cells.
  • Symptoms include pain episodes (sickle cell crisis), anemia, swelling in hands and feet, bacterial infections, and strokes.
  • Manifests around 5-6 months when a child inherits two defective copies of the HBB gene, one from each parent.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – Insertion:

  • One or more nucleotides inserted in DNA sequence (e.g., Huntington's disease, Fragile X syndrome).

Option C – Deletion:

  • Loss of one or more nucleotides or DNA segment during replication (e.g., cystic fibrosis).

Option D – Frameshift:

  • In a frameshift mutation, nucleotides are inserted or deleted in such a way that the resulting codons on mutated DNA are not divisible by 3. Thus, the mutated DNA has a changed sequence of codons (e.g., Tay-Sachs disease).

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents to the surgical outpatient department with complaints of mucus-containing diarrhea and bleeding per rectum from the last 3 months. On presentation patient's vitals are blood pressure of 90/70 mmHg, pulse rate of 110 beats/min, and respiratory rate of 21/min. On further evaluation, colonoscopy findings are consistent with ulcerative colitis. The patient does not respond to medical therapy. What will be the treatment of choice in this case?

choices.text: Colectomy + manual proctectomy + ileoanal pouch anastomosis

questions.solution:
Option C: Proctocolectomy with ileoanal pouch anastomosis

  • Clinical signs: Mucus containing diarrhea and bleeding per rectum are suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Restorative proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis- a procedure of choice for patients who wish to avoid a permanent ileostomy
  • Emergent operation
    • In patients with fulminant colitis or toxic megacolon.
    • Total abdominal colectomy with end ileostomy (with or without a mucus fistula) is recommended.
  • Elective operation
    • For patients with an increased risk of malignancy and those who are intractable to medical treatment.
      • Total proctocolectomy with end ileostomy - the gold standard for treating patients with chronic ulcerative colitis.
      • Total proctocolectomy with continent ileostomy (Koch's pouch).
      • Restorative proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis: The procedure of choice for patients who wish to avoid a permanent ileostomy.
      • Abdominal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis: For patients with indeterminate colitis and rectal sparing.
  • The diagram below shows the proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis.

 

Option A: Colectomy with ileostomy

  • The colon and rectum are both removed during this treatment. Proctocolectomy is regarded as the standard of care.
  • The surgeon might make a stoma or abdominal wall opening if the entire colon is removed.
  • The stoma allows the lower small intestine's tip to pass through.

Option B: Colectomy + manual proctectomy + ileoanal pouch anastomosis

  • Although it's one of the treatments of chronic ulcerative colitis, it is not the treatment of choice.

Option D: Ileorectal anastomosis

  • Abdominal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis is done for patients with indeterminate colitis and rectal sparing.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presented with vision problems, light-colored skin, learning disabilities, and a dipped chest bone. His father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 32. Ophthalmologic examination reveals downward and inward lens subluxation. What is the most likely amino acid accumulated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Homocysteine:

  • Homocystinuria is indicated by symptoms like lens subluxation, learning disabilities, skeletal abnormalities, and a family history of premature myocardial infarction.
  • It's caused by cystathionine β-synthase deficiency and features ectopia lentis, severe myopia, cataracts, and thromboembolic episodes.
  • Elevated homocysteine levels trigger endothelial injury, leading to atherosclerosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ornithine:

  • Elevated ornithine levels relate to urea cycle disorders, not atherosclerosis. Symptoms include vomiting, lethargy, and seizures.

Option B - Cysteine:

  • Cystinuria, resulting from cysteine metabolism defects, doesn't cause atherosclerotic plaque. It leads to recurrent cystine kidney stones.

Option D - Leucine:

  • Leucine metabolism disorders aren't linked to premature atherosclerosis. Symptoms include decreased appetite, lethargy, skin rash, and blood sugar fluctuations.

questions.text: Which gas is used to measure the diffusing capacity of the lung?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Carbon monoxide:

  • Carbon monoxide (CO) is used to measure the diffusing capacity of the lung (DLCO). DLCO measures how effectively a gas moves from the alveoli into the bloodstream, influenced by the alveolar-capillary membrane's surface area and thickness. CO binds rapidly to hemoglobin, making its transfer diffusion-limited, while oxygen uptake is primarily limited by perfusion.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Carbon dioxide:

  • Carbon dioxide is not used to measure the diffusion capacity of the lungs.

Option C - Nitrogen:

  • Nitrogen can be used to measure lung volumes
  • Carbon monoxide rather than nitrogen is used to measure the diffusing capacity of the lungs

Option D - Helium:

  • Helium is used to measure FRC.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who has had HIV for 2 years and has a CD4 count of 150 cells//µL presents with the complaint of fatigue, weight loss, and cough for several days. He is also complaining of chest tightness on breathing. The patient says that the symptoms are getting worse every day. The doctor ordered sputum microscopy. The Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain of his sample showed black-coloured cysts, as shown in the image below. Select the true statement about the pathogen causing the above-mentioned disease as shown in the image.

choices.text: Ampicillin is the drug of choice
Occurs in patients with CD4+ count 400/µL

questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option A: Stain : - Gomori Methenamine Silver (GMS)

The given image shows Pneumocystis jirovecii

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii (previously known as Pneumocystis carinii) causes PCP (Pneumocystis pneumonia)
  • It most commonly infects HIV patients (with CD4+ cell count below 200/µL) and patients on long-term immunosuppressive regimens.
  • It mostly affects only immunocompromised individuals.
  • Patients with hematologic and non-hematologic malignancies.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiographs show perihilar haziness with diffuse mottling.
  • Sputum induced by inhalation of a hypertonic saline solution is a useful specimen for microscopic demonstration of the organism.
  • Gomori’s methenamine silver (GMS) staining is the method of choice to demonstrate the cysts of P. jirovecii. The cysts resemble black-coloured crushed ping-pong balls against the green background.
  • Cotrimoxazole is the DOC for Pneumocystis pneumonia.

Image: The spore cases (cysts) of pneumocystis stained with the Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain.

Other Options

Option B: Ampicillin is the drug of choice

  • The drug of choice for pneumocystis jirovecii is amphotericin B.
  • Ampicillin is the drug of choice in infections caused by a beta-lactamase-negative type of H. influenza, enterococci, and L. monocytogenes.

Option C: Occurs in patients with CD4+ count 400/µL

  • It usually occurs in patients with a CD4+ count below 200/µL.
  • Recurrent bacterial pneumonia occurs when CD 4 count is 200-500/ µL.

Option D: Diagnosed on X-Ray imaging

  • This disease is most commonly diagnosed through sputum microscopy.
  • The X-ray can show consolidation, but diagnosis is confirmed by sputum culture,

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common congenital heart defect?
questions.solution:
Option B: Membranous VSD

  • The most common of all congenital cardiac malformations seen clinically are membranous VSDs.
  • Ventricular septal defects account for approximately two-thirds of all cardiac septal defects.
  • The membranous interventricular septum forms by the proliferation and fusion of tissue from three different sources:
    • Right bulbar ridge
    • Left bulbar ridge
    • Atrioventricular (AV) cushion
  • Because of this complex formation, the probability of defects is very high.

Option A: Persistent truncus arteriosus

  • Partial development of the aorticopulmonary septum due to the absence of migration of neural crest cells to the truncus arteriosus region will cause persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA).

Option C: Common ventricle

  • A common ventricle is a congenital heart defect characterized by the presence of a single, undivided ventricular chamber instead of the typical two separate ventricles. This condition is also referred to as a "single ventricle."

Option D: Foramen secundum defect

  • It is a genetic defect.
  • Since the question asks for the most common defect, the answer is membranous VSD.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a suspected tuberculoma was sent to the radiological department for brain imaging. The radiologist decided to take magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Which peak on MR spectroscopy is seen in tuberculoma?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lipid lactate

  • Tuberculomas or tuberculous granulomas, one of the most severe morphological forms of tuberculosis, are well-defined focal masses caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.

  • The brain and the lung are the sites where tuberculomas typically develop.

  • A significant fatty lactate peak at 0.9 to 1.33 ppm and decreased NAA are typically seen in MR spectroscopy results.

  • The high lipid content in the tubercle bacillus cell wall is principally responsible for the lipid peak in tuberculoma.

  • Lactate is a sign of anaerobic glycolysis and necrosis inside the tuberculoma.

  • However, other disorders, such as high-grade gliomas [GBM] that have necrosis, can also show a lipid lactate peak.

Option B: N-acetyl aspartate

  • N-acetyl aspartate (NAA), a vital enzyme in the production of myelin, is deficient, leading to an accumulation of N-acetyl aspartate in the brain, cerebrospinal fluid, plasma, and urine.

  • NAA peak of 2 ppm is visible in MR spectroscopy of Canavan's disease, also known as spongiform degeneration of white matter or aspartoacylase deficiency.

Option C: Creatinine

  • Creatinine resonates at a chemical change of 3.0 ppm (with a second usually smaller peak at 3.95 ppm 2).

  • Although it decreases in high-grade gliomas, it is typically maintained at a reasonably stable level and is mostly utilised as an easy internal reference (to enable ratio computations).

  • In addition, it does not peak in cerebral metastases, and the absence of a peak in an enhancing cerebral mass suggests metastasis over glioblastoma.

Option D: Choline

  • Choline is a precursor of acetylcholine (ACH) and a cell membrane component frequently studied using MR spectroscopy. It has a chemical shift of 3.2 ppm.

  • Because choline measures cellular membrane turnover, it is raised in neoplasms, demyelination, inflammation, and gliosis.

  • Tumors and acute demyelinating lesions commonly exhibited Choline peak, decreased NAA, and frequently increased lactate.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents to his primary health care physician for further evaluation of hypercalcemia detected incidentally during a routine medical check-up. She is asymptomatic and denies constipation, palpitation, or bone pains. Her laboratory investigations are as follows: 


	
		
			
			Haemoglobin
			
			
			12.2 g/dL
			
		
		
			
			Serum
			
			 
		
		
			
			Creatinine
			
			
			0.7 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Proteins
			
			 
		
		
			
			Total
			
			
			7.0 g/dL
			
		
		
			
			Albumin
			
			
			4.1 g/dL
			
		
		
			
			Calcium
			
			
			13.2 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Phosphorus
			
			
			2.2 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Alkaline phosphatase

			PTH
			
			
			130 U/L

			72
			
		
	


After administration of normal saline, her serum calcium is 12 mg/dl. The rest of the laboratory investigations, including the cancer screen, are normal. What is the most likely indication for surgery in this patient?

choices.text: Serum calcium >11 mg/dL above the normal value

questions.solution:
Option D:  Serum calcium >11 mg/dL above the normal value

  • This clinical vignette is about a patient suffering from primary hyperparathyroidism, the most common cause of asymptomatic hypercalcemia (as also seen in this patient).
  • The patient is asymptomatic, but her serum calcium level is more than 11 mg/dL, higher than the normal upper limit. Therefore, this patient needs surgery for the treatment of her condition.
  • Normal calcium levels: 9-11 mg %

Role of surgery in the management of hyperparathyroidism:

  • A more aggressive surgical approach should be considered in most patients due to concerns of subtle neuropsychiatric symptoms, long-term skeletal effects, and potential for cardiovascular deterioration.

Option A: Age >50 years

  • Age of less than 50 years is an indication for surgery of primary hyperparathyroidism

Option B: 24-hour urine for calcium >100 mg/day

  • Urinary excretion of > 400 mg/day of calcium is an indication of surgery

Option C: Osteopenia on bone density testing

  • T score in bone density test between -1 to -2.5 indicates osteopenia

questions.text: First, add a few crystals of ferrous sulfate to 5 ml of gastric aspirate. Then, add 5 drops of 2% sodium hydroxide. Boil the mixture and then allow it to cool. Afterward, add 10 drops of 10% hydrochloric acid. If the solution turns a 'greenish-blue color,' this indicates the presence of cyanide in the aspirate. What is the name of this bedside test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lee Jones Test:

  • The Lee Jones Test is a bedside test used to detect the presence of cyanide in gastric aspirate.

  • Proceedure:

    • Add a few crystals of ferrous sulfate to 5 ml of gastric aspirate.
    • Add 5 drops of 2% sodium hydroxide.
    • Boil the mixture and then allow it to cool.
    • Finally, add 10 drops of 10% hydrochloric acid.

  • If the solution turns a "greenish-blue color," it indicates the presence of cyanide in the gastric aspirate. This test is a rapid and simple way to assess whether cyanide poisoning may be a factor in a patient's condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Marquis Test:

  • The Marquis Test is a different chemical test used to identify the presence of various drugs, including opiates and amphetamines, by using specific reagents. It is not related to the detection of cyanide.

Option C - Marsh Test:

  • The Marsh Test is a method used to detect and quantify arsenic in a substance or solution. It is not used for cyanide detection.

Option D - Mydriatic Test:

  • It is used for testing for the presence of toxic alkaloids found in datura plants

questions.text: When does a secondary oocyte complete its second meiotic division to become a mature ovum?
questions.solution:
Option C: At fertilization

  • The primary oocyte is arrested in the diplotene stage of Meiosis I. Only after the luteinizing hormone surge, it will form a secondary oocyte.
  • The secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II of meiosis II
  • The secondary oocyte completes its second meiotic division to become a mature ovum at fertilization.

 

Option A: At ovulation

  • A secondary oocyte begins meiosis II at ovulation, but this division is arrested at metaphase.
  • The secondary oocyte will remain arrested in metaphase until a sperm penetrates it at fertilization.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the secondary oocyte degenerates.

 

Option B: Before ovulation

  • Meiosis I is a reductional division during which the maternal & paternal chromosomes are separated.
  • Please note that before ovulation, due to the LH surge, the primary oocyte completes meiosis I and releases the secondary oocyte and first polar body.
  • A Luteinizing hormone surge occurs 36 hours before ovulation, and a luteinizing hormone peak occurs 12 hours before ovulation (1 polar body released).

 

Option D: At puberty

  • The oocyte is resting in the diplotene stage of prophase 1 (meiosis I) at the time of birth. Meiosis I completed at the time of ovulation (puberty).
  • A secondary oocyte & 1 polar body are released (at the time of ovulation). T
  • he secondary oocyte is arrested in "Metaphase II" (meiosis II) till fertilization.
  • After fertilization, 2nd polar body & ovum are released.
  • Oocytes are protected by granulosa cells, and those not protected undergo atresia.

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 30 weeks gestation with nausea and dizziness every time she lies down. She states that the symptoms subside when she turns on her side. Which of the following is the best explanation of such a presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Inferior vena cava (IVC) compression

  • Pregnant patients in the supine position have compression of the inferior vena cava and aorta by the gravid uterus, which leads to decreased venous return and, thus, hypoperfusion.
  • Symptoms include tachycardia, diaphoresis, nausea, vomiting, pallor, weakness, lightheadedness and dizziness.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Raised intragastric pressure

  • Normal pregnancy leads to chronically increased intra-abdominal pressure, and the stomach is increasingly displaced upwards, leading to an altered axis and increased intra-gastric pressure.
  • The patient’s symptoms are more likely due to inferior vena cava compression due to a gravid uterus rather than raised intragastric pressure.

Option C: Decreased fluid in semicircular canals

  • The semicircular canals are activated by a circular motion and are filled with endolymph.
  • The semicircular canals play a crucial role in detecting the head’s rotational position.
  • Decreased fluid in semicircular canals causes nausea and dizziness every time with rotational head movement rather than when the patient lies.
  • Fluid levels within the semicircular canals remain unchanged during pregnancy.

Option D: Peripheral venous Pooling in pregnancy

  • The diameter of lower extremity veins and venous volume significantly increase in pregnant women.
  • This factor predisposes pregnant women to thrombosis through Virchow’s triad components, including endothelial injury, venous stasis, and hyper- coagulability.

questions.text: A 70-year-old Chinese male presents to the clinic due to right-sided cervical lymphadenopathy for 4 months. It is associated with 3 episodes of epistaxis. On physical examination, unilateral serous otitis media, ipsilateral trigeminal neuralgia, and ipsilateral palatal palsy are seen additionally. The patient is a suspected case of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma. Which of the following is the best prognostic factor for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.?
questions.solution:
Option B: WHO type III histology

  • The Chinese population has a higher susceptibility to nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Epstein-Barr (EB) virus is closely related to nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Environmental factors include polluted air, tobacco smoke, opium, nitrosamine from dry salted fish, and smoke from incense and wood.
  • Clinical features include nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, denasal speech, conductive hearing loss, and serous or suppurative otitis media due to eustachian tube blockage.
  • Tumours extending into the surroundings involve CN II, III, IV, V, VI, IX, and X.
  • The cervical nodal enlargement usually occurs between the jaw angle and the mastoid.
  • Distant metastasis is to the bone, lung, liver, and other sites.
  • Histology:

WHO type PATHOLOGY Risk factor Other factors Survival/ Recurrence
I 25% Keratinizing Squamous cell differentiated carcinoma Smoking Low-risk population Older age Non-familial factors 10% Survival
II 12% Non-keratinizing Squamous cell differentiated carcinoma EBV Preserved foods Familial factors 50% Survival
III 60% Non-keratinizing Squamous cell undifferentiated carcinoma EBV High a risk population, Children Preserved foods Familial factors 60% Survival Best prognosis

 

  • Diagnosis is by endoscopic evaluation, imaging studies, audiogram, and biopsy.
  • Treatment includes radiotherapy and chemotherapy.
  • Treatment is based on TNM staging.

 

Tumour/Node/Metastasis Staging of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma
Stage Description
T Classification
Tx Primary tumours cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of a tumour
T1 Confined to the nasopharynx or extends to the oropharynx and/or nasal cavity
T2 The tumour extends to the parapharyngeal space
T3 Tumour involves sinuses and/or the skull base
T4 Intracranial, infratemporal/masticator space involvement, cranial nerve involvement, orbit, or hypopharynx
N Classification
N0 No nodal involvement
N1 Unilateral cervical lymph nodes ≤6cm, or unilateral or bilateral retropharyngeal nodes ≤6 cm above the supraclavicular fossa
N2 Bilateral cervical lymph nodes ≤6 cm above supraclavicular fossa
N3a Lymph node >6 cm
N3b Supraclavicular lymph node
M Classification
M0 No distant metastasis
M1 Distant metastasis (includes mediastinal nodes)
Stage Classification
Stage I T1N0M0
Stage II T1N1M0, T2N0M0 and T2N1M0
Stage III T3N0M0, T3N1M0, and T1 to T3N2M0
Stage Iva T4, any NM0
Stage IVb Any TN3M0
Stage IV Any T; any N, M1

Option A: High angiogenesis in the tumour

  • New growth in the vascular network is essential for the proliferation and metastatic spread of cancer cells.
  • HIF-1α and VEGF play roles in angiogenesis.
  • It has been reported that the overexpression of HIF-1α in nasopharyngeal carcinoma correlates with carcinogenesis proliferation and poor prognosis.

Option C: Lung metastases

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is known for its propensity for distant metastases.
  • Lung metastasis is one of the most important causes of death for patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Option D: WHO type I histology

  • WHO type I has a 10% survival rate and poor prognosis.
  • WHO type III has a 60% survival rate with the best prognosis.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is not seen in a patient of Grave's disease?

choices.text: Subperiosteal new bone formation in metacarpals

questions.solution:
Option A: Enophthalmos

  • Enophthalmos is defined as the posterior displacement of the globe of the eye in an anterioposterior plane within the orbit.
  • This is caused by one of the following factors:
    • Enlargement of the orbit
    • Reduction of the orbital contents
    • Shrinkage or contracture of orbital contents
  • However, the ophthalmopathy seen in Graves' disease is called exophthalmos.

 

Options B, C, and D: Gynecomastia, Subperiosteal new bone formation in metacarpals, and Pretibial myxedema are features of Grave's disease.

questions.text: International health regulations define their purpose and scope to prevent, protect against, control and provide a public health response to the international spread of disease. Which of the following disease is not covered by International health regulations?
questions.solution:
Option B: HIV/AIDS

  • The International Health Regulations (WHO IHR) do not cover HIV/AIDS.
  • It covers:
  • Immediately Notifiable Diseases
    • Smallpox
    • Human Influenza
    • Wild Polio
    • SARS
  • Potentially Notifiable Diseases:
    • Public health importance:
      • Cholera
      • Plague
      • Yellow fever
      • Viral hemorrhagic fever
      • West Nile fever
      • Dengue
      • Rift valley fever
      • Meningococcal disease.
  • Biological / Chemical / Radiological events
  • Serious illnesses of Unknown origin

 

Option A: Cholera

  • Cholera is a potentially notifiable disease under the Internation health regulation.
  • Extremely contagious cholera can result in severe acute watery diarrhoea. After consuming infected food or drink, symptoms usually appear between 12 hours and 5 days.

Option C: Plague

  • Plague is a potentially notifiable disease under the Internation health regulation.
  • Yersinia pestis is the bacterium that causes Plague. The most common ways for humans to contract the plague are through handling a plague-infected animal or by getting bitten by a rodent flea that is carrying the disease.

Option D: Yellow fever

  • Yellow fever is a potentially notifiable disease under the Internation health regulation.
  • Acute viral hemorrhagic disease called yellow fever is spread by infected mosquitoes. A safe and economical vaccine that is incredibly successful at preventing yellow fever is available. Yellow fever vaccination only needs to be administered once to provide lifelong immunity and protection from the disease.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient who complains of breathlessness on exertion associated with a productive cough has come up for a consult. On auscultation, bilateral basal inspiratory fine crackles. What is the next best step to confirm a diagnosis of ILD?
questions.solution:
Option B: HRCT

  • High-resolution computed tomography is superior to the plain chest x-ray for early detection and confirmation of suspected ILD.
  • In addition, HRCT allows better assessment of the extent and distribution of disease.
  • Ideally, a lung biopsy should be done, but in the appropriate clinical setting, HRCT may be sufficiently characteristic to preclude the need for a lung biopsy.

Option A: Chest X-ray

  • Chest X-ray is a good initial test to assess the lungs grossly for any other pathology, but it is not the best for studying fibrosis in detail.

Option C: Gallium – 67 DTPA scan

  • Gallium scans are nuclear medicine tests.
  • Gallium salts are absorbed by tumors, inflammation, and both acute and chronic infection, allowing imaging of these pathological processes.
  • Gallium is particularly useful in imaging osteomyelitis involving the spine and in imaging older and chronic infections that may cause a fever of unknown origin.

Option D: MRI

  • A magnetic resonance image could differentiate areas of reversible active inflammation from irreversible fibrosis, but the best imaging modality for visualizing fibrosis is HRCT.

questions.text: An experiment is conducted in which ADH is administered at an hour interval to three to four subjects (A to D). In the following figure, which lines most likely reflect the response to ADH administration in a normal patient and a patient with central diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - DB:

Central diabetes insipidus:

  • Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is characterized by deficient secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin. This condition results in the inability of the kidneys to retain water, leading to the excretion of large volumes of dilute urine. Patients typically experience polyuria (excessive urination) and polydipsia (excessive thirst).
  • The diagram illustrates the response to ADH administration in normal and central DI patients. In central DI (represented by "B" in the diagram), urine output is high in the absence of ADH, and administration of ADH results in a sharp decrease in urine output, indicating the absence of endogenous ADH secretion. This contrasts with the response in normal individuals (represented by "D"), where urine output is lower in the absence of ADH and further decreases upon ADH administration.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - BA:

  • “B” represents a patient with central diabetes insipidus.
  • "A" represents a patient with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This is because the urine output is high despite introducing ADH, which is due to the failure of the kidneys to respond to the action of the ADH.

Option B - BD:

  • “B” represents a patient with central diabetes insipidus.
  • "D" represents a normal patient after ADH is given.

Option C - DA:

  • "D" represents a normal patient after ADH is given.
  • “A” represents a patient with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This is because the urine output is high despite introducing ADH, which is due to the failure of the kidneys to respond to the action of the ADH.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the hospital outpatient department with the complaint of fever, cough associated with discharge in the ear, and decreased hearing. On examination, the below image depicted which found to be the complication of the above-described symptoms. Which of the following describes best about the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Formed over the occipital bone:

  • This child presented with the sign and symptoms of fever, cough associated with ear discharge and decreased hearing is suspected for the diagnosis of Citelli’s abscess.
  • It is an extratemporal complication of otitis media.
  • The case discussed above is otitis media. An abscess is formed due to the extrusion of cholesteatoma from the medial surface of the mastoid process at the attachment of the posterior belly of the digastric muscle.
  • It generally appears behind the mastoid more towards the occipital bone in comparison to the postauricular mastoid abscess, which forms over the mastoid.
  • Few authors consider the abscess of the digastric triangle, which is formed by tracking of pus from the mastoid tip, as Citelli’s abscess.
  • An abscess is formed behind the mastoid more towards the occipital bone (compared to a postauricular mastoid abscess which forms over the mastoid).

Treatment:

  • Incision and drainage.
  • Injectable antibiotics.
  • Operating for the underlying cause.

Abscesses in relation to mastoid infection:

  • Postauricular abscess: This is the commonest abscess that forms over the mastoid.
  • Pinna is displaced forwards, outwards, and downwards.
  • In infants and children, abscess forms over mac-ewen’s triangle; pus, in these cases, travels along the vascular channels of lamina cribrosa.
  • A zygomatic abscess occurs due to infection of zygomatic air cells situated at the posterior root of the zygoma.
  • Swelling appears in front of and above the pinna.
  • There is associated oedema of the upper eyelid. In these cases, pus collects either superficial or deep to the temporalis muscle.
  • Bezold abscess: It can occur following acute coalescent mastoiditis.
  • When pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Drained through external meatus:

  • This option is wrong because the image shows the abscess in relation to otitis media which is Citelli’s abscess.
  • After all, it is more towards the occipital bone.
  • Whereas in meatal abscess, pus breaks through the bony wall between the antrum and external osseous meatus.
  • Citelli’s abscess can be drained through small incision.
  • The abscess may be drained through external meatus if it burst into the meatus.

Option C- Presents as lower neck swelling:

  • This option is also wrong because lower neck swelling is not usually related to otitis media.
  • Mostly it is seen in cases of thyroid disease, thyroglossal cyst, parapharyngeal, or retro-pharyngeal abscess.

Option D- Retro-orbital abscess:

  • This option is also wrong because the image depicted above shows an abscess in relation to the mastoid and more above the occipital bone.
  • Whereas retro-orbital abscesses occur in infections of the soft tissue of the eye in orbit.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man, CEO of a multinational company, suffered from palpitations, breathlessness and sweating while attending a conference. He was rushed to a nearby hospital. On physical examination, the patient was pulseless, and his blood pressure was unrecordable. The ECG was done with findings as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia

  • Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (MVT) is a broad, complicated heartbeat that originates in the ventricles from a single focus.
  • It consists of continual, widespread complicated tachycardia with the uniform broad QRS complex.
  • The heart rate is 250 bpm, and broad complex QRS is seen in all leads.
  • In a patient with pulseless VT, the heart rate increases, causing a decrease in diastolic duration; as a result, the end-diastolic volume decreases leading to a decreased stroke volume, causing the patient to collapse.
  • Therefore, a hemodynamically unstable patient needs a DC shock of 200 J biphasic.
  • However, stable monomorphic VT treatment is done with IV procainamide/Amiodarone.

Option B: Bidirectional tachycardia

  • It is a regular ventricular tachyarrhythmia having 2 different morphologies of QRS, which alternate at a rate between 140 and 180 bpm.
  • Most commonly associated with digoxin toxicity.

Option C: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

  • Multiple ventricular foci are present in polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (PVT), a kind of ventricular tachycardia in which the QRS complex results has varied amplitude, axis, and duration.
  • PVT is typically brought on by myocardial ischaemia or infarction, and other causes which prolong the QT interval include:
    • Metabolic abnormalities (Hypokalemia, Hypomagnesemia and Hypocalcemia)
    • Erythromycin + HCQ also cause QT interval prolongation and lead to Torsades de Pointes. Other banned drugs, such as Cisapride, Astemizole, and Ketoconazole, cause QT interval prolongation and can make the ventricular myocardium unstable.
  • ECG:
    • QTc prolongation (c= corrected)
    • Broad QRS complex tachycardia: the amplitude, axis and duration of QRS are variable, so it is called Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

Option D: Ventricular fibrillation

  • ECG findings include
    • It has chaotic irregular deflection having a varying amplitude
    • P waves, QRS complexes, and T waves cannot be identified
    • Ventricular rate of 150 to 500 per minute and decreasing amplitude with duration

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to compare rapid and slow sand filters by his senior. All of the following are true for Rapid sand filters except?

choices.text: No preliminary storage of raw water is required
Can be gravity type or pressure type

questions.solution:
Option C: Frequent washing is not required

  • A slow sand filter does not require frequent washing, but a Rapid sand filter requires frequent washing.

Rapid Sand filter

  • No preliminary storage of raw water is required.
  • Operation requires highly skilled persons.
  • Can be gravity type or pressure type.
  • Required frequent washing.
  • Suitable in big cities.

Option A: No preliminary storage of raw water is required

  • No preliminary storage of raw water is required for a rapid sand filter.

Option B: Operation requires highly skilled persons

  • Operation requires highly skilled persons in the rapid sand filters.

Option D: Can be gravity type or pressure type

  • Rapid sand filters can be gravity type or pressure type.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not classified as a Conditionally Essential Amino Acid (CEAA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Histidine:

  • Histidine is classified as an Essential Amino Acid (EAA) or Semi-Essential Amino Acids, not a Conditionally Essential Amino Acid (CEAA).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C are CEAA

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents to the surgical OPD with an epigastric mass, early satiety, and weight loss for the last 3 months. Abdominal examination revealed an irregular mass in the epigastric region 4×5cm, moving with respiration, and hard in consistency. Endoscopic Biopsy from an ulcer-proliferative lesion in the greater curvature revealed gastric adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is a manifestation of carcinoma stomach?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - All of the above:

  • Most patients have advanced stage III or IV at the time of diagnosis.
  • The most common symptom is weight loss, reduced food intake due to anorexia, and early satiety.
  • Chronic occult blood loss occurs, leading to Iron deficiency anemia and heme-positive stools.
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes such as Trousseau's syndrome (thrombophlebitis), acanthosis nigricans, and peripheral neuropathy may occur.
  • Cervical, Left supraclavicular ( referred to as Virchow's node called Troisier's sign), and axillary (Irish )lymph nodes may be enlarged.
  • Malignant ascites or pleural effusion or aspiration pneumonitis may be present.
  • The abdominal mass shows a large tumor (T4 tumor), liver metastasis, or carcinomatosis (including Krukenberg's tumorof the ovary).
  • Palpable umbilical nodes (Sister Mary Joseph's node) are pathognomic of advanced disease.
  • Rectal examination shows drop metastasis or rectal shelf of Blumer in the pouch of Douglas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Troisier's sign:

  • The Troisier sign shows an enlargement of a left-sided supraclavicular lymph node. The enlarged supraclavicular lymph node is known as a Virchow node. It is suggestive of gastric malignancy.

Option B - Trousseau's syndrome:

  • Trousseau syndrome is an acquired blood clotting disorder that results in migratory thrombophlebitis (inflammation of a vein due to a blood clot)
  • It is often associated with gastric carcinoma.

Option C - Irish node:

  • Gastric carcinoma may cause an enlargement of an axillary lymph node called the Irish node.

questions.text: Parkinson's disease is associated with a lesion in the deep part of the cerebral cortex. Identify the incorrect match with the labeled structure.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - B-Claustrum:

Incorrect Match

  • Basal ganglia: Subcortical nuclei primarily for motor control, motor learning, and emotional behaviors.
  • Functions: Planning and programming of voluntary motor activity.
  • Largest part: Corpus striatum, including caudate and lenticular nuclei (putamen, globus pallidus externus and internus).
  • Also includes: Subthalamic nucleus (STN) and substantia nigra (SN).
  • Disruption leads to movement disorders like Parkinson's Disease and Huntington's Disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cingulate gyrus:

  • Situated above the corpus callosum
  • It is an arch shape structure and a component of the limbic system

Option C - Insular:

  • The insular cortex is a part of the cerebral cortex that if folded deep into the lateral sulcus separates the temporal lobe from the frontal and the parietal lobe.

Option D - Thalamus:

  • The location of the thalamus is just above the brain stem
  • Between the cerebral cortex and the midbrain

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy visits the clinic accompanied by his parents with a history of failure to thrive. Physical examination shows jaundice and splenomegaly. A CBC shows a microcytic, hypochromic anaemia (haemoglobin - 7.3 g/dL). Fetal haemoglobin accounts for most of the haemoglobin. A peripheral blood film is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: β-thalassemia

  • Peripheral smear given in the case shows hypochromic, microcytic RBCs, with anisocytosis, poikilocytosis and target cells; along with clinical features suggests the diagnosis of β-Thalassemia
  • Unpaired α-chains precipitate in red blood cells, accounting for ineffective erythropoiesis and increased hemolysis.
  • In homozygous β-thalassemia, fetal haemoglobin (haemoglobin F) accounts for most of the haemoglobin, although increased levels of haemoglobin A2 are also present.

Option A: G6PD deficiency

  • It presents with normocytic anaemia rather than microcytic anaemia, as seen in this case.
  • It occurs secondary to exposure to oxidizing agents such as dapsone, nitrofurantoin, and fava beans.

Option B: Sickle cell anaemia

  • The absence of sickle cells on the peripheral smears of this patient effectively rules out sickle cell anaemia.

Option D: Iron deficiency anaemia

  • Hypochromic microcytic cells are also found in IDA, but jaundice and splenomegaly effectively rule it out.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female from a rural area presents to OPD for a follow-up visit after she had a recent history of compound leg fracture. She now has signs of acute appendicitis and is taken to surgery. When her appendix is removed, it contains light-coloured, 20.5-cm long roundworm and bile-stained eggs. Her features are consistent with Ascaris. How does she probably acquire this infection?

choices.text: Ingestion of water containing filariform larvae
Ingestion of food contaminated with the eggs

questions.solution:
Option D: Ingestion of food contaminated with the eggs

  • Human infection is acquired through ingesting food contaminated with embryonated eggs.

  • The clinical scenario and microscopic features of the egg are indicative of Ascaris.

  • Embryonated Ascaris eggs released in faeces may contaminate food or water, which is then consumed. Ascaris do not attach to the intestine but maintains their position by mobility.

  • The worm may become hypermotile (e.g., during febrile periods, anaesthetic use, or antibiotic use) and migrate into the appendix or bile duct.

  • Habitat of ascaris adult worm: Jejunum / upper ileum

Ascaris causes:

  • Intussusception → Intestinal obstruction

  • Strongly associated with Loeffler's syndrome → Massive eosinophilia

Egg of Ascaris:

  • Bile stained

  • Unsegmented ovum

  • Eggs with rugosity

  • The image below: Fertilised egg of Ascaris

  • Image below: Unfertilised egg of Ascaris

Option A: Ingestion of water containing filariform larvae

  • Infection of Ascaris in humans is not acquired through ingestion of water contaminated with filariform larvae.

  • The ingested larvae cannot mature into free-living adults and must find a new host to continue the life cycle.

  • In contrast, embryonic eggs are swallowed and hatched in the small intestine. They subsequently develop into filariform larvae, which go into the lungs and result in eosinophilia.

Option B: Skin penetration by filariform larvae.

  • The filariform larvae can penetrate through the skin but don't cause infectivity.

  • From there, they travel through the bloodstream and lymphatic to the lungs, which are eventually coughed up and ingested.

  • They mature into adult female larvae, incapable of infectivity without male larvae.

Option C: Skin penetration by rhabditiform larvae

  • Rhabditiform larvae cannot penetrate through the skin.

  • They develop into filariform larvae which are capable of penetrating through the skin.

  • Infection of Ascaris in humans is acquired through ingestion of food contaminated with embryonated eggs.

questions.text: Which bias occurs if very ill or very healthy individuals are excluded from the study?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Neyman bias:

  • Neyman bias, also known as prevalence or incidence bias, occurs when very ill or very healthy individuals are excluded from the study, resulting in the true target population not being represented accurately.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pygmalion bias:

  • Pygmalion bias is related to the motivation of the investigator affecting the subject's performance, leading to exaggerated responses.

Option B - Hawthorne bias:

  • Hawthorne bias occurs when subjects modify their behavior due to being monitored.

Option C - Berksonian bias:

  • Berksonian bias is caused by differences in hospitalization rates, where hospitalized individuals may have more severe illnesses or engage in less healthy behavior.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is accompanied to the obstetrics and gynecology OPD by her mother. The girl has not yet started menstruation. On examination, she has developed secondary sexual characteristics appropriately. The gynecologist provides counseling and reassurance to them and educates them about the stages of puberty. What is the correct sequence of events in puberty?
questions.solution:
Option D: Thelarche-pubarche-growth spurt-menarche

  • In girls, the sequence of changes in puberty is as follows:
    • Thelarche-pubarche-growth spurt-menarche (mnemonic - TPGM)
      • Thelarche is the appearance of breast tissue due to the action of estradiol. 
      • Pubarche is the appearance of pubic hair.
      • The growth spurt is the height increase that affects axial (trunk) and appendicular (limb) components. In later puberty, however, the growth spurt is primarily truncal. 
      • Menarche is the first menstrual bleed. It occurs 2 to 2.5 years after thelarche. 

Option A: Thelarche-pubarche-menarche-growth spurt

  • Menarche occurs at the end of the growth spurt.
  • It occurs 2 to 2.5 years after thelarche.

Option B: Pubarche-thelarche-growth spurt-menarche

  • The first step of puberty in females is the appearance of breast tissue.
  • It is termed thelarche.

Option C: Menarche-growth spurt-thelarche-pubarche

  • Menarche never occurs as the first step in puberty.
  • It is rather the last event in female puberty.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is not associated with coenzymes?

choices.text: It has a high molecular weight
It combines loosely with enzyme molecules.
Mostly belongs to the vitamin B complex group

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It has a high molecular weight:

  • Coenzymes are non-proteinaceous substances aiding enzyme catalysis, possessing a high molecular weight. Unlike enzymes, they lack a defined tertiary structure and can bond to enzymes through various means like ionic or covalent bonds. Coenzymes facilitate bond cleavage, electron transfer, and methyl group transfer in enzyme-catalyzed reactions, exemplified by thiamine pyrophosphate.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - It combines loosely with enzyme molecules: Coenzymes attach loosely to enzymes and can be released after the reaction, but their association is essential for enzyme function.

Option C - Mostly belongs to the vitamin B complex group: While many coenzymes belong to the Vitamin B complex, not all do. Examples include thiamine pyrophosphate (B1 derivative) and pyridoxal phosphate (B6 derivative), but others like NAD+ are not part of this group.

Option D - It is heat-stable:  Coenzymes are generally heat-stable, but not universally so; some may be sensitive to heat.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT considered a fundamental aspect of Disaster Management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Rehabilitation:

  • Rehabilitation involves restoring physical, social, and economic infrastructure post-disaster, making it a crucial part of the recovery phase rather than a fundamental aspect like impact, mitigation, and preparedness.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and C are 3 fundamental aspects of Disaster Management.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a history of progressive shortness of breath and dry cough for 2 weeks. He reports mild substernal chest pain. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years. On examination, he is afebrile, his blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, his pulse is 74 beats/min, and his respiratory rate is 16 breaths/min. On chest auscultation, fine basal crackles are heard bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal. Lower limbs are edematous bilaterally up to mid-thigh, and oedema is more pronounced at the ankles. An echocardiogram is done, which reveals an ejection fraction of 25% with anterior, septal, and lateral wall motion defects. He is admitted to the ward and stabilized on furosemide, spironolactone, bisoprolol, and ramipril. What would be the best next investigation in course of his management?
questions.solution:
Option B: Angiogram

  • This patient’s presentation is consistent with heart failure secondary to ischemic heart disease.
  • An echocardiogram is a screening tool used for looking at wall motion abnormalities.
  • Angiography:
    • Angiography or arteriography is an imaging technique in which a contrast dye is used to visualize the inside of blood vessels and the heart chambers.
    • It is a gold standard investigation to assess the anatomy, and physiology of the heart.
    • Angiography is used to assess vasculature abnormalities and to evaluate the extent of severity of cardiac disease in symptomatic individuals.
    • The indications of angiography are as follows:
Indications of Angiography:
Asymptomatic or Symptomatic Ventricular tachycardia
Symptomatic Acute Coronary Syndrome
Chest pain syndromes
STEMI
Congestive Heart failure
Pericardial disease
Cardiac Transplantation

Option A: Endomyocardial biopsy

  • Endomyocardial biopsy (EMB) is a procedure that obtains small amounts of myocardial tissue percutaneously for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.
  • Endomyocardial biopsy (EMB) is used for surveillance of cardiac allograft rejection and the diagnosis of unexplained ventricular dysfunction.
  • It is not an investigation to look at vessels.

Option C: Viral titers

  • This patient’s presentation is consistent with heart failure. Heart failure can occur secondary to viral infections such as hepatitis B and C, COVID-19, and parvovirus etc.
  • However, this patient does not have any prodromal viral symptoms and his history is more consistent with heart failure in the setting of ischemic heart disease.

Option D: Exercise tolerance test(ETT)

  • ETT is contraindicated in the setting of ongoing chest pain.
  • As this patient has ongoing pain, it should not be done.

questions.text: A forty-three-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of a lesion on his left hand. Examination of the dorsal surface of his left-hand shows a scaly erythematous lesion. A skin sample of the lesion shows abnormal keratinocytes covering the entire epidermis thickness. The arrows indicate apoptotic bodies in the image below. In this patient's skin cancer, which of the following proteins plays the most critical role in mediating programmed cell death?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cytochrome C

  • This patient has squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.
  • Cytochrome C is a critical regulator of apoptosis present in the mitochondrial membrane.
  • It seeps out of mitochondrial pores and activates apoptotic protease activating factor-1 (APAF-1).
  • APAF-1 converts procaspase-9 to caspase-9, causing downstream caspases to be activated (cysteine proteases).
  • These effector caspases break various target proteins, such as endonucleases, nuclear proteins, and cytoskeletal proteins, to orchestrate the morphological and biochemical changes that occur during apoptosis.

Option A: Catalase

  • Catalases through reactive oxygen species can cause cell death but do not cause planned cell death.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C: Cytokeratin

  • Cytokeratin is a protein found in epithelial cells.
  • It is not associated with apoptosis.

Option D: Myeloperoxidase

  • Myeloperoxidase, through reactive oxygen species, can cause cell death but does not cause planned cell death.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought by his parents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of ocular misalignment and also explains that when the child focuses on an object, his eyes are crossed. The doctor, after examination, advises the parents that this disorder has an enthusiastic sequel. If management is beginning on time, only 15-degree misalignment is noted. What will be the best management for the patient’s current pathology?

choices.text: Refraction under atropine followed by full correction

questions.solution:
Option A: Refraction under atropine followed by full correction

  • The case mentioned above is of accommodative esotropia, best treated by refraction correction.
  • A form of strabismus, often known as eye misalignment or accommodative esotropia.
  • One of the most prevalent types of esotropia (crossed eye) in children is refractive esotropia.
  • One or both eyes may cross when trying to focus, which is known as accommodating esotropia.
  • Children who are generally more farsighted (hyperopic) than usual experience this. This implies that clear vision requires more effort from the eyes, especially when viewing close-up objects.
  • Accommodation is the term for this concentrating endeavor.
  • The quantity of accommodation needed increases with the proximity of an item to the eye.
  • Excessive convergence or eye crossing might be a side consequence of the accommodative effort.
  • The algorithm for management of accommodative squint:

Refractive correction

↓

Orthoptics/occlusion for amblyopia

↓

Operative correction

↓

Prism correction

Option B: Surgical correction

  • Surgery is only necessary if wearing glasses does not completely straighten the eyes.
  • In this situation, strabismus surgery (eye muscle surgery) may be advised to reduce the degree of crossing in the spectacles.

Option C: Occlusive patches

  • If the lazy eye has a focusing issue, glasses must be worn to remedy it first.
  • The vision in the lazy eye can occasionally be corrected by just wearing the glasses as directed.
  • Occlusion therapy (patching) can enhance vision in the lazy eye, if it is still limited or if glasses are not required.

Option D: Ocular exercises

  • Exercise shouldn't be used as a replacement for medical care.
  • Patient-directed eye exercises alone should not be considered the only treatment for strabismus because the origins and presentations of the condition vary widely.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with swelling of his left parotid gland and pain, especially during chewing.
