He had experienced ten such episodes lasting 10–15 days each in the previous 2 years. Physical examination revealed a swollen left parotid gland with local tenderness and erythema of the overlying skin. The immunological evaluation revealed an IgA level of less than 7 mg/dl. The remaining immunoglobulin IgE, IgM, and IgG were within normal limits. Which of the following is the most important risk about the given condition?

choices.text: It is the second most common immunoglobulin deficiency disease
Decreased risk of sinopulmonary infections and diarrhoea
Reduced risk of SLE and rheumatoid arthritis

questions.solution:
Option D: Anaphylactic reaction on blood transfusion

  • The given clinical features and laboratory investigations point towards Isolated IgA deficiency.
  • The normal range for IgA is 36–268 mg/dl.
  • Common immunodeficiency is caused by impaired differentiation of naïve B lymphocytes to IgA-producing plasma cells.
  • Affected individuals have extremely low levels of both serum and secretory IgA.
  • Most individuals with IgA deficiency disease are asymptomatic. Because IgA is the major antibody in external secretions, mucosal defences are weakened, and infections occur in the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and urogenital tracts.
  • The symptomatic patient commonly presents with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and diarrhoea.
  • When IgA-deficient patients are transfused with blood containing normal IgA, some of these patients develop severe, even fatal, anaphylactic reactions because the IgA behaves like a foreign antigen (since the patients do not produce it and are not tolerant to it).

Option A: It is the second most common immunoglobulin deficiency disease

  • IgA deficiency is the most common immunoglobulin deficiency disease.

Option B: Decreased risk of sinopulmonary infections and diarrhoea

  • IgA deficiency increases the risk of sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections.

Option C: Reduced risk of SLE and rheumatoid arthritis

  • IgA-deficient patients have a high frequency of respiratory tract allergy and a variety of autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT contribute to the generation of force by skeletal muscle during contraction?

choices.text: Increase in the number of cross-bridges at the sarcomere level
Increase in the number of motor unit activation or recruitment
Increase in the frequency of motor unit activation
Decrease in the number of motor unit activation or recruitment

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Decrease in the number of motor unit activation or recruitment:

  • Decreasing the number of motor units activated or recruited reduces the overall force output of skeletal muscle contraction because fewer muscle fibers are involved, resulting in weaker contractions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increase in the number of cross-bridges at the sarcomere level: Increasing the number of cross-bridges at the sarcomere level contributes to force generation by enhancing the interaction between myosin and actin filaments, leading to stronger muscle contractions.

Option B - Increase in the number of motor unit activation or recruitment: Increasing the number of motor units activated or recruited is crucial for force generation, as it involves more muscle fibers simultaneously, resulting in higher force production.

Option C - Increase in the frequency of motor unit activation: Increasing the frequency of motor unit activation also contributes to force generation by stimulating muscle fibers more frequently, leading to greater force output.

questions.text: Which of the following long-term health effects is NOT associated with PCOS?
questions.solution:
Option D: Postdated pregnancy

  • Pregnancy complications of PCOS include preterm birth and not postdates.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Increased Risk of Cardiovascular Disease

  • PCOS is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. Women with PCOS are more likely to have risk factors such as obesity, insulin resistance, and dyslipidemia, contributing to an elevated cardiovascular risk.

Option B: Infertility

  • Infertility is a common consequence of PCOS due to anovulation or irregular ovulation. Hormonal imbalances in PCOS can disrupt the normal menstrual cycle, making it challenging for women to conceive.

Option C: Abnormal glucose tolerance test

  • PCOS is associated with insulin resistance, which can lead to abnormal glucose metabolism and an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Therefore, an abnormal glucose tolerance test is a potential long-term health effect associated with PCOS.

questions.text: An 8-day-old male neonate is brought to the emergency department by his mother with complaints of fever and poor feeding for the past 8 hours. Her mother has a history of premature membrane ruptures leading to an emergency cesarean section. The child has no other abnormalities. On examination, the neonate has a temperature of 104°F, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and chest pain. Which of the following will be the best step of management to prevent further deterioration of the patient's current pathology?

choices.text: Start IV antibiotics immediately after taking a sample for blood culture
Start oral antibiotics and monitor for worsening of the clinical condition
Monitor the baby and start IV fluids only

questions.solution:
Option A: Start IV antibiotics immediately after taking a sample for blood culture

  • This is a case of neonatal sepsis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever and poor feeding for 8 days.
  • The neonate has a perinatal risk factor of premature rupture of membranes, and the examination findings suggest early-onset sepsis symptoms, so IV antibiotics should be started immediately after taking a sample for blood culture.
  • Early empiric therapy for neonates with sepsis should cover group B Streptococcus and gram-negative enteric organisms, especially Escherichia coli. After retrieving the blood culture report, the treatment is modified accordingly.
  • The course of therapy is 10 days.
  • A repeat blood culture monitors the response to antibiotics at 24 to 48 hours and the improvement in the clinical condition.

Option B: Start oral antibiotics and monitor for worsening of the clinical condition

  • Baby has a history of poor feeding, so starting oral antibiotics is not a good step.
  • Baby has tachypnea, and oral antibiotics can lead to aspiration.
  • The IV route has good bioavailability as compared to the oral route.

Option C: Reassure and do nothing

  • Neonatal sepsis requires management.
  • Reassurance and not doing anything will only worsen the condition.

Option D: Monitor the baby and start IV fluids only

  • IV fluids will only help in maintaining the hydration of the baby.
  • If there is ongoing sepsis, antibiotics are an absolute indication, preferably through the intravenous route.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy complains of numbness and tingling in both feet. The examination reveals no pulse in the femoral artery, increased blood pressure in the arteries of the upper extremities, and enlarged arteries. Which of the following abnormalities would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Option C: Postductal coarctation of the Aorta

  • Upper extremity pulses are normal or increased, but absent or non-palpable lower extremity pulses indicate post-ductal narrowing
  • No pulse in the femoral artery.
  • Increased blood pressure in the upper extremity arteries, enlarged intercostal arteries, and numbness and tingling in both feet are clinical symptoms suggestive of post-ductal coarctation of the Aorta.
  • The narrowing of the Aorta affects the blood supply to the lower extremities.

Coarctation of the Aorta

  • Sharp indentation involving anterior, lateral & posterior walls of the Aorta; the Medial wall is usually spared
  • Juxta ductal part of the Aorta is mostly involved
  • The medial wall of the Aorta is usually spared
  • Clinical features:
    • Severe Coarctation Heart failure in neonates with B/L feeble or impalpable femoral pulses
    • Hypertension
    • Milder disease: Intermittent claudication of lower limbs
  • Chest X-ray:
    • Figure 3's appearance
    • Notching of the inferior margin of 3rd to 9th ribs usually seen >3 years of age
    • Contrast esophagogram & barium swallow: E sign
  • Treatment:
    • Balloon angioplasty
    • Anti-hypertensives for hypertension

Option A: Double aortic arch

  • The double aortic arch may press on the trachea and oesophagus, leading to trouble breathing and swallowing.
  • Stridor and repeated pulmonary infections are some of the symptoms.

Option B: Tetralogy of Fallot

  • TOF is cyanotic heart disease.
  • Tetralogy of Fallot is most often diagnosed in the first few weeks of life due to either a loud murmur or cyanosis.
  • VSD, overriding Aorta, RVH and infundibular pulmonary stenosis are the features of TOF.

Option D: Right aortic arch

  • Right aortic arch anomalies occur in approximately 0.01 to 0.1 per cent of the general population.
  • In general, these anomalies do not directly cause any cardiovascular problems.
  • However, right aortic arches can be associated with other congenital heart defects, vascular rings, and chromosomal abnormalities such as DiGeorge syndrome in some patients.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy comes to your clinic with complaints of headache and runny nose for the last 4 days. The patient gives a history of worsening symptoms during summer while playing outside. On examination, you found the features depicted below in the image. Which of the following will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Allergic Rhinosinusitis

  • The above clinical features are seen in allergic rhinosinusitis
  • The image depicted explains Dennie morgan's folds
  • Most common allergen- House dust mite/ carpet dust
  • Most common in urban areas & developed countries.
  • Most common in snow-covered area Symptoms® Intermittent < 4 days/ week or < 4 weeks®
  • Persistent > 4 days /week or < 4 weeks
  • On examination
    • Atopic facies
    • Dennie Morgan lines
    • Nasal crease/ allergic salute
  • On Nasal examination: Mucoid secretion in the nasal cavity, the Mulberry appearance of the nasal mucosa. The nasal mucosa is hypertrophied
  • Treatment Steroids (Intranasal spray)

Option B: Vasomotor Rhinosinusitis

  • Results from changes in vascular tone and permeability: Stimulation of afferent sensory nerves is the most likely pathophysiologic mechanism, and it activates the parasympathetic nerves that supply the nasal mucosal glands
  • Symptoms include clear watery rhinorrhea and occasionally sweating/epiphora.
  • Dennie morgan's folds are not seen here.

Option C: Atrophic Rhinosinusitis

  • Causes include aggressive turbinectomy, excessive nasal surgery, nutritional deficiencies (iron or vitamin A or D deficiency), chronic bacterial infection (e.g., Klebsiella ozaena, less common in the antibiotic era), trauma, manifestations of granulomatous diseases, chronic cocaine abuse, and radiation therapy
  • Symptoms include paradoxical nasal congestion/obstruction despite a wide nasal cavity, nasal crusting, and odor.
  • Dennie morgan's folds are not seen here.

Option D: Rhinitis Medicamentosa

  • Rhinitis medicamentosa (RM), also known as rebound rhinitis, is a condition characterized by nasal congestion that is triggered by the overuse of topical vasoconstrictive medications, most notably intranasal decongestants; recreational use of intranasal cocaine may also cause a similar condition.
  • Underlying reasons for intranasal decongestant use can usually be identified, such as allergic or nonallergic rhinitis, acute or chronic rhinosinusitis, nasal polyps, night-time use of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), or upper respiratory tract infection.
  • With regular daily use, some patients may develop rhinitis medicamentosa in 3 days, whereas others may not have evidence of rebound congestion after 4 to 6 weeks of use.
  • Management of rhinitis medicamentosa is focused on withdrawal of intranasal decongestants and treatment of congestion and underlying conditions with appropriate interventions.
  • Dennie morgan's folds are not seen here.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who has been using IUCD for contraception for a year now presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge, fever and pain in the lower abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Keep the IUCD, give an antibiotic, follow up for antibiotic response, and then decide on IUCD removal.
Start antibiotics and then remove IUCD
Remove IUCD and then start antibiotics
Wait till the next menstrual cycle for any intervention

questions.solution:
Option A: Keep the IUCD, give an antibiotic, follow up for antibiotic response and then take a decision regarding IUCD removal

  • The history suggests that pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) occurred in an intrauterine copper device (IUCD) user.
  • PID generally arises within 4 weeks of insertion and is caused by an undetected vaginal infection or the tail of IUCD generating ascending infection.
  • The presence of PID in and of itself is not an indicator of IUCD removal because there might be other reasons for PID, which are normally treatable with antibiotics. Because sterile standards are maintained, it is uncommon for PID to arise due to IUCD implantation.
  • PID without abscess formation is initially treated with systemic antibiotics and then monitored for the response.
  • Actinomycosis is a frequent infection linked with IUCD. If signs or symptoms of infection appear in women harbouring Actinomyces species, the device should be removed, and antimicrobial therapy should be started. Actinomyces species are susceptible to gram-positive antimicrobials, particularly penicillins.

Option B: Start antibiotics and then remove IUCD

  • If there is no clinical improvement after 48-72 hours of starting antibiotic therapy, then the decision about the removal IUD can be made.

Option C: Remove IUCD and then start antibiotics

  • When PID is diagnosed in an IUD user, the IUD does not have to be taken out.
  • A comprehensive assessment of the literature showed that treatment results did not differ significantly between women with PID who kept the IUD and those who had the IUD removed.

Option D: Wait till the next menstrual cycle for any intervention

  • If PID develops in an IUCD user, appropriate antibiotic therapy can be started without waiting for the next menstrual cycle.
  • Antibiotic therapy can be started at the onset of symptoms, and if there is no clinical improvement after 48-72 hours of antibiotic therapy, then the decision about removing IUCD can be made.

questions.text: An alcoholic develops intractable vomiting for 2 days with loose motions. Since he had decreased food intake and altered sensorium, he has been brought to the hospital, where the fluid loss and dyselectrolytemia are aggressively corrected with the fluid infusion. Post-treatment, the patient starts having quadriplegia and mutism. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Osmotic demyelination syndrome

  • Chronic hyponatremia management is significantly complicated by the asymmetry of the cellular response to the correction of plasma Na+ concentration.
  • Specifically, brain cells' reaccumulation of organic osmolytes is attenuated and delayed as osmolality increases after correcting hyponatremia, sometimes resulting in degenerative loss of oligodendrocytes and an osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS).
  • Overly rapid correction of hyponatremia (>8–10 mM in 24 h or 18 mM in 48 h) is also associated with a disruption in the integrity of the blood-brain barrier, allowing the entry of immune mediators that may contribute to demyelination.
  • The lesions of ODS classically affect the pons.
  • Patients with central pontine myelinolysis can present 1 or more days after overcorrection of hyponatremia with paraparesis or quadriparesis, dysphagia, dysarthria, diplopia, a "locked-in syndrome," and/or loss of consciousness.
  • Other regions of the brain can also be involved in ODS, most commonly in association with lesions of the pons but occasionally in isolation; in order of frequency, the lesions of extrapontine myelinolysis can occur in the cerebellum, lateral geniculate body, thalamus, putamen, and cerebral cortex or subcortex.
  • Therefore, the clinical presentation of ODS can vary as a function of the extent and localization of extrapontine myelinolysis, with the reported development of ataxia, mutism, parkinsonism, dystonia, and catatonia.
  • Relowering of plasma Na+ concentration after overly rapid correction can prevent or attenuate ODS.
  • However, even appropriately slow correction can be associated with ODS, particularly in patients with additional risk factors; these include alcoholism, malnutrition, hypokalemia, and liver transplantation.

Option B: Syndrome of inappropriate ADH production

  • SIADH is caused by various drugs, such as SSRIs and disorders of the pulmonary system and CNS.
  • It causes euvolemic hyponatremia.
  • However, it is not associated with mutism or quadriparesis.

Option C: Brainstem infarct

  • Brainstem infarcts may present with quadriplegia.
  • Coma can occur.
  • However, the risk factors are hypertension, diabetes and chronic atherosclerotic diseases.

Option D: Meningitis

  • Meningitis presents with headache, fever and signs of meningeal irritation.
  • Meningitis complicated by brain abscess can cause a focal neurologic deficit.

questions.text: A 10-day-old infant presents with a complaint of projectile vomiting. His mother states that the infant will actively drink his milk, but he forcefully vomits after each feeding. The infant shows signs of failure to thrive, with weight loss, dehydration, and lethargy. Physical examination reveals a firm, nontender, mobile, "olive-shaped" epigastric mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Congenital pyloric stenosis

  • This patient with projectile vomiting after feedings, failure to thrive, weight loss, dehydration, lethargy, and a firm, nontender, mobile, "olive-shaped" epigastric mass most likely has Congenital pyloric stenosis.
  • It is caused by hypertrophy of the circular muscle layer of the pylorus.
  • Hypertrophy of pyloric musculature → Obstruction, non-bilious projectile vomiting.
  • It typically presents in male infants within the first several days to weeks of life and is generally not seen at the time of birth.

Option A: Candida esophagitis

  • It is characterized by whitish plaques in the oesophagus and associated discomfort while eating.
  • It is typically seen in immunocompromised individuals, for example, those having a very low CD4 count secondary to HIV infection.

Option C: Esophageal cancer

  • A 10-day-old infant is the least likely candidate to have oesophagal cancer, as it is generally a disorder in older adults.
  • Projectile vomiting and an olive-shaped epigastric mass are also typically absent in oesophagal cancer cases.

Option D: Gastroesophageal reflux disease

  • It can present with a burning sensation or discomfort, particularly after meals.
  • It is also an adult disease and is generally seen in obese individuals.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female was admitted with a complaint of escalating abdominal pain, increased abdominal circumference, and recurrent diarrhea for 2 months. He has a history of consumption of bush teas for 5 months to reduce weight. Physical examination revealed mild jaundice, distended abdomen, and tenderness on RUQ. Laboratory results showed WBC 6.82 × 109/L, Hb 122 g/L, HbsAg (-), ALT 66 U/L, AST 81 U/L, serum total bilirubin 39.7 μmol/L, direct bilirubin 10.6 μmol/L, and ALB 32.8 g/L. CT scan of the abdomen revealed moderate ascites, hepatomegaly, delayed enhancement of parenchyma, and obscure hepatic veins. Which of the following drugs is effective in improving survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Defibrotide

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of veno-occlusive disease.
  • Bush tea contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids, which is a risk factor for the development of veno-occlusive disease.
  • Treatment of choice: If hepatic failure is present – Liver transplantation.
  • If there is no hepatic failure – side-to-side portocaval shunt.
  • One drug is effective in improving survival – DEFIBROTIDE.

Option A. B, and C do not improve survival rate in veno-occlusove diseases.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman came to the Medical outpatient department complaining of blurry vision; on inquiring, she told me she had been a patient of diabetes for 10 years. Moreover, have uncontrollable Blood pressure and kidney disease. She told the doctor that she had been diagnosed with proliferative diabetic retinopathy a few months ago. Now she complains of floaters and painless loss of vision. The doctor thinks of retinal detachment. Which type of retinal detachment is most commonly seen in proliferative diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Option B: Tractional

  • The most severe type of diabetic retinal illness is called tractional retinal detachment.
  • Tractional refers to tugging on the retinal surface, but "retinal detachment" denotes pulling powerful enough to pull the light-sensing retina away from the back of the eye. 
  • Damaged retinal blood vessels give rise to abnormal blood vessels that eventually form the vitreous, the jelly inside the eye.
  • These blood arteries densify and develop into membranes of fibrous scar tissue as they expand into jelly.
  • When the scar tissue eventually contracts, the retina is pulled away.
  • There are occasions when the retina is under such a lot of strain that tears or holes develop.
  • Diabetic tractional retinal detachment is the most advanced form of diabetic retinal disease. "Tractional" means that there is pulling on the retinal surface, and "retinal detachment" means that the pulling is strong enough to separate the light-sensing retina from the back of the eye.

Pathophysiology

  • Contractile vitreoretinal, epiretinal, intraretinal (rarely), or subretinal membranes pull the neurosensory retina away from the RPE in TRD related to proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) and penetrating trauma. 
  • PVR might be viewed as an improper or uncontrolled response to the healing process. The cellular makeup of these membranes was discovered through microscopic analysis.
  • These membranes contain RPE cells, glial cells, fibrocytes, macrophages, and collagen fibrils, among other critical components. 
  • The main participants in these membranes are RPE cells.
  • When the retina breaks form, they can enter the vitreous cavity.
  • It has been demonstrated that the magnitude of the retinal fractures correlates with the number of RPE cells in the vitreous cavity.
  • There are more RPE cells intravitreally when the break is greater.
  • Additionally, severe cryotherapy, cryotherapy applied to bare RPE, and scleral indentation after cryotherapy can all cause RPE cells to disseminate into the vitreous cavity.
  • The RPE cells undergo morphological changes once they are inside the vitreous cavity, where they have fibroblast-like activity and secrete growth factors that encourage collagen synthesis.
  • Causes:
    • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
    • Penetrating trauma
    • Proliferative sickle retinopathy
    • Retinal venous occlusions

Option A: Rhegmatogenous

  • The most typical form of retinal detachment is Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. If your retina has a little tear or crack, it may occur. 
  • If the retina tears or fractures, the gel-like fluid in the center of your eye, known as the vitreous, may get behind your retina. The vitreous then pushes the retina away from the rear of the eye, causing it to split. 
  • The commonest cause of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is aging. As you age, the vitreous tissue in your eye may shrink and change in texture. Your retina may occasionally injure if the vitreous shrinks and pulls on it.
  • Nearsightedness, eye injury, and rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Option B: Exudative

  • Exudative retinal detachment occurs when fluid accumulates behind the retina, but the retina is neither torn nor broken. Your retina may be pushed away from the back of your eye and detached if enough fluid becomes trapped behind it.
  • The most common causes of exudative retinal detachment are leaking blood vessels or swelling in the back of the eye.
  • Several things can cause swelling in your eye:
    • Injury or trauma to your eye
    • Tumors in your eye
    • Diseases that cause inflammation inside the eye
    • Coats disease, a rare eye disorder

Option D: Retinoschisis

  • A disorder known as retinoschisis occurs when a portion of the retina, which lines the interior of the back of the eye and transmits visual information to the brain and optic nerve, has split into two layers.
  • There will be poor vision in the area of the retina that is afflicted by retinoschisis.
  • This can happen in various retinal layers and for various reasons.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male comes into the outdoor patient department with the presenting complaints of increased hunger and thirst. On testing, it is noted that he has elevated blood sugar levels. Owing to the patient’s financial condition, it is decided to prescribe him sulfonylurea. Glibenclamide is preferred over Chlorpropamide in the treatment because the latter is more likely to cause which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Alcohol intolerance

  • Chlorpropamide is a first generation sulfonylurea. It accomplishes this by blocking K+ channels in the membrane of pancreatic beta cells, which results in inhibition of efflux of potassium ions. Accumulation of potassium ions inside the cell cause depolarization of the cell. Subsequently, this opens calcium channels allowing influx of calcium. Ultimately, the release of insulin is due to exocytosis of insulin containing secretory granules triggered by opening of voltage gated calcium channels.
  • Hangover-like symptoms, as well as nausea, vomiting, flushing, dizziness, and headaches, are hallmarks of alcohol intolerance and reactions similar to those caused by disulfiram.
  • The accumulation of acetaldehyde in the blood as a result of the inhibition of hepatic aldehyde dehydrogenases is the root cause of this condition.
  • Another potential adverse reaction to this treatment is cholestatic jaundice, which manifests clinically as an unusually elevated level of hepatic alkaline phosphatase in comparison
  • Additionally, it creates increased ADH, which stands for severe inappropriate antidiuretic hormone, and this condition manifests as euvolemic hyponatremia (average amount of body fluids with low sodium).

Increase Insulin

Sulfonylureas

Meglitinides

1st Generation :

  • Chlorpropamide
  • Tolbutamide
  • Nateglinide
  • Repaglinide

2nd generation:

  • Glipizide
  • Gliclazide
  • Glibenclamide
  

Option A: Lactic Acidosis

  • Lactic acidosis is the high amount of lactic acid accumulation in the body. The main drug that can cause it among anti-diabetics is Metformin.

Option C: Pancreatitis

  • Pancreatitis is defined as inflammation of the pancreas. It usually presents itself as epigastric pain that radiates to the back. Among anti-diabetic medications, GLP-1 analogues have been associated with an increased risk of pancreatitis.

Option D: Urinary Tract Infection 

  • Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors are a class of anti-diabetic medications commonly known to cause urinary tract infections (UTI). SGLT2 inhibitors are used in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus. They work by inhibiting the SGLT2 channels in the proximal renal tubules, which leads to a reduction in glucose reabsorption and an increase in urinary glucose excretion. Increased urinary glucose creates a favorable environment for the growth of bacteria.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of chronic fatigue, cyanosis with bluish lips, and painful, stiff joints for one month. She has no significant medical or surgical history. Physical examination reveals signs of pallor and jaundice. Her vitals are within normal limits. Investigation findings include anaemia, pancytopenia, and thrombocytopenia with increased reticulocyte count. Direct Coombs test is positive for C3d. The peripheral blood film is shown below. What is the most likely cause of this pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cold AIHA

  • This is the case of cold agglutinin haemolytic anaemia (cold AIHA), in which the patient presents with complaints of chronic fatigue, cyanosis with bluish lips, and arthralgia for one month.
  • Examination findings of pallor and jaundice, along with the presenting complaints, indicate an ongoing haemolytic disorder mediated by cold temperature.
  • This is further confirmed by anaemia, pancytopenia, thrombocytopenia, and increased reticulocyte count on laboratory findings.
  • Positive direct Coombs test for C3d and marked agglutination of RBCs seen in the above picture on peripheral blood smear confirms the diagnosis.
  • Cold AIHA is an autoantibody-mediated disorder characterised by the destruction of RBCs by cold-mediated autoantibodies at cold ambient temperatures of 0–4°C resulting in abnormal complement activation leading to acute intravascular and extravascular Haemolysis.
  • Clinical symptoms result from binding IgM to red cells in vascular beds where the temperature may fall below 30°C, such as in exposed fingers, toes, and ears.

Option B: Warm AIHA

  • It is also an autoantibody-mediated disease characterised by the binding of heat-sensitive autoantibodies, instead of cold-mediated antibodies, to RBCs, leading to increased red cell destruction by phagocytes and reticuloendothelial systems.
  • This autoantibody reaction is usually triggered by body temperatures of ≥ 37°C/98.6°F, with peripheral blood smear showing abundant spherocytes.

Option C: Hemoglobinopathy

  • It is usually characterised by the abnormal structure of haemoglobin, which can be seen on peripheral blood smears in the form of sickle-shaped or rod-shaped RBCs, target cells with microspherocytes.
  • It includes haemoglobin C disease, haemoglobin Zurich, sickle cell anaemia, and thalassemia.

Option D: G6PD deficiency

  • It is an inherited disease resulting in impaired glutathione regeneration, leading to increased susceptibility of RBCs to oxidative stress like infection, various drugs, and consumption of fava beans. This results in episodic hyperproliferative haemolytic anaemia.
  • Heinz bodies (small inclusions in RBCS containing precipitates of denatured haemoglobin) and bite cells are usually seen on peripheral blood smears.

questions.text: A 35-year-old diabetic primigravida, at 36 weeks of gestation, comes to the obstetric department for a routine antenatal check-up. She is completely well, and her pregnancy was uneventful except for a history of fewer fetal activities 2 days ago. Her diabetes is well-controlled, and she takes the multivitamins, iron, and calcium pills as prescribed. Upon physical examination, her vitals were normal, and the physician ordered an NST (Non-Stress test) to assess fetal well-being. The patient may be sent back home and asked to return after 1 week if the NST shows any of the following findings:

choices.text: At least two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with a baseline variability of 5-25 bpm
One fetal heart rate acceleration is noted in 20 mins with a baseline variability of 5- 25 bpm
Two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm
Three fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 30 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: At least two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with baseline variability of 5-25 bpm

  • The Non-Stress test is primarily a test of sympathetic and parasympathetic fetal well-being.
  • In normal conditions, the fetal heart rate raises at least 15 beats whenever it moves.
  • If the baby shows two accelerations in heart rate lasting at least 15 seconds during the 20-minute test, it is read as normal or reactive.
  • A reactive non-stress test (NST) is a reassuring sign of fetal well-being.
  • If the heart rate does not accelerate with movement or another 20 minutes of observation fails to meet the criteria, the NST is considered non-reactive.

Incorrect options:

Option B: One fetal heart rate acceleration is noted in 20 mins with baseline variability of 5- 25 bpm

Option C: Two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm

Option D: Three fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 30 mins with baseline variability > 25 bp

questions.text: A 30-year-old young male came with sudden onset visual loss with no history of trauma. The fundus details cannot be appreciated on fundoscopy, and there is no significant systemic history. The other eye has evidence of sheathing of vessels in the periphery. Regarding the above-given condition, which one is the most common presenting symptom of this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Recurrent vitreous hemorrhage:

  • The above-given condition is Eales disease
  • Most patients complain about blurring or decreased vision, floaters and cow webs due to vitreous hemorrhage.
  • Recurrent Vitreous Hemorrhage in the young is the most common and pathognomic identifying feature.
  • Eales disease:
    • Also known as Antiopatia retinae juveniles, Periphlebitis retinae.
    • Eales disease is an Idiopathic occlusive vasculopathy. Tubercular protein hypersensitivity is postulated as a possible etiology.
    • The most common site is the peripheral retina.
    • Causes perivasculeritis of the retina
    • Also causes peripheral periphlebitis, usually bilateral
    • Common in young males in the Indian subcontinent
    • 3 overlapping stages - Inflammatory, occlusive and retinal neovascular stages
    • It is primarily a diagnosis of exclusion
    • Visual prognosis is good in most the cases

Clinical features:

  • Peripheral periphlebitis - sheathing, superficial retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots
  • Branch Retinal Vein Occlusions
  • Peripheral capillary non-perfusion with microaneurysms, tortuosity, vascular shunts and neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage
  • Complications: vitreous hemorrhage, tractional retinal detachment, macular epiretinal membrane, neovascular glaucoma

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Neovascularization:

  • Eales disease has 3 overlapping stages - Inflammatory, occlusive and retinal neovascular.
  • Neovascularization is not an early feature but rather a late feature of Eales's disease.

Option C - Macular edema:

  • Eales disease predominantly involves the retina, but macular involvement can also be seen.
  •  Macular edema is not the most common feature but can be seen in OCT (Optical Coherence Tomography)

Option D - Posterior subcapsular cataract:

  • The major etiological factors for posterior subcapsular cataracts are diabetes, ionizing radiation and aging.
  • Eales disease commonly presents in the young population.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman taking oral contraceptives presents with complaints of peripheral neuropathy, dry, scaly lips with cracks at the corner of the mouth. Blood examination reveals sideroblastic anemia. This patient's condition is caused by the deficiency of a vitamin that acts as a cofactor in which of the following steps of catecholamine synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - C:

  • Clinical features such as peripheral neuropathy and sideroblastic anemia in a patient on OCPs point to Vitamin B6 deficiency.
  • DOPA decarboxylase requires pyridoxal phosphate, the active form of vitamin B6, for L-DOPA conversion.
  • Additionally, vitamin B6 acts as a cofactor in various reactions including cystathionine synthesis, heme synthesis, decarboxylation, and transamination.
  • Clinical signs of deficiency include glossitis, gingivostomatitis, peripheral neuropathy, and sideroblastic anemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A:

This is false because:

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase catalyzes the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine in the cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (THB).
  • Clinical features of THB deficiency include swallowing difficulty, behavioral problems, seizures, and progressive neurologic deterioration, which this patient lacks.

Option B - B:

This is false because:

  • Tyrosine hydroxylase catalyzes tyrosine's conversion to L-DOPA in the cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (THB).
  • Clinical features of THB deficiency include swallowing difficulty, behavioral problems, seizures, and progressive neurologic deterioration, which this patient lacks.

Option D - D:

This is false because:

  • Dopamine β-hydroxylase catalyzes the conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine in the presence of the cofactor's vitamin C (ascorbic acid) and Cu2+.
  • Clinical features of vitamin C deficiency include follicular hyperkeratosis and perifollicular bleeding, ecchymoses, gingivitis, and impaired wound healing, which are not observed here.
  • Moreover, most patients with vitamin C deficiency will have either normocytic anemia or macrocytic anemia unlike this patient.

questions.text: Identify the type of time distribution shown in the Photograph below?
questions.solution:
Option B: Seasonal trend

  • The given image is showing peaking of disease in September of every year; which is showing seasonal fluctuation in the occurrence of a disease known as Seasonal trends.
  • Examples of diseases showing seasonal trends: Measles, URI, and GIT infections.

Other options

Option A: Epidemic

  • An epidemic occurs when a disease spreads quickly across a community, affecting a significant number of people in a little amount of time.
    • Single exposure, point source epidemic - Staph. food poisoning
    • Multiple exposures, point source epidemic - Typhoid
    • Propagated epidemic - Tuberculosis

Option C: Secular trend

  • In the Secular trend, the majority of communicable diseases are reducing with time.
  • Whereas non-communicable diseases are slowly rising.
  • So gradual decrease of communicable & gradual increase of non-communicable is also a secular trend of the disease.

Option D: Cyclical trend

  • A recurrent pattern that occurs often, such as seasonal variations in the abundance of insect vectors or respiratory diseases among elementary school students.  
  • The disease occurs after a gap of fixed years
    • Measles shows a cyclical trend once every 2-3years
    • Rubella shows a cyclical trend once every 6-8years
    • Influenza shows the maximum cyclical trend.

questions.text: A patient is having thick, gray coating on the throat and tonsils, followed with fever, chills and swollen glands in the neck. Microscopic examination of nasopharyngeal or pharyngeal swab showed gram positive organism with a special stain. What are the constitutes of the stain?

choices.text: Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic acid
Carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, and methylene blue

questions.solution:
• The constitutes of the stain are Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic acid.
  • The clinical scenario given in the question is suggestive of diphtheria.
  • Gram positive organism causing gray colored coating (pseudomembrane) is Corynebacterium diphtheriae .
  • So, the specific stain is Albert stain: To demonstrate metachromatic granules (Volutin, Babes Ernst, polar bodies) of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Contents of Albert stain:-

  • Albert stain is made up of two staining solutions:
  • Stain A- glacial acetic acid, malachite green, toluidine blue
    Stain B- Iodine and Potassium iodide in water

1: Crystal violet, Gram's iodine: used in Gram staining.

3, 4: Carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, and methylene blue: Used in ZN staining (Refer to the image below).

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the endogenous production of beta-alanine in humans?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Uracil:

  • Beta-alanine is derived from pyrimidine catabolism, including the degradation of uracil, forming coenzyme A, pantothenic acid, and dipeptides like carnosine.
  • Beta-alanine is also formed from aspartate by a decarboxylation reaction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Adenine:

  • Deamination of adenine forms hypoxanthine and not beta-alanine.

Option B – Guanine:

  • Guanine deamination forms xanthine.
  • It does not form beta-alanine.

Option C – Adenosine:

  • Adenosine degradation leads to hypoxanthine or uric acid, but not beta-alanine.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 4 hours after the sudden onset of excruciating pain in his right calf. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. The right foot is cold and pale, and palpation of the right posterior tibial artery shows no pulse. Muscle strength is 1/5, and the sensation to touch significantly decreases in the right lower extremity. His serum creatinine kinase concentration is elevated. Arterial duplex sonography shows absent blood flow distal to the right popliteal artery. Compared with a healthy adult, which of the following sets of intracellular electrolyte concentrations are most likely to be found in this patient's right distal gastrocnemius muscle?


	
		
			 
			Na+
			K+
			Ca2+
		
		
			A
			↑
			↓
			Normal
		
		
			B
			↑
			↑
			↑
		
		
			C
			↓
			↑
			Normal
		
		
			D
			↓
			↓
			Normal
		
		
			E
			↑
			↓
			↑
questions.solution:
Option E: E

  • This constellation of changes is consistent with late limb ischemia a stage at which the muscle cells have been irreversibly damaged, and necrosis has begun.
  • Once the cells' supply of ATP is depleted, energy-dependent cellular functions decrease, including Na+/K+ ATPase activity and calcium efflux through the cell membrane, resulting in an increase in intracellular sodium and calcium with a decrease in potassium.
  • The release of cellular enzymes, as evidenced by this patient's elevated serum creatinine kinase, indicates cell lysis, which is a sign of irreversible cell injury. This patient's elevated serum creatinine kinase suggests the release of cellular enzymes, indicating cell lysis, which is a sign of late ischemia.
  • A similar pattern of electrolyte changes occurs in ischemic myocardial cells (e.g., due to myocardial infarction).

Option A: A

  • The constellation of increased sodium, decreased potassium, and normal calcium is consistent with acute cellular ischemia. Because ischemic muscle cells rely on anaerobic metabolism, they quickly deplete their supply of ATP, leading to lactic acidosis and early symptoms of limb ischemia.
  • The affected cells counteract this acidosis by activating sodium-hydrogen exchangers, causing intracellular sodium levels to rise.
  • Intracellular potassium levels also increase, but the mechanism is unknown. Mild muscle weakness, minimal sensory loss, and no paresthesia are expected in patients with acute limb ischemia, as neurons remain intact.
  • This patient, however, has pain, pulselessness, paresthesia, and paralysis. Moreover, elevated serum creatine kinase levels are not expected because muscle cells are not yet irreversibly damaged in the acute phase of an ischemic event.

Option B: B

  • The constellation of increased sodium, potassium, and calcium is seen in reperfusion injury, of irreversibly damaged muscle. 
  • Reperfusion injury typically occurs hours to days after the blood supply is restored to an ischemic muscle and is mostly due to the generation of free radicals and intracellular calcium overload.
  • This patient, however, is at a prolonged stage of limb ischemia, and perfusion to the muscle has not yet been restored. Therefore, another set of findings is expected.

Option C: C

  • The constellation of decreased sodium, elevated potassium, and unaltered calcium is not consistent with any stage of ischemia.

Option D: D

  • The constellation of unaltered calcium and decreased sodium and potassium is not consistent with any stage of ischemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for adjuvant chemotherapy after mastectomy?

choices.text: Presence of malignant cells in biopsy
There is no indication for adjuvant chemotherapy

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Size > 1cm & lymph node-positive:

  • After mastectomy, Chemotherapy may be recommended to destroy undetected cancer cells and reduce the risk of cancer recurring. This is called adjuvant Chemotherapy.
  • Tumour size greater than 1cm, positive lymph nodes, or adverse prognostic factors are some indications for adjuvant Chemotherapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Presence of malignant cells in biopsy:

  • The presence of malignant cells in biopsy is indicates neoplasm.
  • It does not provide enough evidence regarding whether the patient will benefit from adjuvant chemotherapy

Option C - Family history of breast cancer:

  • Family history of breast cancer can influence treatment decisions, such as the choice of surgery (e.g., lumpectomy versus mastectomy), the extent of lymph node dissection, and the use of adjuvant therapies (e.g., chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, targeted therapy).

Option D -There is no indication for adjuvant chemotherapy:

  • Adjuvant Chemotherapy is indicated in patients with positive lymph nodes post-surgery.
  • It is also indicated in patients who are at high risk for recurrence.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old female presents to the emergency with complaints of difficulty in breathing. She reports no associated cough or fever. On examination, her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), her pulse is 120/min, her respiration rate is 28/min, and her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. There are scattered wheezes on pulmonary examination. A chest x-ray is shown below:



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option A: Short-acting beta 2 agonists

  • This patient is most likely suffering from acute exacerbation of asthma. The management of acute exacerbation of asthma involves the use of short-acting beta 2 agonists like salbutamol.
  • Short-acting beta 2 agonist drugs including albuterol (salbutamol), levalbuterol, and terbutaline, are the drugs of choice for treating acute exacerbation of severe asthma. The management of asthma is summarised as follows:

Option B: Long-acting beta 2 agonist

  • Long-acting beta 2 agonists (LABAs), such as formoterol and salmeterol, have a prolonged duration of action (≥ 12 hours) compared to short-acting beta 2 agonists (SABAs). They are used for long-term asthma and COPD symptom control.
  • LABAs are typically administered via nebulizer or metered-dose inhaler. Unlike SABAs, which provide quick relief, LABAs are not intended for immediate symptom relief during acute exacerbations of asthma.

Option C: Oral theophylline

  • Oral theophylline is used in the management of asthma. However, it has no role in the treatment of acute exacerbation of asthma.

Option D: Inhaled ipratropium bromide

  • These drugs are used in the treatment of COPD. However, these are not preferred for the treatment of asthma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the psychiatric outpatient department by his friend due to a history of making obscene phone conversations with an unknown lady on the telephone. During history, it is discovered that the patient usually discloses his sexual preoccupations vocally and entices her to discuss her sexual activities. Masturbation generally follows the talk, often finished after the contact is broken. He is diagnosed with scatologia. Scatologia is an example of which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option C: Paraphilia

  • Paraphilias (sexual deviations or perversions) are sexual preference disorders in which sexual arousals occur frequently and significantly in response to objects that are not normally associated with sexual arousals, such as nonhuman objects, self or sexual partner suffering, humiliation, children, or non-consenting person.
  • Paraphilias can be of several types. These include:
  • Paedophilia
  • Exhibitionism
  • Fetishism
  • Frotteurism
  • Sexual Sadism
  • Transvestism
  • Sexual Masochism
  • Voyeurism
  • Bestiality
  • Scatologia
  • Scatologia is characterized by making obscene phone calls with an unknown accomplice.
  • The anticipation of phoning induces tension and arousal.
  • The telephoner (usually male) verbally exposes his preoccupations and induces the recipient to talk about her sexual activity.
  • It is accompanied by masturbation, often completed after the contact is interrupted.
  • People, sometimes compulsively, send obscene messages by electronic mail to transmit sexually explicit messages, images, and videos (CYBER-SEX).

Option A: Eating disorder

  • Eating disorders are syndromes characterized by their presenting symptoms, e.g., weakness, weight loss, dental caries, hyponatremia, and hypokalemia.
  • Most common are bulimia nervosa, anorexia nervosa and binge-eating disorder.

Option B: Sleep disorder 

  • Sleep disorders are characterized by any condition that leads to a disturbance in the normal rhythm or pattern of sleep.
  • It can have an organic or psychological cause.
  • Most commonly involve insomnia, hypersomnia, narcolepsy, sleep apnea, and sleep paralysis.​​​​​​​

Option D: Defense mechanism

  • Defense mechanisms are automatic and unconscious psychological processes that protect against anxiety generated by intrapsychic conflicts.
  • Common examples are sublimation, altruism, displacement, intellectualization, rationalization, and suppression.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman has been experiencing lower abdominal pain and frequent urination for seven months. She has no other symptoms, and tests have been inconclusive. Cystoscopy revealed a finding, what is true about the management of this condition?

choices.text: Conservative management; Has a good prognosis
Application of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the bladder

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Application of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the bladder:

This patient is suffering from interstitial cystitis, and the treatment is the instillation of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the distended bladder under anaesthesia. Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition causing bladder pressure, bladder pain and pelvic pain.

Pathology-

  • There is pancystitis with fibrosis of vesical musculature along with linear ulcers in the bladder mucosa. Microscopically, severe inflammation of all layers of bladder with fibrosis is observed. 
  • Bladder eventually becomes thimble (systolic) bladder with decreased bladder capacity up to 30-60 ml (less than 100 ml). 


Features- Pain. 

  • Decreased bladder capacity. 
  • Pain increases with bladder distension. 
  • Frequency and often haematuria. 


Investigation- 

  • Cystography and cystoscopy are diagnostic. 


Treatment-

  • Hydrostatic dilatation. 
  • Instillation of dimethyl sulphoxide (Rimso 50). 
  • Ranitidine instillation. 
  • lleocystoplasty or caecocystoplasty, to increase the bladder capacity.
  • Urinary diversion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Conservative management; has a good prognosis:

  • Interstitial cystitis is not managed conservatively. Its treatment is difficult and unsatisfactory, involving the distention of the bladder and the instillation of dimethyl sulfoxide.

Option C - Surgery followed by chemotherapy:

  • The treatment of hunger ulcers is the instillation of dimethyl sulfoxide into the bladder. The bladder is distended under anaesthesia.
  • No surgery followed by chemotherapy is needed.

Option D - Bladder resection under anesthesia:

  • The bladder is distinct under anesthesia but not resected; dimethyl sulfoxide is instilled into the blood, but the treatment is difficult and unsatisfactory.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with a yellowish "birthmark" on the scalp. Her mother reports that the lesion has progressively become thicker and warty. She is asymptomatic, but they are concerned regarding the cosmetic appearance. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Nevus sebaceous

  • Congenital, hairless plaque that typically occurs on the face or scalp.
  • Epidemiology: onset commonly during childhood.
  • Etiology: unclear, probably due to gene mutations.
  • Clinical features: Skin-colored, elevated lesion with surrounding alopecia.
  • Localization: usually occurs as a single lesion on the scalp.
  • Diagnosis: based on clinical appearance.
  • Treatment: prophylactic excision if sebaceous nevus persists after puberty.
  • Prognosis: Usually regress after puberty.

Option A: Sebaceous hyperplasia

  • Definition: a benign and common condition of sebaceous glands manifesting as single or multiple soft, yellow papules.
  • Pathophysiology: Decreased androgen levels lead to less sebocyte turnover and ultimately activation of sebocyte proliferation and hyperplasia.
  • Clinical features: Solitary nodule or multiple skin-colored or yellowish papules on the face (mainly forehead, cheeks, chin) and on the upper trunk

Option B: Congenital warts

  • Definition: hyperkeratosis and hyperplasia of epidermis commonly caused by human papillomavirus (HPV)
  • Etiology: Transmitted by direct skin contact and common clinical manifestation of HPV
  • Localization: elbows, knees, fingers, palms
  • Appearance: skin-colored or whitish, soft, rough-surfaced, scaly papules or plaques (sometimes with a cauliflower-like appearance)

Option D: Aplasia cutis 

  • A congenital dermatological condition characterized by the absence of a portion of skin in a localized or widespread area at birth.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male, presenting with fatigue, pale appearance, yellow conjunctiva, black stools, history of hepatitis, and alcoholism, was diagnosed with bleeding esophageal varices via upper GI endoscopy. What's the recommended treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Octreotide:

  • This is a case of upper GI bleeding.
  • Octreotide, an analog of somatostatin, is a medication used in the management of bleeding esophageal varices
  • Administer splanchnic constrictors and antibiotics upon arrival in the emergency room for suspected variceal bleeding.
  • Options include vasopressin, its analog terlipressin, and somatostatin or its analog octreotide.
  • These agents contract gastrointestinal vessels, reducing portal venous pressure and achieving hemostasis.
  • Vasopressin alone is not recommended due to cardiovascular side effects; combination therapy with nitroglycerin is more effective and safer.
  • Terlipressin, with systemic and splanchnic vasoconstriction effects, reduces mortality rates and can be used alone with fewer cardiovascular complications.
  • Somatostatin inhibits vasodilatory peptides, is effective, and has fewer systemic adverse effects.
  • Octreotide, with a longer half-life, stabilizes administration and decreases porto-collateral circulation.
  • Start vasoconstrictor administration promptly upon suspicion of variceal bleeding and continue post-endoscopy for 2 to 5 days to prevent rebleeding, pending further research for optimal duration.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Norfloxacin:

  • Norfloxacin is a fluoroquinolone primarily used to treat bacterial infections, particularly urinary tract infections and gastrointestinal infections caused by certain bacteria.
  • While antibiotics may be used in the management of complications such as bacterial peritonitis in patients with cirrhosis, they are not the first-line treatment for bleeding esophageal varices.

Option C - Propranolol:

  • Propranolol is a beta-blocker commonly used to reduce portal pressure in patients with cirrhosis by decreasing the heart rate and cardiac output.
  • While it is used in the prophylaxis of variceal bleeding, it is not the immediate treatment for acute bleeding episodes.

Option D - Clonidine:

  • Clonidine is another medication that acts as a centrally acting alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, primarily used to treat hypertension and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
  • It is not typically indicated for the treatment of bleeding esophageal varices.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female comes to the hospital to evaluate a finger deformity. She started experiencing pain and difficulty using her fingers a few weeks ago. She has a long history of rheumatoid arthritis but does not take medicines regularly. Which of the following is correct about the given deformity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Swan neck deformity:

  • The deformity given in the radiograph is Swan's neck deformity.
  • This deformity is seen in Rheumatoid arthritis.

  • Swan neck deformity is characterized by proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint hyperextension and distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint flexion.
  • There is also reciprocal flexion noted of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint.
  • This is a result of an imbalance of the extensor mechanism of the digit.
  • The imbalance could be due to a significant laceration or stretching of the extrinsic tendon forces on the distal phalanx or from tightness and pulling of the extensor mechanism, both intrinsic and extrinsic, at the PIP joint

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Boutonniere deformity:

  • This deformity is called Boutonniere deformity / Buttonhole deformity
  • Extensor deficiency at PIP joint
  • Hyperextension at DIP, Flexion of PIP

Option B - Pencil in cup deformity:

  • It is seen in psoriatic arthritis
  • Patients usually have a history of psoriasis
  • It is driven by bone destruction and pathologic new bone formation, often in the same digit.

Option C - Osler nodes:

  • Osler's nodes are painful on the tip of the finger or toes.
  • They are thought to be caused by the localized immunological-mediated response.
  • Seen in infective endocarditis

questions.text: A pig farmer from a rural area presented to the hospital to get vaccinated against Japanese Encephalitis as many people were getting infected by the disease. Which of the following is true regarding the SA-14-14-2 Japanese Encephalitis vaccine?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cell culture-derived live attenuated

  • SA 14-14-2 vaccine of JE is a Live attenuated cell-culture-derived vaccine. 
  •  SA 14-14-2 vaccine of JE is a Live strain of JE.
  • Whereas, Nakayama, Beijing P3 are strains of killed JE vaccine.

Option B: Killed vaccine

  • SA 14-14-2 vaccine of JE is a Live attenuated vaccine.

Option C: Life-long immunity

  • SA 14-14-2 vaccine of JE Gives protection for only 11 years.

Option D: Primary schedule consists of 3 doses

  • Primary Schedule of the SA 14-14-2 vaccine of JE Consist of 2 doses.
    • First dose: 9-12 months.
    • Second dose:16-24 months.

questions.text: Which of the following is consistent with the process of exocytosis?

choices.text: Four steps are involved in the process

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Can be constitutive or non-constitutive:

  • In non-constitutive exocytosis, the secretory product, after synthesis and processing in the rough endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, is stored in the cytoplasm in secretory granules until an appropriate signal for secretion is received.
  • In constitutive exocytosis, secretory products are quickly transported to the cell membrane in vesicles with little or no processing or storage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Is a calcium-independent process:

  • Exocytosis is a calcium-dependent process.

Option C - Does not require SNARE proteins:

  • SNARE proteins are involved in exocytosis.
  • They are involved in the processes of vesicle docking and vesicle fusion.
  • The v- (vesicle) SNAREs on vesicle membranes interact in a lock-and-key fashion with t- (target) SNAREs

Option D - Four steps are involved in the process:

  • In the process of exocytosis, there are five steps involved- vesicle trafficking, vesicle tethering, vesicle docking, vesicle priming, and vesicle fusion.

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient who is being treated for infertility gets ovulation induction with clomiphene and Inj. hCG. After 5 days, she comes to OPD with complaints of abdominal distension, pain, nausea, and vomiting. Physical examination is unremarkable. Ultrasonogram reveals subclinical ascites. The next step in management should be?

choices.text: Outpatient management with limited activity, daily weight record and fluid balance
Hospitalise, input output charting and iv fluid administration
Hospitalise, albumin infusion, input/ output charting

questions.solution:
Option A: Outpatient management with limited activity, daily weight record, and fluid balance

  • The patient has a history of infertility treatment with clomiphene and HCG and has symptoms after 5 days of Inj: hCG, which makes her a provisional diagnosis. A case of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).
  • Ovarian Hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a medical complication that is completely iatrogenic and unique to stimulatory infertility treatment. Its symptoms are the result of ovarian enlargement and fragility, extravascular fluid accumulation, and intravascular volume depletion.
  • Here outpatient management is appropriate, as she has mild OHSS and no symptoms of severity such as difficulty in breathing or coagulopathy, so the patient should be instructed to limit her activity, weigh herself daily, and monitor her fluid intake (at least 1 L/day of mostly electrolyte-balanced fluid) and urinary output.
  • Mild OHSS is a self-limiting condition.
  • Management of severe cases of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is done by admitting the patient for monitoring and following strict protocols to prevent secondary life-threatening complications.

Option B: Hospitalize, input-output charting and iv fluid administration

Indications for hospitalization include a more severe grade of OHSS with:

  • Inability to tolerate oral hydration
  • hemodynamic instability
  • respiratory compromise
  • tense ascites
  • hemoconcentration
  • leukocytosis
  • hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
  • abnormal renal or liver function
  • decreased oxygen saturation

 

Option C: Hospitalize, albumin infusion, input/ output charting

  • Hospitalization is done for more severe forms of OHSS with the abovementioned indications.
  • Albumin infusion is required in a patient with low serum protein values with excess extravascular fluid loss.

Option D: Paracentesis

  • Paracentesis is required in tense ascites causing excessive abdominal distension or causing respiratory distress.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 42Yr old chronic smoker with a known case of COPD now has complaints of easy fatigability, and shortness of breath has worsened further. On examination, Spo2 is 89%, Dyspneic and tachycardiac. Bronchial Biopsy taken shows stratified squamous cells with underlying glands. Which of the following change is this?
questions.solution:
Option A: Metaplasia

Metaplasia

  • Normally in bronchi →pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is present.
  • In a chronic smoker, replaced by →stratified squamous epithelium.
  • This type of change in the epithelium is called Metaplasia.
  • The most common epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous, as seen in smokers
  • *Metaplasia is a benign, reversible condition.

Option B: Anaplasia

  • The loss of the mature or specialized features of a cell or tissue, for example, a malignant tumor.
  • Grading is done depending on the degree of anaplasia.
  • A lack of differentiation is called Anaplasia (a hallmark of malignancy).

  • Features of Anaplasia: Pleomorphism, Tumor giant cells, Atypical mitoses, Loss of polarity

Option C: Dysplasia

  • The abnormal types of cells are present in a tissue in the pre-cancerous stage.
  • This means “disordered growth.”
  • Dysplastic cells may exhibit considerable pleomorphism and often contain large hyperchromatic nuclei with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio.

Option D: Neoplasia

  • Neoplasia is a new uncontrolled growth of cells that is not physiological but pathological.
  •  When dysplastic changes are marked and involve the full thickness of the epithelium but the lesion does not penetrate the basement membrane; it is considered a preinvasive neoplasm.

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby received the DPT vaccine's 1st dose in a rural PHC. Which of the following is the correct minimum accepted interval between two doses of the DPT vaccine?
questions.solution:
Option B: 4 weeks

  • For the DPT vaccine, a Minimum interval of 4 weeks is given for the immune system to activate & then the next dose is given.
  • The adverse effects of the DPT vaccine include:
    • Persistent inconsolable crying
    • Seizures
    • Hypotonic Hyporesponsive Screaming 
    • Anaphylaxis
  • The contraindications to the DPT vaccine include
    • Progressive neurological illness
    • Anaphylaxis to previous DPT dose.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents with sudden changes in speech characterized by slow, limited utterances but with preserved understanding and task performance. Weakness in the right half of the face is noted. Suspecting a lesion or loss of blood supply, which Brodmann's area is implicated in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 44:

  • Location of Ischemic Injury: Left inferior frontal gyrus, affecting Brodmann area 44.
  • Affected Function: Motor homunculus for the face.
  • Resulting Condition: Motor aphasia due to a lesion in Broca's area.
  • Symptom: Weakness of the right side of the face indicates a lesion in the left inferior frontal gyrus.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - 22:

  • Area 22 is Wernicke's sensory area, the superior temporal gyrus.
  • Wernicke is wordy but makes no sense.
  • Patients do not have insight.

Option B - 17:

  • Area 17: It is the occipital visual cortex.

Option C - 41:

  • Area 41,42: It is the temporal auditory cortex.
  • In areas 41 and 42, the primary auditory cortex includes the gyrus of Heschl on the upper surface of the superior temporal lobe. It is also known as the transverse temporal gyrus, which is entirely hidden within the Sylvian fissure.

questions.text: A community medicine intern was asked to compare two study designs. What is the similarity between Cross-sectional study design and Ecological study design?

choices.text: Both studies are done at a point of time
Both are based on primary data
The unit of study is the population

questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Both studies are done at a point of time

  • Both cross-sectional and ecological studies are done at a point of time.
  • The cross-sectional study is also called a snap-shot study.

Option B: Both provide prevalence

  • The cross-sectional study provides prevalence.
  • The strength of association/prevalence cannot be calculated in an ecological study.

Option C: Both are based on primary data

  • The cross-sectional study is based on the primary data.
  • An ecological study is based on secondary data.

Option D: The unit of study is the population

  • The unit of study in a cross-sectional study is individual.
  • The unit of study in an ecological study is population.

questions.text: A 38-year female presents to emergency with complaints of Headache, confusion, decreased urinary output, swelling on both ankles, nausea, fatigue and shortness of breath. Urine investigations revealed: Urine osmolality: 800 mOsm/kg. Urinary sodium 10 mmol/L.BUN: creatinine=20:1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pre-renal acute renal failure

  • Urine osmolality should be greater than 500 mOsm/kg
  • Urine sodium less than 20mmol/dl
  • Fractional excretion of sodium should be less than 1
  • BUN and creatinine ratio should be greater than 20:1
  • All these criteria are fulfilled above
  Pre renal Renal (ATN) Post renal
Urine osmolality > 500 mOsm

 

 ~ 300 mOsm

 

 <400 mOsm
Urine sodium <20 mmol/dl >20 mmol/dl

 

 Variable
FeNa <1 >1 Variable
Urine microscopic findings Hyaline casts Muddy brown casts

 

 Normal or RBC/WBC
BUN: creatinine ratio >20:1 (normal 10:1)

 

 <20:1

 

 >20:1

 

 

Option B: Acute tubular necrosis

  • This constitutes renal injury for which the following criterion is followed
  • Urine osmolality almost equal to 300 mOsm/kg
  • Urine sodium of more than 20mmol/dl
  • Fractional excretion of sodium of more than 1
  • BUN and creatinine ratio should be less than 20:1

Option C: Acute Cortical Necrosis

  • This constitutes renal injury for which the following criterion is followed
  • Urine osmolality almost equal to 300 mOsm/kg
  • Urine sodium of more than 20mmol/dl
  • Fractional excretion of sodium of more than 1
  • BUN and creatinine ratio should be less than 20:1

Option D: Urinary Tract Obstruction

  • This constitutes post-renal injury for which the following criterion is followed
  • Urine osmolality less than 400 mOsm/kg
  • Urine sodium is variable
  • Fractional excretion of sodium is also variable
  • BUN and creatinine ratio should be more than 20:1

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of intestinal obstruction has been admitted to the surgical ward. The conservative treatment does not relieve his symptoms. He has been taken for immediate surgery. The anaesthesia with inhaled anaesthetic has been started. Which of the following factor decreases the MAC of the inhaled anaesthetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lithium:

  • The lithium decreases the value of MAC
  • Increases in MAC
    • Hyperthermia
    • Hypernatremia
    • Excess pheomelanin production
    • Drug-induced increases in central nervous system catecholamine levels
    • Cyclosporine
  • Decreases in MAC
    • Hypothermia
    • Increase in age
    • Preoperative medication
    • Drug-induced decreases in central nervous system catecholamine levels
    • Alpha 2 agonists
    • Acute alcohol ingestion
    • Pregnancy
    • Postpartum(returns to normal in 24-72 hours)
    • Lithium
    • Lidocaine
    • Neuraxial opioids(?)
    • Ketanserin
    • PaO2 < 38mm Hg
    • Mean blood pressure < 40mm Hg
    • Cardiopulmonary bypass
    • Hyponatremia
  • No change in MAC
    • Anaesthetic metabolism
    • Chronic alcohol abuse
    • Gender
    • Duration of anaesthesia
    • PaCO2 15-95 mm Hg
    • PaO2 > 38 mm Hg
    • Blood pressure > 40 mm Hg
    • Hyperkalemia or Hypokalemia
    • Thyroid gland dysfunction

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hyperthermia: Hyperthermia increases the value of MAC.

Option C - Gender: Gender does not affect the MAC value

Option D - Thyroid dysfunction: Thyroid dysfunction does not affect the MAC value

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with complaints of red sore throat, cough, hoarseness and redness of the eyes from the last 4 days. The doctor, after examination, diagnosed this condition as pharyngitis according to presenting signs and symptoms, which is caused by Streptococcus species. C-carbohydrate in this type of causative agent contributes to which of the following properties?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lancefield classification

  • C carbohydrate in Streptococcus pyogenes contributes to Lancefield classification.
  • β-Hemolytic Streptococci are classified by Lancefield serological classification into groups based on the nature of "C carbohydrate antigen:
  • Lancefield groups (A-V excluding I, J):
    • Group A: Streptococcus pyogenes
    • Group B: Streptococcus agalactiae
    • Group C: Streptococcus equisimilis
    • Group D and so on.
  • Streptococcus pyogenes is classified into serotypes by Griffith typing: Based on M protein. More than 100 serotypes are present.

Classification

  • Group A - Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Group B - Streptococcus agalactiae
  • Group C - Streptococcus equisimilis, Streptococcus equi, Streptococcus zooepidemicus, Streptococcus dysgalactiae
  • Group D- Enterococci, Streptococcus bovis
  • Group E - Streptococcus milleri and mutans
  • Group F - Streptococcus anginosus
  • Group G - Streptococcus canis and Streptococcus dysgalactiae
  • Group H - Streptococcus sanguis
  • Group L - Streptococcus dysgalactiae
  • Group N - Lactococcus lactis
  • Group R & S - Streptococcus suis
  • Other Streptococcus species are classified as 'non-Lancefield Streptococci'

Option B: Phagocytic inhibition

  • C-Carbohydrate antigen doesn’t have any anti-phagocytic role.
  • Tyrosine phosphatase activation and suppression of myosin buildup at the site of phagocytic synapse diminish the interaction between macrophages and target cells, and CD47-SIRP interaction inhibits phagocytosis.

Option C: Toxin production

  • C-Carbohydrate antigen doesn’t have any correlation with toxin production.
  • Bacterial toxins fall into the exotoxin or endotoxin categories. Endotoxins continue to be produced by the bacteria while exotoxins are released.

Option D: Hemolysis

  • On the basis of hemolysis, Streptococci can be divided into 3 groups:
    • α Hemolytic: S. pneumoniae, S. viridians
    • β Hemolytic: Divided further on the basis of carbohydrate C antigen of cell wall into Lancefield groups (A-V excluding I, J). E.g., S. pyogenes
    • γ Hemolytic: Enterococcus

questions.text: A community medicine intern in his viva session with his senior in charge was asked to define the saturation index. Which of the following is the correct definition of the Saturation index?

choices.text: Used to assess air quality by measuring the concentration of pollutants.
Used to assess the Water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH.
Used to assess the Soil quality and whether it is good for growing crops.
Used to assess the Milk quality by estimating the bacterial count in it.

questions.solution:
Option B: Used to assess the Water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH.

  • The Langelier saturation index is used for the assessment of water quality.
  • It indicates the degree of saturation of CaCO3 in water.
  • LI should be kept at zero: To avoid corrosion & scaling.

Option A: Used to assess air quality by measuring the concentration of pollutants.

  • It is not used to assess air quality.
  • The Langelier saturation index is used for the assessment of water quality.

Option C: Used to assess the Soil quality and whether it is good for growing crops.

  • It is not used to assess soil quality.
  • The Langelier saturation index is used for the assessment of water quality.

Option D: Used to assess the Milk quality by estimating the bacterial count in it.

  • The Langelier saturation index is used for the assessment of water quality (not milk quality).

questions.text:
A 22-year-old patient presents to the clinic complaining of itching and ocular pain. The examination of his eye shows the following findings:



Which of the following is not a feature of the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chalazion

  • The given image shows Arlt's line on the upper palpebral conjunctiva - a feature of trachoma.
  • It does not cause chalazion.

Chalazion:

  • A chalazion is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland.
  • Etiology:
    • It is probably due to chronic irritation caused by an organism of low virulence.
  • The glandular tissue is replaced by granulation tissue containing giant cells predominantly.
  • It is often multiple occurring in crops. 
  • It is more common in adults than in children. 
  • Seen in people with oily skin and ocular rosacea.
  • Symptoms
    1. There is no pain unless the chalazion is secondarily infected.
    2. There is disfigurement due to the presence of swelling in the lid.
    3. It may be single or multiple.
  • Signs
    1. A small non-tender hard swelling in the lid, slightly away from the lid margin, is seen.
    2. There are no signs of acute inflammation.
    3. On everting the lid, the conjunctiva over the swelling is red or purple. It is grey in later stages. It may be yellow when secondarily infected by pyogenic organisms.
  • Treatment:
    • It is incised and thoroughly scraped.
    • Injection of triamcinolone directly into the chalazion may cause complete resolution.

Option A: Corneal opacity

  • Trachoma can cause corneal opacity, which can lead to blindness.

Option C: Entropion

  • Entropion is the inward turning of the eyelashes, which can lead to conjunctivitis due to constant irritation.
  • It is a feature of trachoma.

Option D: Herbert's pits

  • In trachoma, regression of the follicles leads to depressed, round, thinned areas known clinically as Herbert's pits.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 37 yr old man was referred to NIMHANS Neurology opd with a history of 2 episodes of GTCS, Headache, weakness on the right side of the body, behavior, and personality changes. NCCT is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis that can be made?
questions.solution:
Option B: Oligodendroglioma

  • Oligodendroglioma has chicken wire calcifications.
  • The above-given NCCT image shows an ill-defined hypodense lesion in the left frontal lobe with dense foci of calcification in the center.
  • Both low- and high-grade oligodendroglial tumors express proangiogenic mitogens and may contain regions of increased vascular density with finely branching capillaries with a 'chicken wire' appearance.
  • Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT, which can be central, peripheral, or ribbon-like.
  • Meningioma is dural-based and appears hyperdense on NCCT.

Option A: Meningioma

  • Meningioma is dural-based and appears hyperdense on NCCT.
  • Typical unenhanced images feature a well-circumscribed, smoothly marginated extra-axial mass abutting the dura.
  • Calcification is seen in approximately 20-25% of cases.
  • The CT nature of the calcification may be nodular, fine and punctate, or dense.
  • Surrounding parenchymal vasogenic edema is common, identified as hypodense brain tissue.
  • Occasionally, the edema is extensive and, as it predominantly affects white matter, can resemble fingers of low attenuation.

Option C: Glioblastoma

  • GBM usually does not show calcification.
  • With gliomatosis cerebri, CT scan findings may be normal, or images can show widespread low-attenuating regions with no focal mass and enhancement.
  • Non-enhanced CT scan findings may include a heterogeneous poorly marginated mass; internal areas of low or fluid attenuation that are the foci of necrosis (present in as many as 95% of GBMs).
  • Internal areas of high attenuation are the foci of hemorrhage or, rarely, calcifications (more common if GBM is the result of the transformation of a low-grade astrocytoma or after therapy); and a significant mass effect and edema (vasogenic distribution of edema).

Option D: Craniopharyngioma

  • On CT, the cystic component of the tumor extends anteriorly or laterally and typically wraps around the solid component. Conversely, the solid component characteristically extends posteriorly and laterally.

questions.text: A primigravida is shifted for delivery in the second stage of labour. Immediately after the baby's delivery, the resident pulls the cord,  and the placenta pulls the fundus of the uterus out of the cervix. The senior obstetrician is called.
