What should be the next step in management?

choices.text: Administer oxytocin to prevent mortality due to hemorrhagic shock and then attempt repositioning
Urgently take-up patient for Huntingtons surgery

questions.solution:
Option D: Manual Reposition under tocolytics

 

The scenario explained, wherein undue traction on umbilical cord has pulled the fundus out of the cervix is suggestive of uterine inversion.

  • Uterine inversion usually occurs due to:
    • fundal implantation of placenta
    • uterine atony
    • cord traction applied before placental separation
    • abnormally adhered placentation e.g. placenta accreta.
  • Manual Reposition under tocolytics such as terbutaline, MgSO4, can be done initially to reposition the uterus, thus oxytocin is not to be given.
  • In most cases, manual reposition works.
  • If it fails, surgical interventions like haultain surgery and huntington procedure may be done.

 

Option A: Administer oxytocin to prevent mortality due to hemorrhagic shock and then attempt repositioning

  • Oxytocics are not to be given as patient requires tocoysis for reposition. Oxytocin is to be given immediately after successful repositioning so the uterus contracts preventing PPH.

Option B: Urgently take up the patient for Huntington surgery

  • It is not the initial step in the management of uterine inversion.
  • If the manual repositioning technique has not worked out, the Huntington procedure should be carried out.

 

Option C: Hydrostatic Reposition

  • Hydrostatic reduction of acute uterine inversion is an option if manual repositioning has failed and surgical intervention is not possible.
  • The patient is placed in reversed Trendelenburg lithotomy position.
  • A bag of warmed fluid is hung at least one meter above the patient and allowed to flow by gravity or with light pressure through tubing connected to a silastic ventouse cup in the vagina; the seal between the perimeter of the cup and the vagina prevents significant leakage.
  • The resulting intravaginal hydrostatic pressure may force the inverted fundus back to its normal position. Two to 5 litres of fluid may be needed

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the clinic with insidious onset of deep, dull aching pain in the left hand involving distal interphalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and 1st carpometacarpal joints are worsened by activity and improved by rest. The patient also complains of joint stiffness in the morning, lasting less than 30 minutes. There is a sparing of meta-Carpo-phalangeal and wrist joints. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Osteoarthritis

  • The given clinical scenario has classical features of Osteoarthritis
  • Osteoarthritis characteristically involves the distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden's node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard's node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb) of the hand with sparing of metacarpophalangeal joint and wrist joint.
  • It can affect any joint, but weight-bearing joints are most involved (hips, knees, cervical and lumbar spine)

Clinical Presentation:

  • Insidious onset of joint pain
  • A deep dull ache, worsened by activity and improved by rest
  • Stiffness in the morning or after inactivity which lasts for less than 30 minutes
  • Restricted joint motion

Risk Factors:

  • Advanced age (>55 years old)
  • Obesity
  • Trauma

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • X-ray findings involve joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, subchondral cysts, and bone spurs
  • Low WBCs in synovial fluid (non-inflammatory arthritis)
  • All blood tests normal

Treatment:

  • Weight loss
  • Exercise and physical therapy
  • Topical or oral NSAIDs

Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis

  • Involvement of PIP, MCP, Wrist
  • Spared: DIP joint usually
  • Anti-CCP antibodies are positive
  • DMARDs can slow the disease progression

Option C: Ankylosing spondylitis

  • The joint involved in Ankylosing spondylitis is the Sacroiliac joint
  • Hands are spared
  • Associated with HLB27
  • Managed with NSAIDs

Option D: Psoriatic arthritis

  • According to the Caspar criterion, PA involves a distal interphalangeal joint,  Proximal interphalangeal joint, and any joint
  • Associated with psoriasis
  • Pitting of nails is a characteristic feature.

questions.text: A 6-year-old male presents to the clinic by her mother with the complaint of poor speech development. On examination, the child has difficulty concentrating and communicating and has poor speech development. His mother also reports that he has no friends and spends most of the day looking at his own hands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Autism

This child displays all three fundamental symptoms of autism, including:

  1. Social interaction impairment (difficulty forming friends)

  2. Communication impairment

  3. Repetitive behavior.

  • Stereotyped conduct is a term that refers to the way people act in certain situations (spend most time seeing their own hands).

Clinical features of Autism:

  1. Impairment in social interaction (Reciprocal social skills poor).

  2. Poor eye contact

  3. Lack of social smile and anticipatory posture absent.

  4. Poor attachment to parents and others

  5. Restricted, repeated & stereotype behaviors: Repetitive plays, Stereotyped movements like hand wringing, spinning, and head banging

  6. Impairment of communication and language: Delayed language milestones, motor milestones normal

  7. The higher threshold for pain and less/no sensations for spinning movements.

  8. Self-destructive behaviors (biting, scratching, head banging)

  9. Abnormal dermatoglyphics(fingerprints)

Option B: ADHD

  • In ADHD, there are inattentive spells and hyperkinetic symptoms.

  • This child meets the criteria for autism disorder.

Option C: Specific learning disability

  • Specific learning disorders are neurodevelopmental disorders typically diagnosed in early school-aged children, although they may not be recognized until adulthood.

  • They are characterized by persistent impairment in at least one of three major areas: reading, written expression, and/or math.

  • This child meets the criteria for autism disorder.

Option D: Tourette syndrome

  • Motor tics characterize Tourette syndrome.

  • Inattentive spells are not seen.

  • This child meets the criteria for autism disorder.

questions.text: A 36-year old female patient is evaluated for gram negative septicemia. The patient’s medical records reveals that she has earlier experienced an episode of anaphylaxis leading to shock after the administration of penicillin V. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Aztreonam:

  • In patients allergic to Penicillin, most beta-lactams are risky, except for monobactams and certain 3rd/4th generation cephalosporins. Monobactams lack the thiazole ring of beta-lactams, making them safe alternatives.
  • Aztreonam and imipenem are effective for gram-negative infections. However, as the patient is allergic to beta-lactams, carbapenems show cross allergy and are contraindicated in people with beta-lactam allergy. So Aztreonam is preferred in such a patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ampicillin plus sulbactam:

  • Ampicillin is a beta-lactam which can cause life-threatening anaphylaxis again in this patient, so it is contraindicated

Option C - Cefazolin:

  • Cefazolin is a first generation cephalosporin and is a beta-lactam, so it cannot be administered to this patient with evidence of beta-lactam allergic reaction

Option D - Imipenem plus cilastatin:

  • Imipenem is a carbapenem, and carbapenems have shown cross-allergy in patients with a beta-lactam allergy, so it is also contraindicated in this case

questions.text: A female infant is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child exam. The mother starts to wean her child from breastfeeding and started on semi solid foods. When the mother gave one biscuit in her baby's hand, to her surprise, the child could take the biscuit to her mouth all by herself. At what age can the child do that?
questions.solution:
Option C: 6 months

  • This is a case of a well-child examination in which the child could take the biscuit to her mouth alone.
  • By 5- 6 months, a child can begin to take the biscuit to his mouth.
  • By 12 months, he tries to feed herself with a cup but spills some of the contents.
  • By 15 months, he can drink from a cup without spilling
  • By 18 months, he can feed himself well with a spoon

Option A: 2 months

  • At 2, the baby holds his head up when on his tummy.
  • Have a social smile.
  • Can move both arms and legs.
  • Opens hands briefly.

Option B: 4 months

  • At 4, he holds his head steady without support when you are holding him.
  • Can hold a toy when you put it in his hand.
  • Brings his hands to mouth.

Option D: 9 months

  • At the age of 9, a child can sit without support.
  • Drops an object and looks at a fallen object.
  • Uncovers toy after seeing it hidden.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby was brought in with complaints of abdominal mass, blueberry muffin spots on the skin, proptosis, and periorbital ecchymosis. Upon further evaluation, urinary catecholamines and their metabolites were elevated. Which of the following is incorrect about the described condition?

choices.text: Most common Intracranial solid tumor of childhood
It can originate anywhere along the sympathetic chain

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Most common Intracranial solid tumor of childhood:

  • The above-described clinical condition is neuroblastoma
  • The most common solid tumors of childhood - Brain tumors
  • However, it is the most common tumor diagnosed in infants < 1 year of age and is the most common intraabdominal malignancy of children.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D are correct about neuroblastoma.

questions.text: A 7-day-old male infant presents with worsening respiratory distress for 3 days. Examination reveals tachypnea, increased work of breathing, and decreased breath sounds on the left side of the chest. Chest X-ray shows left-sided herniation of abdominal organs. What statements are true regarding the involved structure?

choices.text: Spleen and intestines enter the thoracic cavity.

questions.solution:
Option B: Less common than morgagni hernia

  • This statement is incorrect as Bochdalek hernia is more common than morgagni hernia
  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is of the following 2 types:

Bochdalek hernia:

Morgagni hernia
  • Usually left sided
  • It is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia
  • Deficiency in the left pleuroperitoneal cavity
  • Left lung hypoplasia
  • The right lung is also compressed
  • Cyanosis at birth
  • Neonatal emergency
  • Mostly on the right side
  • Antero-medial & Retrosternal
  • Transverse colon herniates in front of the heart.
  • Less common than Bochdalek hernia

 

 Incorrect options

Options A,C,D are true statements about Bochdalek hernia:

  • Usually left sided
  • Neonatal emergency
  • Spleen and intestines enter the thoracic cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most ideal electrode to measure the Resting Membrane Potential and what is the ideal diameter of the tip?

choices.text: Glass microelectrode filled with KCL solution, 1 μm
Glass microelectrode filled with KCL solution,0.5 μm

questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Glass microelectrode filled with KCL solution,0.5 μm:

  • To measure the Resting Membrane Potential, the electrode used is a Glass microelectrode filled with KCL solution, and the tip diameter is very thin, i.e., 0.5 μm (less than 1).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glass microelectrode filled with KCL solution, 1 μm: The Glass microelectrode filled with KCL solution is indeed used for the measurement of the RMP, but the tip diameter of 1 μm is relatively large and damages the cell.

Option B - Metal electrode, 0.5 μm: Metal electrodes cannot used for measuring the Resting Membrane Potential, so the glass electrode is used.

Option D – None of the above: A glass microelectrode filled with KCL solution with a tip diameter of 0.5 μm is the ideal electrode to measure the RMP.

questions.text: A microbiologist is teaching his intern to prepare the DPT vaccine in the laboratory. After vaccine preparation, he added an adjuvant to the DPT vaccine. What is the role of adjuvant in the DPT vaccine?

choices.text: Increase the shelf life of a vaccine

questions.solution:
Option C: Increase antigenicity

  • Aluminum hydroxide/phosphate is used as an adjuvant/adsorbent in the DPT vaccine.
  • It binds the three components (D, P, and T) together.

  • The commonly used adjuvant are alumnium salts (aluminium phosphate, aluminium hydroxide, or potassium aluminium sulfate).

  • Adjuvants are primarily included in vaccines to increase antigenicity, which means they enhance the body's immune response to the antigens in the vaccine.

  • Adjuvants help stimulate a stronger and longer-lasting immune response by activating immune cells, such as dendritic cells, and promoting the production of antibodies and memory cells. This ensures that the vaccine is more effective in providing immunity against the targeted diseases.

Option A: Decrease hypersensitivity

  • Adding an adjuvant does not decrease the hypersensitivity reactions. 
  • Adjuvants can rarely lead to injection site reactions and contact hypersensitivity.

Option B: Decrease absorption of vaccine

  • The adjuvant does not decrease the absorption of vaccine.
  • The adjuvant is added to a vaccine to enhance the immune response, making it possible to the total number of doses needed to achieve immunity.

Option D: Increase the shelf life of a vaccine

  • The adjuvants have no role in increasing the shelf life of the vaccine.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with growth retardation associated with intellectual disability. Further history revealed that the patient had delayed milestone development. Further examination revealed kinky hair. Lab investigations revealed low serum copper levels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Menke's disease

  • The given scenario suggests the diagnosis of Menke's disease.
  • Menke's disease, also known as kinky hair disease, is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by gene mutations coding for the copper transport protein ATP7A.
  • The copper level is low in the liver and brain and high in enterocytes and fibroblasts.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Sparse hypopigmented kinky hair
    • Trichorrhexis nodosa (fractures along the hair shaft) and pili torti (twisted hair) on microscopic examination of the hair
    • Growth retardation
    • CNS involvement includes intellectual disability, delayed milestones, seizures, and hypotonia.
    • Hypothermia

Option B: Trisomy 21

  • Trisomy 21, also known as Down syndrome, is the most common chromosomal abnormality.
  • Down’s syndrome is associated with intellectual disability, congenital heart disease, M/C;endocardial cushion defects, acute leukaemia, Alzheimer’s disease, congenital hypothyroidism and atlantoaxial instability.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Round face
    • Protruding tongue
    • Occiput flat
    • Wide fontanelle
    • Flat nasal bridge
    • Low-set and dysplastic ears
    • Oblique palpebral fissure and epicanthic fold
    • Brushfield spots in the iris
    • Brachycephaly
    • Hypotonia
    • Simian palmar crease

Option C: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome

  • It is an X-linked disease caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), which is important in the purine salvage pathway.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Developmental delay
    • Neurologic signs such as dystonia, spasticity, and dysarthria
    • Self-mutilating behaviour
    • Elevated serum uric acid levels >5 mg/dl

Option D: Wilson disease

  • Wilson disease, also known as hepatolenticular degeneration, is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation of the ATP7B gene on chromosome 13.
  • The clinical features include:
    • Hepatic: Hepatomegaly, hepatitis, liver failure, portal hypertension, and ascites
    • Hematologic: Hemolytic anaemia
    • CNS: Tremors, dysarthria, dystonia, and chorea
    • Eye: Kayser-Fleischer ring and sunflower cataract
    • Renal: Fanconi syndrome and renal failure

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not correct regarding gluconeogenesis?

choices.text: Lactate from vigorous muscle activity can be used as a carbon source in gluconeogenesis
Glycerol formed during the hydrolysis of triacylglycerols is converted to glucose in gluconeogenesis
Lactate formed in red blood cells can be used as a carbon source in gluconeogenesis
Fatty acids formed during the hydrolysis of triacylglycerols can be used as a carbon source in gluconeogenesis

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Fatty acids formed during the hydrolysis of triacylglycerols can be used as a carbon source in gluconeogenesis:

  • Gluconeogenesis synthesizes glucose from non-carbohydrate sources during food deprivation.
  • Occurs in cytoplasm and mitochondria.
  • Major carbon sources: glycerol, lactate, glucogenic amino acids.
  • Fatty acids (except odd-chain) from triacylglycerols cannot form glucose.
  • β-oxidation breaks down fatty acids to acetyl CoA.
  • Acetyl CoA must convert to pyruvate via reverse link reaction to be glucogenic.
  • Acetyl CoA cannot convert back to pyruvate, preventing even-chain fatty acids from being gluconeogenic substrates

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lactate from vigorous muscle activity can be used as a carbon source in gluconeogenesis:

  • Lactate is formed by anaerobic glycolysis in muscle during conditions such as vigorous exercise or running.
  • Once the conditions become aerobic, this lactate will pass into the liver to be converted back to glucose via the Cori cycle.

Option B - Glycerol formed during the hydrolysis of triacylglycerols is converted to glucose in gluconeogenesis:

  • Glycerol is formed as one of the products of TG hydrolysis along with free fatty acids.
  • It can be converted to glycerol 3 phosphate and then to DHAP, which can undergo either glycolysis or gluconeogenesis.

Option C - Lactate formed in red blood cells can be used as a carbon source in gluconeogenesis:

  • Glycolysis always produces lactate in RBCs, as RBCs cannot undergo aerobic respiration due to a lack of mitochondria.
  • From RBCs, Lactate is transported to the liver, where it is converted to pyruvate by lactate dehydrogenase.
  • Pyruvate is a substrate for gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to ER after her brother threw a caterpillar into her right eye. On examination, she has conjunctival redness, swelling and decreased vision. She also complains of ocular pain. The visual acuity is 20/80 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. Numerous caterpillar hairs are embedded in the periocular skin, eyelids, and the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva of the right eye. Which of the following is a likely complication seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ophthalmia nodosa

  • Conjunctival inflammatory nodule due to caterpillar hair or tarantula hair.
  • It can lead to chronic conjunctivitis and visually disabling corneal scars, cataracts, vitreous and macular edema.
  • Treatment: Removal of the offending agent and managing inflammation through topical anti-inflammatory agents such as NSAIDs and steroids with antibiotic cover to prevent secondary infections.

Option A: Intraocular melanoma

  • Malignant melanoma occurs typically at the limbus in older adults.
  • It spreads over the surface of the eyeball.
  • Recurrences and metastases occur elsewhere in the body commonly.
  • It is treated by enucleation of the globe or exenteration of the orbit in cases of extraocular extension.

Option C: Pterygium

  • Degenerative and hyperplastic condition of the conjunctiva.

Option D: Pinguecula

  • It is a triangular yellow patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus in the palpebral aperture.
  • It commonly occurs in elderly persons exposed to strong sunlight, dust, wind, etc.
  • It is seen first on the nasal side.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a dull ache in the right eye following blunt ocular trauma. Three days earlier, he had been hit in the right eye with a cricket ball. Injury of Wiegert's ligament is suspected. Wiegert’s ligament is seen at which of the following site?

choices.text: Attachment of vitreous to posterior surface of the lens

questions.solution:
Option D: Attachment of vitreous to the posterior surface of the lens

Vitreous Cavity:

  • The vitreous is an inert, avascular, transparent, jelly-like structure which serves only optical functions.
  • It consists of a delicate framework of collagen and hyaluronic acid. It is a hydrophilic gel which becomes "fluid" when its protein basis is thickened due to the:
    • Advancing senile age
    • Degenerations, e.g. as in high myopia
    • Chemical and mechanical trauma.
  • Attachments of vitreous:
    • It is attached anteriorly to the lens (Hyaloid Capsular ligament of Wiegert) and ciliary epithelium in front of the Ora serrata. The part of the vitreous about 4 mm across the Ora serrata is known as the "base of vitreous," where the attachment is strongest.
    • It is attached posteriorly to the edge of the optic disc and macula lutea (foveal region), forming a ring-shaped structure around them.

Option A: Suspension of the ciliary body

  • The Wiegert's ligament attaches the lens to the vitreous.
  • The lens is suspended on the ciliary body by the zonule fibers.

Option B: Junction of cornea and sclera

  • The sclera-corneal junction is called the limbus.
  • Here, the deep surface of the suprachoroidal lamina is covered by the scleral endothelium, a simple squamous epithelium.
  • The limbus is the location of corneal stem cells.

Option C: Posterior chamber

  • Wiegert's ligament is attached between the lens and vitreous.
  • Posterior chamber is the region between the posterior surface of iris and the anterior surface of the lens. This is not the location of attachment of the Wiegert's ligament.

questions.text: A 45-year-old perimenopausal woman was admitted with a history of abnormal uterine bleeding for the past 6 months. She was posted for a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salphingo oophorectomy. The anaesthesia plan was spinal anaesthesia with an epidural catheter for postoperative analgesia. Postoperative pain scores were low, and the patient was comfortable postoperatively. The epidural catheter was removed after 48 hours. What is the most appropriate indication for this type of anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - All of the above:

  • Epidural anaesthesia is an excellent choice for independent anaesthesia and analgesia with general anaesthesia.
  • Thoracic epidural injection for thoracic surgery, and rib fracture.
  • Upper and lower abdomen procedures require a lumbar epidural.
  • It may also be used for urogenital or gynecologic procedures such as;
    • Cystectomy
    • Nephrectomy
    • Ureteral repair
    • Radical abdominal prostatectomy
    • Ovarian tumour debulking
    • Pelvic exenteration
    • Total abdominal hysterectomy

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rib fracture:

  • Thoracic epidural injection for thoracic surgery, rib fracture
  • Other indications for thoracic epidural
    • Thoracotomy
    • Rib fractures
    • Pectus repair
    • Thoracic aneurysm repair
    • Thymectomy
    • Video-assisted thoracic surgery

Option B - Lower abdominal surgery:

  • Lower abdomen procedures require a lumbar epidural.
  • Lower abdominal procedures may include:
    • Abdominal aortic aneurysm repair
    • Colectomy
    • Bowel resection
    • Abdominal perineal resection

Option C - Upper abdominal surgery:

  • Upper abdomen procedures require a lumbar epidural.
  • Upper abdominal procedures may include:
    • Esophagectomy
    • Gastrectomy
    • Pancreatectomy
    • Cholecystectomy
    • Hepatic resection

questions.text:
A 75-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to dysuria and passing foamy urine for 2 weeks. He has had a history of type II diabetes mellitus for 20 years, for which he takes insulin irregularly. The recent laboratory investigations reveal:


	
		
			
			Glucose
			
			
			200mg/dl
			
		
		
			
			Urea
			
			
			52mg/dl
			
		
		
			
			Creatinine
			
			
			1.2mg/dl
			
		
		
			
			Uric acid
			
			
			5.3mg/dl
			
		
	



	
		
			Blood pressure
			160/92mmHg
		
		
			Urine Albumin
			35mg
		
	


The physician suspects a complication of long-standing diabetes mellitus. Which of the following is associated with this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Urine dipsticks can easily detect microalbuminuria
24 hr urine albumin is more sensitive than spot sample urine albumin: urine creatinine
Microalbuminuria correlates with nocturnal spike in Systolic blood pressure
It is the most common cause of death in type II diabetes mellitus.

questions.solution:
Option C: Microalbuminuria correlates with a nocturnal spike in systolic blood pressure

  • The patient presents with clinical features of diabetic nephropathy.
  • Diabetic nephropathy is a microvascular complication of diabetes mellitus.
  • Diabetic nephropathy is initially manifested as microalbuminuria.
  • Microalbuminuria is the urinary albumin excretion of 30-300mg/day.
  • Microalbuminuria correlates with a nocturnal spike in systolic blood pressure.
  • There is a positive link between high blood pressure and microalbuminuria.
  • High blood pressure may cause microalbuminuria by increasing glomerular filtration pressure and subsequently causing kidney damage.
  • Antihypertensive activity decreases microalbuminuria by decreasing intraglomerular pressure and lowering systemic hypertension.
  • Hence, normotensive diabetic patients with microalbuminuria have slightly elevated blood pressure during sleep, which is lowered by antihypertensive therapy.

Option A: Urine dipsticks can easily detect microalbuminuria

  • Sensitive radioimmunoassay methods measure small amounts of urinary albumin in contrast to less sensitive dipstick strips, whose minimal detection is 0.3-0.5%

Option B: 24 hr urine albumin is more sensitive than spot sample urine albumin: urine creatinine

  • 24-hour urine albumin values are affected by the following:
    • Exercise
    • Dietary protein
    • Sustained erect posture
  • ​​​​​​​This problem is circumvented with spot sample urine albumin to urine creatinine values.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option D: It is the most common cause of death in type II diabetes mellitus

  • Myocardial infarction is the most common cause of death in type II diabetes mellitus.
  • Heart disease in a patient with diabetes is due to coronary atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of coronary artery disease is brought to the emergency department due to the sudden onset of the right-side face, arm weakness, and difficulty speaking. The symptoms began abruptly one hour ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), his pulse is 76 beats/min, and his blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences and has difficulty repeating sequences of words. He can follow simple instructions. Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 3/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left. Non-contrast CT scan of the head is shown in the image below. Which is the best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Intravenous reteplase

  • The patient is presenting with complaints of a stroke. Non-contrast CT of the head shows a hypodense area in the left middle cerebral artery indicating acute ischemic stroke.
  • Causes of ischemic stroke include:
  • Thrombotic (a thrombus forms at the site of the infarct)
  • Embolic (an embolus travels from other parts of the body)
  • Hypoxic (due to systemic hypotension or hypoxemia)
  • Management of ischemic stroke:
  • Thrombolytic therapy (e.g., reteplase, alteplase) if the ischemic stroke occurred within 4.5 hours with no risk of haemorrhage.
  • Mechanical thrombectomy is required if there is a large artery occlusion.
  • Treating the underlying cause of the ischemic stroke.
  • Lowering a patient's blood pressure will reduce cerebral perfusion and worsen the patient; hence antihypertensives are avoided.
  • Aspiration pneumonia and deep vein thrombosis should be prevented
  • Mannitol is given when features of raised intracranial pressure are present.

Option A: Intravenous nicardipine

  • IV nicardipine is a calcium channel blocker.
  • It is not required as blood pressure is not in the range of a hypertensive crisis.

Option B: Intravenous labetalol

  • Labetalol is a beta blocker drug used as an antihypertensive and antiarrhythmic.
  • IV labetalol is unsuitable as the patient's blood pressure is not in the hypertensive crisis range.

Option D: Intravenous mannitol

  • Mannitol is given when features of raised intracranial pressure are present. This patient shows no sign of raised intracranial pressure, i.e. nausea, vomiting, or headache. Hence, no need for mannitol in this patient

questions.text:
All of the following are false about Erb's paralysis except?

A) The forearm lies extended & supinated

B) Injury to lower trunk of Brachial Plexus

C) Inability to initiate abduction

D) Decreased sensation on the medial side of the hand
questions.solution:
Option C: C only.

Erb’s paralysis:

  • Also called waiter's tip palsy, is caused by traction or tear of the upper trunk (C5 to C6 roots).
  • Occurs in infants due to lateral traction on the neck during delivery; In adults, due to trauma leading to neck traction (e.g., falling on head and shoulder in a motorcycle accident).
  • Injury to the nerve causes paralysis of the deltoid, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and biceps brachii. 
  • The patient presents with loss of abduction (leading to arm hanging by the side), loss of lateral rotation (leading to arm medially rotated), and loss of flexion and supination (leading to an extended and pronated arm).
  • The resulting deformity is known as Policeman / Porter / Waiter’s tip hand
  • The affected arm hangs by the side, adducted & medially rotated; The forearm lies extended & pronated.
  • Disability: Loss of fall movements
    • Abduction & lateral rotation of the arm at the shoulder
    • Biceps with supinator jerk lost 
    • Sensory loss over a small area of the deltoid.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: A only

  • Erb’s palsy causes loss of supination due to the involvement of C5 and C6 nerve roots supplying the supinator and biceps brachii, The forearm lies extended & supinated

Option B: B only

  • Erb's palsy occurs due to an injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus.

Option D: D only

  • Erb’s palsy causes sensory loss over a small area of the deltoid. Loss of sensation of the medial side of the hand is caused by the injury of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady with no known co-morbid presented to the hospital with complaints of spontaneous vaginal bleeding. She gets symptomatic treatment. She suffers from a tonic-clonic seizure in the next 24 hours. She is febrile, jaundiced, and has extensive purpura on physical examination. A haemoglobin of 5.3 g/dL with 8% reticulocytes, a platelet count of 10,000/mL, and a BUN of 48 mg/dL were found in the lab. A peripheral blood smear is also advised. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura

  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) occurs in acute or chronic form.
  • This disease has a pentad that includes fever, Microangiopathic hemolytic Anemia, Thrombocytopenia, Neurologic symptoms and Renal impairment.
  • All these things are positive in this patient.
  • The deposition of PAS-positive hyaline microthrombi in arterioles and capillaries throughout the body, particularly in the heart, brain, and kidneys, is a morphologic hallmark of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.
  • Platelet aggregates, fibrin, a few erythrocytes and leukocytes make up the microthrombi.
  • The peripheral blood smear displays microangiopathic hemolytic Anemia and numerous schistocytes.
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura resembles hemolytic uremic syndrome, which occurs more often in children than adults.
  • The other choices are not associated with microangiopathic changes (e.g., schistocytes).

 

Option A: Drug-induced thrombocytopenia

  • Drugs can cause thrombocytopenia by several mechanisms, including direct bone marrow or other organ toxicity.
  • Clinically, these patients present with moderate to severe thrombocytopenia (defined as a platelet count of less than 50 × 109/L) and spontaneous bleeding varying from simple ecchymosis, petechiae, and mucosal bleeding to life-threatening spontaneous intracranial haemorrhage.
  • Excluding other causes of thrombocytopenia (such as congenital disorders and inflammatory processes) is important.
  • Many drugs can cause thrombocytopenia. Some of them are Heparin, furosemide, Gold, Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory disease, Antibiotics, and Statins.
  • In this case, no such drug has been used

Option B: Henoch-Schönlein purpura

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura is the most common vasculitis in childhood.
  • It most commonly affects children 2-8 years of age 
  • The features include rash and one or more of the following:
    • Arthritis/arthralgia (50-75%)
    • Abdominal pain (50%)
    • Nephritis (25-50%)

Option C: Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura

  • It is a quantitative disorder of platelets caused by antibodies directed against platelet or megakaryocytic antigens.
  • Related to antibody-mediated immune destruction of platelets or their precursors.
  • The peripheral blood smear in Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura exhibits numerous large platelets, and the bone marrow shows a compensatory increase in megakaryocytes.
  • Clinical Features include:
    • Petechia
    • Purpura
    • Hemorrhagic bullae
    • Gum bleeding
    • Hematuria
    • Melena

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of redness of the eyes, frequent urinary tract infections and mild joint pain for two weeks. The patient further gives a history of dysuria and pelvic pain. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. For further examination of the eyes, the doctor had to pick cycloplegic drops to ensure that the patient did not develop posterior synechiae; which of the following difference between hyoscine and atropine must the doctor remember well?

choices.text: Hyoscine exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses
Hyoscine exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye
Hyoscine has weaker anti-motion sickness activity

questions.solution:
Option A: Hyoscine exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses

  • This is a case of reactive arthritis in which the patient presents with complaints of redness of the eyes, frequent urinary tract infections and mild joint pain for two weeks. The patient further gives a history of dysuria and pelvic pain. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • The above-mentioned clinical feature suggests reactive arthritis.
  • The diagnosis of reactive arthritis is usually made clinically.
  • For further examination of the eye, the doctor had to use cycloplegic drops.
  • To ensure the patient doesn't develop posterior synechia, the doctor must know that hyoscine exerts a depressant effect on the CNS at relatively low doses.

Option B: Hyoscine exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye

  • Hyoscine doesn’t exert more potent effects on the heart than on the eye.
  • It has a more potent effect on the eye and the secretory glands.

Option C: Hyoscine is longer acting

  • Hyoscine is a very short-acting drug.
  • Atropine is a long-acting drug.

Option D: Hyoscine has weaker anti-motion sickness activity

  • Hyoscine has a strong anti-motion sickness activity.
  • It is most commonly used to prevent motion sickness.
  • It can also be used for the reduction of saliva in the mouth.

questions.text: Which is not a finding of endometriosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Feeding vessel sign:

  • The feeding vessel sign is more commonly linked to certain characteristics seen in endometrial polyp rather than endometriosis. Endometrial polyp is endometrial gland hyperplasia, and endometrium appears Hyperechoic. It will be within the endometrium.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Kissing ovaries:

  • This is a finding in endometriosis where the ovaries are close together, appearing to "kiss" due to the presence of endometrial tissue.

Option C - T2 shading sign:

  • T2 shading is a characteristic MRI finding in endometriomas (cysts associated with endometriosis). It refers to the dark shading within the cyst on T2-weighted images, indicating the presence of old blood products.

Option D - Mushroom cap sign:

  • The mushroom cap sign is seen in rectal endometriosis where the lesion has a central hypoechoic area surrounded by echogenic tissue, resembling a mushroom cap.

questions.text: A patient presents to the office after he and his girlfriend eloped. He was struck with a cricket bat by his girlfriend's relatives near the temporal area. Later, he had some difficulty in hearing. His examination revealed a problem in his middle ear. Normally, the advantage gained by the middle ear transformer mechanism is?
questions.solution:
Option C: 22 times

  • It is a correct statement.
  • Effective vibratory area- 55mm2
  • Footplate area- 3.2mm2
  • Areal ratio: 17:1
  • Lever ratio- 1.3:1
  • Total transformer ratio= Areal ratio X Lever ratio= 17 X 1.3= 22
  • The sound gets amplified by 22 times (Advantage gained)

Total transformer ratio= 22:1

  • The tympanic membrane and the ossicles function to overcome the mismatch of impedances between air and the cochlear fluids, and thus the middle ear serves as a transformer or impedance matching device.

Middle ear transformer mechanism

  1. Catenary lever – ear drum – 2 times gain in sound pressure
  2. Ossicular lever – ossicles – handle of malleus 1.3 times longer than long process of incus – mechanical advantage of 1.3
  3. Hydraulic lever – diff in surface TM (55 sq mm) & stapes (3.2 sq mm) – areal ratio – 14:1

  • The outer ear is air-filled, and the cochlea is filled with liquid, which causes an impedance mismatch. This impedance mismatch would cause much of the sound entering the ear to be reflected, and the auditory system would lose much of its sensitivity.
  • For purposes of simplicity, the conductive mechanism of hearing can be divided into three parts: (1) air medium, (2) impedance matching mechanism, and (3) fluid medium between the listener and the sound source, as representing the first part of the conductive mechanism of hearing.
  • The major function of the middle ear is to match relatively low-impedance airborne sounds to the higher-impedance fluid of the inner ear. The term “impedance” in this context describes a medium's resistance to movement.
  • The area ratio (pressure) transformer is the first and most effective of the three impedance matching mechanisms. It results from the difference in surface area between the tympanic membrane and the membrane covering the oval window.
  • Impedance matching is the force delivered through the mechanical advantages of the lever action of the tympanic ossicles and the areal ratio of the tympanic membrane to the oval window to overcome the acoustic impedance between the ambient air and the fluid in the inner ear.

Option A: 18 times

  • It is a false statement.
  • The transformer ratio according to the areal and lever ratio is 22 times.

Option B: 19 times

  • It is a false statement.
  • The transformer ratio according to the areal and lever ratio is 22 times.

Option D: 24 times

  • It is a false statement.
  • The transformer ratio according to the areal and lever ratio is 22 times.

questions.text: A patient's lifestyle can cause sleep disturbances. It is commonly referred to as poor sleep hygiene. Universal sleep hygiene focuses on modifiable environmental and lifestyle components that can disrupt sleep and actions that can disrupt sleep. Which of the following is not the correct advice regarding sleep hygiene?

choices.text: Wake up at the same time
30 mL and a lesser amount of alcohol could be useful to induce sleep over the long term
Sleep in a dark, quiet environment
Avoid fluid intake and large meals right before bedtime

questions.solution:
Option B: 30 mL and a lesser amount of alcohol could be useful to induce sleep over the long term

Some basic components of sleep hygiene are:

  • Physical exercises should be done daily (preferably not in the evening).
  • Avoid fluid intake and large meals right before bedtime to avoid midday naps.
  • Before going to bed, avoid caffeine (e.g., tea, coffee, and cola beverages).
  • Avoid consuming alcohol regularly (especially avoid the use of alcohol as a hypnotic for promoting sleep).
  • Sleep in a dark, quiet, and comfortable setting with a regular bedtime and wake-up times. Experiment with relaxing techniques.
  • Don't use your phone or other electronic gadgets when you're in bed.
  • Avoid looking at the clock repeatedly to check the time of sleep onset.

Option A: Wake up at the same time

  • Waking up simultaneously schedules your sleep-wake cycle and improves sleep hygiene.

Option C: Sleep in a dark, quiet environment

  • Sleeping in a quiet, dark environment improves sleep hygiene.

Option D: Avoid fluid intake and large meals right before bedtime

  • Avoiding fluid intake and large meals right before bedtime is one of the basic components of sleep hygiene.

questions.text: Earliest loss of which sensation is seen in damage to somatosensory area-1?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Graphesthesia and stereognosis:

  • Damage to somatosensory area 1 primarily affects the perception of complex somatosensory functions such as graphesthesia and stereognosis. Graphesthesia refers to the ability to recognize numbers or letters drawn on the skin without visual input, while stereognosis involves identifying objects by touch.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are not lost initially in case of damage to somatosensory area-1.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male comes to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of scanty, foul-smelling, blood-stained discharge from the ear associated with conductive hearing loss. Further examination revealed the migration of the external auditory canal epithelium into the middle ear. Which of the following is the treatment for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Modified radical mastoidectomy

  • The above-given case is acquired cholesteatoma.
  • It is a bag-like cystic structure lined by keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium containing desquamated epithelium having erosive property and mostly seen in the temporal bone.
  • Squamous epithelium from the external auditory canal migrates/invades into the middle ear along the marginal perforation and causes squamous metaplasia.
  • Secondary acquired cholesteatoma. In these cases, there is already a pre-existing perforation in pars tensa.
  • This is often associated with posterosuperior marginal perforation or sometimes large central perforation.
  • The treatment of choice is modified radical mastoidectomy.
  • The attico-antral disease is usually associated with cholesteatoma.
  • Cholesteatoma is the most common condition in chronic suppurative otitis media of unsafe variety.
  • Cholesteatoma causes destruction of bone or whatever structure comes in its way, eroding aditus and or antrum.
  • The facial nerve may be similarly injured.
  • It may erode the lateral sinus plate resulting in lateral sinus thrombosis.
  • It causes otorrhoea-usually scanty and foul smelling, hearing loss, marginal perforation, or retraction pocket with cholesteatoma debris.
  • Pus culture may be positive for Pseudomonas pyocyaneus.
  • X-ray mastoid may show sclerosis in mastoid bone with erosion.
  • Depending upon the extent of the disease, simple/modified or radical mastoidectomy may be done to treat cholesteatoma.

Option B: IV antibiotics

  • Surgery is always indicated in cholesteatoma due to the risk of complications.
  • The reconstruction of the middle ear and sound-conducting apparatus is indicated.
  • IV antibiotics are not useful for the treatment of acquired cholesteatoma.
  • Cholesteatoma produces the cyst by modification of the eardrum, and the cyst should be removed surgically.
  • Mostly IV antibiotics are used during the surgical procedure of mastoidectomy.

Option C: Oral antibiotics

  • Oral or IV antibiotics are not useful for the treatment of acquired cholesteatoma.
  • Oral antibiotics are recommended after the surgery procedure to avoid infection.

Option D: No treatment

  • Surgery is always indicated in cholesteatoma due to the risk of complications.
  • Mostly IV antibiotics are used during the surgical procedure of mastoidectomy.
  • Oral antibiotics are recommended after the surgery procedure to avoid infection.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male presents to the physician because of a skin lesion on his nose. The lesion has gradually increased since it first appeared 11 months ago. He is a farmer and lives together with his wife. Examination of the skin shows a nontender lesion at the right medial canthus. An image of the lesion is shown.



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Basal cell carcinoma:

  • This patient is most likely suffering from basal cell carcinoma. Basal cell carcinoma is characterized by a slow-growing, locally invasive malignant neoplasm of the skin that arises from the basal epithelial cells.
  • It is the most common type of skin cancer.
  • Typically, basal cell carcinoma develops in sun-exposed areas as a pearly, indurated, nodular, non-tender lesion with a rolled border and central ulceration, as illustrated in the image below:

  • The subtypes of basal cell carcinoma include nodular basal cell carcinoma and superficial basal cell carcinoma.
  • Nodular basal cell carcinoma mainly involves the face, especially the nose.
  • Meanwhile, superficial basal cell carcinoma is characterized by a flat eczematous (scaly) plaque with a pearly border lesion.
  • The superficial basal cell carcinoma variant mainly involves the trunk. This variant is illustrated in the image below:

  • The patient with basal cell carcinoma (BCC) should undergo a full-thickness biopsy of the edge of the lesion for histopathological confirmation of BCC.
  • The standard treatment options include surgical excision with a safety margin and  Mohs micrographic surgery.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Squamous cell carcinoma:

  • Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) is the second most common type of skin cancer and is commonly located on the face or neck (the lower lip is a specific location). Sun exposure and smoking present in this patient are risk factors for SCC. Although this patient also has a lesion involving his face, SCC has a different appearance: it is typically a hyperkeratotic nodule or ulcer with crusting that does not heal and bleeds easily. A pearly induration with a rolled border suggests another diagnosis.

Option C - Actinic keratosis:

  • While actinic keratosis typically affects patients over 50 and is associated with sun exposure, it does not manifest as pearly nodules surrounding a central ulcerative depression.
  • Instead, actinic keratosis presents with dry and scaly patches of skin.

Option D - Keratoacanthoma:

  • While keratoacanthomas may appear as an erythematous nodule with a central crater, which would be consistent with this patient's lesion, they do not have a pearly appearance or a rolled border. In contrast to this patient's lesion, keratoacanthomas typically proliferate over 2–3 months and usually heal without treatment.

questions.text: The image shows the uterine sutures in a woman with PPH. Identify.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • B-Lynch suture
  • Two sutures are applied longitudinally, which looks like a "brace-suspender,"
  • The b-Lynch suture is referred as the "brace suture."
  • It involves the use of vertical brace sutures, which appose the anterior and posterior wall of the uterus, which leads to compression of the fundus and lower uterine segment, thereby controlling hemorrhage

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Hayman suture

  • Hayman procedure is considered a uterine compression suture using two longitudinal threads and transfixing the entire uterine wall.
  • This suture is simpler than the B-Lynch suture, and is sometimes called the "simple brace."

Option C: Cho suture

  • The Cho suture, or Modified Cho suture, involves placing a series of vertical and horizontal sutures on the uterine fundus to achieve hemostasis.

Option D: Pereira suture

  • The Pereira suture is a type of uterine compression suture, involving placing horizontal and vertical sutures on the uterus.
  • It is different from Cho suture as there is no transfixion of the total uterine wall.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female is brought to the emergency room with complaints of fever, palpitations, abdominal pain and diarrhoea for the past few hours. On examination, the patient had tremors and profuse sweating since she arrived. ECG revealed Atrial fibrillation. A diagnosis of thyroid storm is made. Which of the following anti-thyroid medications should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Propylthiouracil

  • A thyroid storm is also known as a thyrotoxic crisis.
  • The symptoms of thyroid storm are tachycardia, fever, profuse sweating, poor feeding and weight loss, agitation, restlessness, anxiety, diarrhea etc.
  • The treatment of thyroid storm consists of supportive therapy, which includes intravenous (IV) fluids for dehydration, oxygen, cooling blankets to return body temperature to normal, and acetaminophen.

  • Treatment for thyrotoxicosis involves a multifaceted approach to manage symptoms and address the underlying hormonal imbalance:

    • Beta blockers are used to alleviate symptoms caused by increased adrenergic activity, such as palpitations and tremors, unless contraindicated.

    • Thionamides, like methimazole or propylthiouracil, inhibit the synthesis of new thyroid hormones, thus helping to normalize thyroid hormone levels.Antithyroid medication like Propylthiouracil is given to lower the hormone levels in the blood. It is the drug of choice for thyroid storms because it has an early onset of action and the capacity to inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

    • Iodine solutions, like Lugol's solution or potassium iodide, are administered to block the release of thyroid hormones from the thyroid gland, particularly in preparation for thyroid surgery or to manage thyroid storm.

    • Glucocorticoids may be prescribed to reduce the conversion of T4 to the more active T3 hormone, promote stability in vasomotor function, potentially mitigate the autoimmune process in Graves' disease, and address any associated relative adrenal insufficiency. These medications can help manage symptoms and address underlying mechanisms contributing to thyrotoxicosis.

Option A: Thiocyanates

  • Thiocyanates are not used in the treatment of thyroid storm.

Option C: Propranolol

  • Propranolol is used to minimize sympathomimetic symptoms.
  • It is a life-saving drug used for cases of thyroid storm.

Option D: Radioactive iodine

  • Radioiodine therapy can be a definitive therapy for thyroid storm once symptoms improve.

questions.text: In a town of 20,000 population, a total of 456 births were there in a year out of which 56 were dead born. There were 56 deaths within the first 28 days of life and another 34 had died after 28 days and before completing the first birthday. What is the Infant mortality rate in this area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: 225

  • The infant mortality rate (IMR) is calculated as the number of infant deaths (under one year of age) per 1,000 live births.
  • Total live births = 456 - 56 (dead born) = 400
  • Total infant deaths = 56 (within 28 days) + 34 (between 28 days and first birthday) = 90
  • IMR = (Total infant deaths / Total live births) x 1000
    • IMR = (90 / 400) x 1000
    • IMR = 225
  • So, the infant mortality rate in this area is 225 per 1,000 live births.

Other options are incorrect

questions.text: Where is Killian's dehiscence located?

choices.text: Below the upper 1/3rd of the smooth muscle of the esophagus

questions.solution:
Correct Option C -Above the cricopharyngeal muscle:

Killian's Dehiscence:

  • Location: Weakness located between the inferior constrictor muscle.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Below Superior constrictor:

  • Killian's dehiscence is located between the inferior constrictor muscle. 

Option B - Between Inferior constrictor: 

  • It is located above the cricopharyngeal muscle. 

Option D - Below the upper 1/3rd of the smooth muscle of the esophagus 

  • Killian’s dehiscence is an area of muscular weakness in the neck.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy living in rural India had a history of cowpox infection. His sister's rash on the skin turned into a fluid-filled blister with a dent in the center. On history taking, the patient says it was just nausea, vomiting, and fever in the beginning. Later, she started having ulcers in the mouth and a rash that turned into blisters. The doctor suspected it was a contagious viral infection. The strange thing, in this case, is that the boy who is her brother, despite coming in contact with his sister multiple times, was not infected. The boy's protection from this disease by the previous infection is due to the?
questions.solution:
Option A: Antigenic cross-reactivity

The protection against smallpox by previous infection with cowpox represents antigenic cross-reactivity.

  • The above given is a case of smallpox. The fluid-filled blister with a dent in the center is characteristic of smallpox.
  • The initial mouth ulcer followed rash; eventually, blisters are a classical pattern for smallpox.
  • Antigenic cross-reactivity- Sometimes single antigen stimulates the production of various antibodies that more or less resemble the correct fit for the antigen.
  • Each of these antibodies may attack different antigens that more or less resemble one another.
  • Cross Reactivity: The ability of an individual antibody combining site to react with more than one antigenic determinant.
  • The ability of a population of antibody molecules to react with more than one Ag.

Option B: Activation Of B cell

  • Lymphocytes are part of the adaptive immune system.
  • Both T lymphocytes and B lymphocytes come under the same banner of the adaptive immune system.
  • Activation of B lymphocytes by T-lymphocytes leads to maturation of B-cell into plasma cells and antibodies formation from plasma.

Option C: Passive immunity

  • This immunity is conferred by the transfer of serum or lymphocytes from a specifically immunized individual.

Option D:Innate immunity

  •  It is the resistance that an individual possesses by birth.
  • It is not specific and is the first line of defense against pathogens.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male came to the hospital with complaints of tinnitus associated with sensorineural hearing loss that is followed by vertigo. You made a provisional diagnosis of Meniere's disease. But in this case, the symptoms improved during the episode of vertigo. Meniere's disease occurred in reverse order. Which of the following describes the best about this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lermoyez syndrome

  • The above given is a case of Lermoyez syndrome
  • Lermoyez syndrome is a rare variant of Meniere's where symptoms appear in reverse order.
  • Tinnitus and loss of hearing prior to an attack of vertigo, after which hearing improves.
  • Some authors believe that lermoyez also has other features of Meniere's disease like endolymphatic hydrops
  • Another theory says that Lermoyez is due to hydrops caused due to obstruction of the ductus reuniens
  • ductus reuniens is a narrow duct that connects the labyrinth to the cochlea
  • Treatment of lermoyez syndrome is the same as Meniere's disease.
  • Migraine and vascular treatment can also be done but are controversial.

Option B: Lemierre's syndrome

  • It is a condition characterized by thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein and bacteremia caused primarily by anaerobic organisms following a recent oropharyngeal infection.

Option C: Leriche syndrome

  • It is also commonly referred to as an aortoiliac occlusive disease and is caused by severe atherosclerosis affecting the distal abdominal aorta, iliac arteries, and femoropopliteal vessels.
  • Leriche syndrome presents with a triad of claudication, impotence, and absence of femoral pulses.

Option D: Le Riche syndrome

  • The disease of peripheral arty at aortic bifurcation leads to the classic triad of bilateral buttock, hip, or thigh claudication.
  • It also causes absent/diminished femoral pulses and erectile dysfunction.

questions.text: The skin receptors are of two types- rapidly adapting and slowly adapting. The rapidly adapting receptor, found in the location as marked in the image below, is:
questions.solution:
Option B: Meissner's corpuscle

  • Meissner's corpuscles are present in the dermo-epidermal junction. The marked area is the Dermo-epidermal junction.
  • It is rapidly adapting receptors and functions for 2-point discrimination.
  • Meissner's corpuscles are present in the hairless skin and are responsible for tactile sensations. These receptors can sense low-frequency vibrations (10-50 hertz).
  • The Meissner corpuscle is composed of three components:
    • Elongated Schwann cells.
    • Connective tissue capsule.
    • A central axon.
  • On light microscopy, Meissner's corpuscles appear as coiled, spring-like structures with their longitudinal end perpendicular to the skin surface. The touch sensitivity, size, and density of Meissner's corpuscles decline with age.

NOTE

  • Reading braille: Meissner corpuscle >> Merkel disc

Option A: Merkel's cell

 

  • Merkel Cells: Slow adapting receptor
  • Involved in light touch sensation;
  • For e.g., detecting pencil in fingers
  • Helps in initial learning of Braille characters/words. Later Braille (sentences) are better read by Meissner’s corpuscle.

Option C: Pacinian corpuscle

  •  Pacinian corpuscle is present in the deep dermis
  • The function is that they detect pressure and vibration.
  • It is a rapidly adapting receptor.

Option D: Ruffini's receptor

  • It is a slowly adapting receptor.
  • Senses for dermal stretch and also as thermoreceptor.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the outpatient department physician because of a sore throat, dry cough, headache, and runny nose for the past three days. During this period, His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), his pulse is 80/min, and his blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination of the throat shows erythema of the tonsils and pharynx without exudates. A swab was taken and inoculated into a suitable liquid culture medium, and the bacterium's growth was plotted. In a bacterial growth curve, in which phase is the maximum cell size obtained?

questions.text: The chemical structure of a disaccharide is shown below. This disaccharide is present in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Milk:

  • In a beta linkage, the hydroxyl (OH) group attached to the anomeric carbon is positioned upward or above the plane of the ring.
  • As the bond is β(1→4), we can easily identify this molecule as lactose.
  • Because only lactose has beta-bond.
  • Other common disaccharides usually have α-bonds.
  • Lactose is the major sugar in milk.

Enzyme

Incorrect Option:

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presented to the physician's office complaining of low-grade fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and myalgias for the past 3 months.  On physical examination, she had oral ulcers and facial rash, as shown in the picture below.  Which of the following is not included in the criteria for diagnosing this disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: Leukocytosis

SLE

  • SLE is an autoimmune disease involving multiple organs and is characterized by a vast array of auto-antibodies which cause injury mainly by deposition of immune complexes.
  • Leukocytosis is defined as an elevation in the leukocyte levels in the blood.  It is a feature of inflammatory reactions, especially in response to bacterial infections.
  • However, in SLE, instead of leukocytosis, leukopenia or lymphopenia is observed.  Therefore, leukocytosis is not a diagnostic criterion for SLE.
  • The diagnosis of SLE is made by the following clinical and immunological criteria:

Criteria (2012) for diagnosis of SLE:

Clinical manifestations

  • Skin
    • Acute, subacute cutaneous lupus (photosensitive, malar, maculopapular, bullous rash)
    • Chronic cutaneous lupus (discoid lupus, panniculitis, lichen planus-like, hypertrophic verrucous, chilblains)
  • Oral or nasal ulcers
  • Nonscarring Alopecia
  • Synovitis involving ≥ 2 joints characterized by tenderness, swelling and effusion
  • Serositis (pleurisy characterized by pleural rub or pain, pericarditis characterized by pericardial friction rub)
  • Renal
    • Persistent proteinuria ≥ 0.5 g/ 24 hours or RBC casts
  • Neurologic
    • Seizures, psychosis, mononeuritis, myelitis, peripheral or cranial neuropathies, acute confusional state
  • Hemolytic anaemia
  • Leukopenia (< 4.0 x 109 cells/L) or Lymphopenia (< 1.5 x 109cells/L) on two or more occasions
  • Thrombocytopenia (< 100 x  109 cells/L)

Immunological manifestations

  • ANA > reference negative value
  • Anti-dsDNA antibody >reference, if by ELISA 2x reference
  • Anti-Sm antibody
  • Antiphospholipid (any of lupus anticoagulant, anti-cardiolipin, anti-β glycoprotein I)
  • Low serum complement (C3, C4 or CH50)
  • Positive direct Coombs test in the absence of hemolytic anaemia

Option A: Oral ulcers

  • Oral ulcers and nasopharyngeal ulcers are common clinical findings seen in SLE patients and are part of the diagnostic criteria of SLE.

Option B: Psychosis

  • Psychosis is an important neurological complication of SLE and is a diagnostic criterion of SLE.

Option C: Discoid rash

  • Chronic lupus demonstrates discoid rash, panniculitis and other types of rashes which are important diagnostic criteria of SLE.

questions.text: A 7-year-old with a history of bed wetting and recurrent urinary tract infections is brought with complaints of left-sided abdominal pain that intensifies on urination. She has a fever of 101 F°. Left costovertebral angle tenderness is present. IV pyelogram is conducted, and urinary tract infection is suspected. How would this condition be treated?

choices.text: If the function of the upper pole ureter is normal, then no intervention is needed, and for the lower pole ureter, ureterovesicoplasty can be done
Both the poles should be excised and reimplanted into the bladder as the patient may become susceptible to UTI more frequently
For upper pole hydronephrosis with no function, an Upper pole nephrectomy should be performed.
The lower pole ureter is prone to develop Ureterocele, so it should be excised in any case

questions.solution:
Option C - For upper pole hydronephrosis with no function, an Upper pole nephrectomy should be performed:

  • In the above-mentioned clinical scenario, the patient is a 7-year-old female child who has presented with left-sided abdominal pain, fever and bed wetting. She has had a recurrent UTI since childhood, and her examination and imaging results reveals duplication of her left ureter.
  • Duplication of the ureter (AD)
    • Most Common congenital anomaly of the upper urinary tract.
    • The mode of inheritance is autosomal dominant.
    • More common in females.
    • Unilateral duplication is more common than bilateral.
    • The left side is more commonly involved.
    • Yo-Yo effect in the fused ureter (incomplete duplication) is seen, Yo-Yo reflux is the reflux of contrast in both limbs of the ureter on retrograde pyelogram in complete duplication.
    • Complete duplication occurs when there are two separate ureteric buds.
    • In complete duplication, the upper pole Ureteral orifice in the bladder is caudal and medial to the lower pole of the Ureteral orifice (Weigert Meyer rule).
    • Upper pole ureter is associated with Ureterocele, Lower pole ureter is associated with Short intravesical length of the ureter( risk of VUR).
  • Diagnosis:
    • IVP shows duplication in most cases.
    • which is aka drooping lily sign.
  • Treatment:
    • If the function of the Upper pole ureter is normal- Excision and reimplantation into the bladder.
    • If the function of the Upper pole ureter is impaired- an upper pole nephrectomy is done.
    • Lower pole ureter- Ureterovesicoplasty is done.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - If the function of the upper pole ureter is normal, then no intervention is needed, and for the lower pole ureter, ureterovesicoplasty can be done:

  • In case the function of the entire duplicate ureter is intact, with no symptoms, no intervention is required.

Option B - Both the poles should be Excised and reimplanted into the bladder as the patient may become susceptible to UTI more common:

  • There is no need to excise both poles.
  • Only the dysfunctional part needs to be excised and treated.

Option D - The lower pole ureter is prone to develop Ureterocele, so it should be excised:

  • The lower pole should only be excised and treated if any pathology is present.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented with complaints of 2 episodes of hematemesis. Initial investigations revealed Hb of 7.2g/dl. She was advised to have a UGI endoscopy done. Which of the following finding on upper GI endoscopy indicates the most negligible chances of re-bleeding after hematemesis episodes?
questions.solution:
Option B: Clean-based ulcer

  • Most patients with hematemesis have a re-bleed within the next 3 days of an episode.
  • UGIE is diagnostic and prognostic as a clean-based ulcer has the slightest chance of re-bleeding, while the visible bleeding vessel has the highest chance.
  • Endoscopic intervention is indicated in active bleeding, non-bleeding visible vessel, and active bleeding or visible vessel exposed after adherent clot removal.
  • These are ulcers with a clean base or with flat blood spots.

 

Option A: Adherent clot on the ulcer

  • An adherent clot is called a red, maroon, or black protuberance greater than 3 mm in diameter that could not be dislodged by forceful irrigation with water.
  • It is typically seen as a barium-filled ulcer crater's smooth or irregular filling defect.
  • Granulation tissue or debris in the ulcer may produce similar findings.
  • Symptoms may include sudden, severe pain in the belly (abdomen), usually in the upper abdomen.

 

Option C: Gastric ulcer with AV malformation

  • An arteriovenous malformation (AVM) is an abnormal tangle of blood vessels connecting arteries and veins, which disrupts normal blood flow and oxygen circulation.
  •  Arteries are responsible for taking oxygen-rich blood from the heart to the brain. Veins carry the oxygen-depleted blood back to the lungs and heart.
  • An AVM occurs when arteries in the brain connect directly to nearby veins without having the usual small vessels (capillaries) between them.
  • The exact cause of cerebral AVM is unknown. However, evidence suggests a genetic cause.

 

Option D: Visible bleeding vessel

  • There are four commonly used endoscopic techniques in treating a bleeding ulcer: injection therapy, thermal coagulation, endoscopic clipping, and, most recently, hemostatic powders that are sprayed onto the bleeding ulcer.
  • An endoscopy procedure may help to see if and where GI is bleeding and the bleeding's cause.
  • In upper GI bleeding, an IV drug known as a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is given to suppress stomach acid production.
  • Severe internal bleeding is life-threatening. Perforation or serious bleeding may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the OPD with the complaint of progressively worsening ulcers in the fingertips of both hands and feet for 4 years, along with intermittent claudication of the feet whenever he is walking. After taking history, he told the doctor that he had "migratory superficial thrombophlebitis." He is a  20-pack-year smoker who is not a diabetic; his cholesterol levels are normal according to him, and his ECG findings were normal. What would be the best way for this patient to arrest the development of his disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: Smoking cessation

  • This diagnosis is Buerger’s disease and the only measure that can stop disease progression is the cessation of smoking
  • Buerger’s disease, also known as thromboangitis  obliterans, is characterized by occlusive disease of small and medium-sized arteries.
  • It is associated with superficial thrombophlebitis and Raynaud’s phenomenon in a smoker of usually less than 30 years of age.
  • Amputation is indicated if the disease is not controlled.

Option A: Aspirin

  • It is a platelet aggregation inhibitor, usually beneficial in patients with atheromatous disease.
  • It has very little to no role in thromboangiitis obliterans.

Option B: Good glycaemic control

  • It is useful in patients with a disease due to increased blood sugar levels.
  • Because Buerger’s disease has no diabetic component, glycaemic control is useless in these patients.

Option C: Blood cholesterol control

  • It is useful in patients suffering from a disease due to the formation of atheromatous plaques in the vessel walls, resulting from increased cholesterol levels.
  • Cholesterol levels are normal in Buerger’s disease, so they don’t have a role in disease cessation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with abnormal menstrual bleeding and a pelvic mass undergoes a hysterectomy. The image shows the gross specimen removed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Leiomyoma.

  • Leiomyomas, also known as fibroids, are benign smooth muscle tumors that commonly affect the uterus. They often present with symptoms like abnormal menstrual bleeding and can be associated with a pelvic mass. The image of the gross specimen is consistent with leiomyoma, showing a well-defined, whorled mass.

Incorrect Options

Option B: Adenomyosis

  • Adenomyotic uterus appears symmetrically enlarged, globular uterus due to associated myometrial hypertrophy reflected by thickened myometrium, with a trabeculated cut surface with ill-defined hypertrophic swirls of smooth muscle and petechia-like gray foci of the endometrium.
  • A clear demarcation or capsule is absent, unlike shown in the specimen in question, which suggests fibroid

Option C: Endometriosis

  • Endometriosis is a condition where tissue similar to the lining of the uterus (endometrium) grows outside the uterus. It can cause pelvic pain, irregular bleeding, and the formation of adhesions or cysts. Diagnosis is usually confirmed through laparoscopic visualization or other imaging studies, and it is not typically identified as a gross specimen during a hysterectomy.

Option D: Endometrial hyperplasia

  • Endometrial hyperplasia is an abnormal thickening of the lining of the uterus (endometrium) due to an increase in the number of cells. It is associated with abnormal menstrual bleeding but is not typically visualized as a mass on gross examination. Instead, it may be diagnosed through endometrial biopsy or imaging studies.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman has been using tamoxifen for 2 years now for breast cancer prevention based on her strong family history, nulliparity, and early age at menarche. Her general physical and gynecological examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is this patient most likely to develop while on her current medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Endometrial changes

  • Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator used in the prevention and treatment of breast cancer. It is an antagonist of the estrogen receptor in breast tissue. In contrast, it behaves as an agonist in other tissues, such as the endometrium.
  • The partial agonist action on the endometrium can lead to endometrial hyperplasia and cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: osteoporosis

  • Tamoxifen is used for the prevention and treatment of osteoporosis

Option B: Elevated LDL cholesterol

  • Tamoxifen does not cause an elevation of LDL cholesterol.

Option D: Myocardial infarction

  • Tamoxifen does not increase the risk of myocardial infarction.

questions.text: In a study carried out prospectively, out of 1000 truck drivers who were using mobile while driving, 300 met an accident. During the same period, out of 5000 truck drivers who were not using mobile while driving, 300 met an accident. What is the Relative Risk?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: 5

  • Exposure is mobile usage while driving, the incidence of accidents under consideration is that of:
  • Incidence of exposure (IE)= 300/1000
  • Incidence of non-exposed (INE) = 300/5000
  • RR (Relative Risk) = = 5 (thus mobile usage is associated with 5 times increased incidence of accident).

questions.text: Which among the following indicators helps to measure the human development index?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Life expectancy:

  • Life expectancy is a vital indicator used to measure the Human Development Index (HDI).
  • It reflects the average number of years a person can expect to live, providing insight into overall health and well-being within a country.
  • Higher life expectancy rates are associated with higher levels of human development.

 

Incorrect Options

Option B - Carrying capacity: Carrying capacity refers to the maximum number of individuals an environment can sustain without degrading. It is not used in the calculation of the HDI.

Option C - Population density: Population density is the number of people living per unit area of land. It is not used in the calculation of the HDI.

Option D - Literacy rate: While literacy rate is related to education, the HDI specifically uses two education indicators: the mean years of schooling for adults aged 25 years or more and the expected years of schooling for children entering school. Literacy rate alone is not used to calculate the HDI.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male has come into your clinic complaining of an occipital headache. After examination, BP is elevated at about 170/90 mmHg, and the importance of starting medication immediately is explained. He mentions that he is a known diabetic but is not compliant with medication. Which of the following diuretics, if given, can cause metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Acetazolamide:

  • Acetazolamide functions as a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. Carbonic anhydrase facilitates the conversion of H+ and HCO3- into carbonic acid (H2CO3), leading to the formation of CO2 and H2O.
  • Acetazolamide causes metabolic acidosis by reducing the absorption of bicarbonate ions from proximal convoluted tubules.
  • Thus, it increases the bicarbonate excretion by preventing its absorption and ultimately decreases the blood pH.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Indapamide:

  • Thiazide-like diuretic.
  • Stimulates aldosterone secretion, causing contraction alkalosis.
  • Increases H+ excretion via H+ATPase activity on α-intercalated cells, leading to metabolic alkalosis.

Option B - Furosemide:

  • Increases aldosterone secretion, inducing contraction alkalosis.
  • Enhances H+ excretion through H+ATPase activity on α-intercalated cells, resulting in metabolic alkalosis.

Option C - Hydrochlorthiazide:

  • Thiazide diuretic.
  • Stimulates aldosterone secretion, causing contraction alkalosis.
  • Increases H+ excretion via H+ATPase activity on α-intercalated cells, leading to metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden shortness of breath for one hour. He gives no history of any other abnormalities or any chronic illness. After further investigation and examinations, the patient is diagnosed with acute congestive heart failure. He is given intravenous digoxin in the emergency. A few minutes later, the patient developed an irregular pulse consistent with ventricular arrhythmia. Which of the following monovalent cation would reverse the effects of toxicity of the drug involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Potassium

  • The patient in the case presented with acute onset of dyspnea and was diagnosed with acute compensated heart failure. He was given digoxin but soon developed toxicity and had ventricular arrhythmia. 
  • Digitalis is a cardiac glycoside that causes positive inotropic effects by acting on Na/K ATPase.
  • A monovalent cation (K+), potassium can undo a digitalis-induced arrhythmia.
  • Potassium and digitalis compete to bind on the same receptor present on Na+/K+ ATPase on the cell membrane.
  • Digitalis toxicity is exacerbated by hypokalemia and hypercalcemia.
  • Hyperkalemia decreases digitalis toxicity.
  • Acceleration of the storage of intracellular calcium appears to be responsible for abnormal automaticity induced by digitalis.
  • Hypercalcemia thus increases the chances of digitalis-induced arrhythmia.

Option A: Digibind antibodies

  • They are used in severe digitalis toxicity, which is characterized by neurological symptoms, nausea and anorexia.

Option B: Lignocaine

  • Lignocaine can be used for digitalis-induced arrhythmia.
  • But this drug has a risk of causing heart block in such cases.

  • Lignocaine is the drug of choice for BT/V-Fib due to digoxin toxicity.

Option C: Magnesium

  • Mg2+ has the opposite effect as Ca2+. Therefore, hypomagnesemia increases the risk of arrhythmias, whereas increased magnesium levels reduce the risk.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 10 weeks of gestation, presents to the obstetric outpatient department for her routine antenatal evaluation. She has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and is currently concerned about the viability of her pregnancy. Subsequently, ultrasonography was advised to look for fetal viability. Her ultrasound scan revealed a frog-like appearance of the fetal eyes. Based on the patient's history and ultrasonographic findings, the fetus is most likely to develop which of the following congenital anomalies?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anencephaly

  • Ultrasound done in the first trimester helps in dating the pregnancy.
  • Fetal malformations are best looked for at 18–20 weeks of gestation (anomaly scan).
  • If there is a malformation that is not viable, then a decision for the termination of pregnancy can be taken at this time
