  • However, in the first trimester, i.e., around 9–11 weeks, gross malformations of the fetus, like anencephaly, acrania, or spina bifida, can be picked up.
  • A routine first-trimester ultrasound scan is done for:
  • Pregnancy dating
  • Fetal viability
  • Intrauterine or extrauterine pregnancy
  • Multiple gestations
  • Nuchal translucency and nasal bone are checked at 11-13 weeks (markers for downs syndrome)
  • Anencephaly is a congenital anomaly in which the fetal skull, scalp, and brain do not develop properly.
  • It is a type of neural tube defect. Failure of rostral neuropore closure results in this condition. 
  • Ultrasound examination shows a frog-eye sign.

Option B: Dysplastic kidneys

  • Dysplastic kidneys are characterized by improper development of kidneys in utero.
  • The diagnosis is often made antenatally as early as the 15th week of gestation.
  • They do not appear with a frog sign in the ultrasound.

Option C: Microcephaly

  • Microcephaly is a condition where a baby has a head size much smaller than other babies of the same age and sex.
  • Ultrasonography is to be done at 18–20 weeks of gestation and not in the first trimester to detect specific deformities like microcephaly.

Option D: Holoprosencephaly

  • Holoprosencephaly is a disorder caused by the inability of the embryonic forebrain to sufficiently divide into the double lobes of the cerebral hemispheres.
  • A detailed anomaly scanning must be performed at 18-20 weeks to detect holoprosencephaly.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a crush injury of the lower limb 30 minutes ago. The patient is in severe pain. Limbs appear mottled on the examination. You're an Orthopaedic postgraduate attending the case. What can help you decide between amputation and limb salvage?
questions.solution:
Option C: MESS (Mangled Extremity Severity Score)

  • Mangled Extremity severity score (MESS) - Tells about the survival of a limb after a crush injury
  • Includes 4 parameters:
  • S –Shock
  • I - Ischemia
  • V -Velocity Of Trauma
  • A -Age of the patient
  • Total score = 11 ≥ 7 limbs cannot survive and requires amputation.

MESS (Mangled Extremity Severity Score):

Component Points
Skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Low energy(stab, simple fracture)
  • Medium energy(open or multiplex fractures, dislocation)
  • High energy( Crush injury, gunshot wound)
  • Very high energy (same as above plus gross contamination, soft tissue avulsion)

 
  • 1
  • 2
  • 3
  • 4
Limb Ischemia (score doubled for ischemia more than 6 hours)
  • Pulse reduced or absent, but perfusion normal
  • Pulseless paresthesia diminished capillary refill
  • Cool, paralyzed, insensate(numb)
  • 1
  • 2
  • 3
Shock
  • Systolic blood pressure is always >90mm
  • Transient hypotension
  • Persistent hypotension
  • 0
  • 1
  • 2
AGE (yr)

<30

30-50

>50
  • 0
  • 1
  • 2

Option A: Gustilo Anderson classification

Gustilo Anderson Classification is used to classify open fractures

  • Grade 1: Clean wound of < 1 cm length
  • Grade 2: Wound > 1cm in length without extensive soft tissue damage, skin flap, or avulsion
  • Grade 3: Wound associated with extensive soft tissue damage, comminution, contamination, segmental fractures, Gunshot injuries, or farmhouse injuries

Option B: GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) Score

  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the initial assessment of consciousness in an emergent patient.

Option D: ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support)

  • Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines are used in the assessment and resuscitation of injured patients.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukaemia after an incidental finding of leukocytosis last year. He was treated with imatinib, and the treatment was changed to nilotinib because of progressive leukocytosis. On follow-up, investigations revealed worsening of leukocytosis & thrombocytopenia. His peripheral blood showed >30% blasts with promyelocytes. What is the most effective treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Allogeneic bone marrow transplantation

  • The above features are suggestive of the Accelerated phase of CML.
  • Among patients who present with or evolve to the blastic phase, combinations of chemotherapy and Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors (TKI) should be used to induce remission, followed by allogeneic stem cell transplantation as soon as possible.
  • The same applies to patients who evolve from chronic to accelerated phase. Patients with de novo accelerated-phase CML may do well with long-term TKI therapy; the timing of allogeneic stem cell transplantation depends on their optimal response to TKI (achievement of complete cytogenetic response). The most effective is stem cell transplantation.
  • Among patients who relapse in the chronic phase, the treatment sequence depends on several factors, such as the patient's age and risk factors for stem cell transplantation.

Option B: Autologous bone marrow transplantation

  • Autologous bone marrow transplantation is not the treatment of choice; because the patient's bone marrow is already infiltrated with cancer.

Option C: Chemotherapy

  • The patient's peripheral blood shows >30% blasts with promyelocytes after treatment with imatinib and nilotinib. It shows chemotherapy is ineffective in this case.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Hydroxyurea & interferon

  • Hydroxyurea, a ribonucleotide reductase inhibitor, is used for controlling cell counts.
  • Interferons are given when allogeneic stem cell transplantation is not feasible.

questions.text: Which of the following events occurs immediately following the completion of meiosis II?

choices.text: Sperm penetration of the corona radiata

questions.solution:
Option C: Formation of a female pronucleus

  • The secondary oocytes stop in the metaphase of meiosis II and remain in this meiotic stage until fertilization.
  • After fertilization, the secondary egg cell completes meiosis II and forms a mature ovum and a polar body.
  • The nucleus of the mature egg cell is called the female pronucleus, which fuses with the male pronucleus to form a zygote.

Incorrect otpions

Option A: Degeneration of the zona pellucida

  • Oocytes are protected by granulosa cells, and those not protected undergo atresia.
  • Degeneration of the zona pellucida happens on day 5 after fertilization

Option B: Sperm penetration of the corona radiata

  • After ejaculation, Sperms reach the posterior fornix of the vagina, and it takes 2 minutes to reach the ampulla of the fallopian tube.
  • Acrosome breaks down and releases acrosin to fertilize oocyte (to disperse the corona radiata of zona pellucida of oocyte).
  • Acrosin (Hyaluronidase) will soften the zona pellucida (Acrosome reaction).
  • Sperm penetration of the corona radiata is a process leading to fertilization

Option D: Appearance of the blastocyst

  • Advanced morula enters the uterine cavity on Day 4 and changes to "Blastocyst."

  • It contains Blast cells & cyst-like cavities. Contains: Outer cell mass-Trophoblast [helps in placental formation] and inner cell mass – Embryoblast

  • The appearance of the blastocyst occurs on day 4 after fertilization

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the physician with muscle aches, irritability, and difficulty concentrating for 15 days. The patient is otherwise vitally stable. On probing, the patient says that due to a change in deadline at work, she has had less sleep and began worrying about completing work on time. Which of the following medicine will the doctor prescribe to her?
questions.solution:
Option A: Propranolol

  • This scenario indicates that the patient has a short-term anxiety disorder.
  • Anxiety disorder is a mental health condition that hinders a person’s daily life. Short-term anxiety usually lasts from days to a few weeks.
  •  

  • Mechanism of action: Propranolol works by blocking beta-adrenergic receptors in the body, particularly beta-1 and beta-2 receptors. By doing so, it reduces the effects of adrenaline (epinephrine) and other stress hormones, which can contribute to anxiety symptoms.

  • Performance anxiety: Propranolol is often prescribed for performance anxiety, such as stage fright or public speaking anxiety. By blocking the physical symptoms of anxiety, such as trembling, rapid heartbeat, and sweating, propranolol can help individuals feel more calm and in control during stressful situations.

  • Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD): Propranolol may be used off-label in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder, although it is less commonly prescribed for this condition compared to other medications specifically approved for anxiety disorders, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or benzodiazepines

  • Propranolol suppresses anxiety in short-term stressful situations, but this is due to peripheral rather than a specific central action.

Option B: Imipramine

  • It is a tricyclic anti-depressant that blocks norepinephrine and serotonin in the neuron.
  • Imipramine is used to elevate mood, improve mental alertness, and increase physical activity. Its abuse can cause blurred vision, urinary retention, constipation, and orthostatic hypotension. It isn't used very often for anxiety.

Option C: Fluoxetine

  • It is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor that is used as an anti-depressant. It is also used in longer anxiety disorders, panic attacks, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and bulimia.
  • Fluoxetine can be addictive, depending upon the dosage. Abuse of fluoxetine can cause decreased sex drive, drowsiness, nausea, nervousness, and excessive sweating.

Option D: Tamsulosin

  • Tamsulosin is non-quinazoline 1 receptor antagonist. It is also used in the treatment of BPH.
  • Tamsulosin relaxes the muscle in the prostate and bladder, helping the urine to flow out easily. But it does not produce apoptosis. Its side effects include disturbance in cognitive functions.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with an acute onset of nasal discharge, a frontal headache, and a temperature of 39.5°C. X-ray investigation reveals the below-depicted image:



The marked structure is lined by which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ciliated Columnar Epithelium

  • Paranasal sinuses are lined by a mucous membrane that is continuous with that of the nasal cavity through the ostia of the sinuses. Histologically, it is a pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells that secrete mucus.
  • The normal function of the nose and paranasal sinuses depends upon the health and integrity of the ciliated, columnar mucosal epithelium, and the overall anatomical pathways for mucus clearance, aeration, and sinus drainage.
  • The osteomeatal complex (OMC) is central to these considerations, which functionally represents the final common drainage pathway for the majority of the paranasal sinuses (frontal anterior/middle ethmoid cells and maxillary sinuses).
  • The OMC comprises five structures:
    • Maxillary Ostium: The main drainage channel of the maxillary sinus into the middle meatus.
    • Infundibulum: A common channel draining the Ostia of the maxillary and ethmoid sinuses to the hiatus semilunaris.
    • Bulla Ethmoidalis: A single air cell that projects infero-medially over the hiatus semilunaris.
    • Uncinate Process: A crescent-shaped process arising from the posteromedial aspect of the nasolacrimal duct, forming the anterior border of the hiatus semilunaris.
    • Hiatus Semilunaris: The final drainage passage between the bulla ethmoidalis superiorly and the free edge of the uncinate process.

Option A: Keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium

  • Besides the skin, the keratinized stratified squamous epithelium is also found in areas of the oral mucosa that are subject to frictional stress, such as the gingiva, hard palate and parts of the tongue.
  • While pseudostratified epithelium is found in the paranasal sinuses.

Option B: Nonkeratinizing stratified squamous epithelium

  • The stratified squamous epithelial cells that lack the keratin protein are called the nonkeratinized epithelium.
  • It is found in the buccal cavity, lips, the underside of the tongue, upper oesophagus, conjunctiva of eyes, rectum and vagina
  • Paranasal sinuses contain pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells that secrete mucus.

Option D: Transitional epithelium

  • Bladder contains transitional epithelium while paranasal sinuses are lined by a mucous membrane which contains pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells that secrete mucus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female smoker presented with non-small cell lung cancer from the lateral segmental right middle lobar orifice. Preoperative evaluation revealed excellent pulmonary reserve and no evidence of metastatic disease. Mediastinoscopy had negative results. A right vertical axillary thoracotomy revealed a central 3.0 cm adenocarcinoma invading the superior pulmonary vein and the descending pulmonary artery. Hence, the patient was prepared for pneumonectomy. What is the first step when doing a pneumonectomy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ligate pulmonary artery

  • Pneumonectomy is anatomically more straightforward than lobectomy (in carcinoma bronchus):
    • The pulmonary artery is first dissected, divided, and sutured.
    • The pulmonary veins are then isolated, divided, and sutured.
    • The main bronchus is divided so that no blind stump is usually stapled. 
    • Pneumonectomy indication:
      • Traumatic lung injury
      • Pulmonary tuberculosis
      • Fungal infections of the lung
      • Bronchiectasis
      • Congenital lung disease
      • Bronchial blockage with a destroyed lung
      •  Pulmonary metastases (cancer that has spread to the lungs from another site in the body)

Option A: Ligate the pulmonary vein

  • In carcinoma of bronchus, a pneumonectomy is anatomically simpler than a lobectomy: at first the pulmonary artery is dissected, divided, and sutured before the pulmonary veins are identified, divided, and sutured.

Option C: Divide the bronchus

  • In cases of carcinoma bronchus, a pneumonectomy is more straightforward anatomically than a lobectomy: first, the pulmonary artery is dissected, divided, and sutured; next, the pulmonary veins are isolated, divided, and sutured.
  • Finally, the main bronchus is divided so that no blind stump is left behind.

Option D: Perform lymph node clearance

  • A common medical operation is lobectomy (or pneumonectomy) with lymph node dissection.
  • In each of these procedures, surrounding lymph nodes are also removed to check for potential cancer spread.
  • However, the first step of pneumonectomy is the ligation of the pulmonary artery.

questions.text: What is responsible for the lack of heat sensation when a man touches a hot object, despite the signal reaching the thalamus but not being transmitted to the postcentral gyrus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Third-order neuron:

  • Lack of heat sensation despite signal reaching thalamus suggests disruption in thalamus to postcentral gyrus pathway.
  • Responsible Neurons: Third-order neurons transmit sensory information from thalamus to cortex.
  • Function: Third-order neurons act as pathway between thalamus and postcentral gyrus.
  • Projection: Second-order neurons project to thalamus, tertiary neurons project to postcentral gyrus.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Second-order neuron: Transmits signals from spinal cord to thalamus; located in spinal cord or brainstem.

Option B - First-order neuron: Carries signals from the periphery to the spinal cord or brainstem.

Option D - Receptor: Found in specialized organs; conveys distinct sensory modalities for integration into the perceptual frame.

questions.text: An elderly female patient occupationally teacher presents to the medicine outpatient department. She was complaining of a severe right-sided throbbing headache. Upon history taking, the patient informed that she has a history of polymyalgia rheumatica. The patient also had a history of undocumented weight loss because she had difficulty eating and was constantly fatigued. On further examination, she also complained of aching of the jaw during chewing. The result of the prescribed lab investigation showed the results of elevated ESR. The symptoms mentioned earlier indicate a vascular disease. Which statement is correct regarding the disease?

choices.text: Large vessel vasculitis is commonly seen in patients aged <50 years
Steroids are contraindicated in this vasculitis
50% of the patient present with ocular symptoms that vary from diplopia to complete vision loss
It is medium-vessel necrotizing vasculitis in young adults

questions.solution:
Option C: 50% of the patient present with ocular symptoms that vary from diplopia to complete vision loss

Giant cell arteritis:

  • Also known as "Temporal Arteritis."
  • GCA is a granulomatous large vessel vasculitis of the aorta and its branches, preferably the temporal artery.
  • GCA affecting cranial branches of the aortic arch :
    • Superficial temporal arteries (most common)
    • Ophthalmic arteries

 

  • Clinical features:
    • A disease of the elderly (age > 50)
    • Female predominance
  • Symptoms - constitutional:
    • fever,
    •  fatigue,
    • weight loss
  • Temporal artery:
    • Ipsilateral headache
    • Tender artery and scalp
    • Absent TA pulse
  • Ophthalmic artery : (optical symptoms)
    • Optic neuritis
    • Diplopia to complete vision loss in 50 % of patients
    • Amaurosis fugax
  • Facial artery:
    • Jaw claudication (pain on chewing due to ischemia of masseter muscles).
  • Diagnosis:
    • Diagnosis is based on clinical features + elevated ESR + prompt response to steroid.
    • Elevated ESR.
    • Elevated CRP
    • Normocytic normochromic anemia
    • Temporal artery biopsy
  • Treatment:
  • Steroids (Prednisone at 40–60 mg daily for 1 month with gradual tapering).
  • Do not await biopsy and pathology reports to start steroids.
  • Monitor clinical status and ESR.

Option A: Large vessel vasculitis is commonly seen in patients aged <50 years.

  • In Asia, Takayasu's Arteritis is the most common vasculitis in young and middle-aged patients (age <50).
  • It is granulomatous large vessel  vasculitis affecting
  • Aortic arch vessels
  • Pulmonary arteries ( half of the cases)
  • Clinical features :
    • Fatigue, malaise, weight loss, arthralgia
    • Anaemia and elevated ESR
    • Visual field defects and retinal haemorrhages
    • Systolic BP <10mm Hg b/w arms
    • Loss of pulse in upper extremities
  • Female predominant
  • Angiography is the most accurate test.
  • It shows occlusions, stenosis and aneurysms.
  • Treatment:
    • Steroids (high dose)
    • Immunosuppressant

Option B: Steroids are contraindicated in this vasculitis

  • Steroids are contraindicated in Kawasaki disease (medium-sized vessel vasculitis) due to the danger of vessel rupture.
  • Kawasaki is treated with Aspirin (NSAID) and IV Immunoglobin.
  • GCA is treated with high and low-dose steroids.
  • Corticosteroids are used in GCA to improve the visual acuity of the patient.
  • There is a severe danger of blindness in untreated patients.

 

Option D: It is medium-vessel necrotizing vasculitis in young adults.

  • Polyarteritis Nodusa is necrotizing vasculitis involving medium-sized vessels in young adults, predominately male.
  • It spares pulmonary arteries.
  • Clinical features:
    • Constitutional:  weight loss, fever, fatigue
    • Musculoskeletal: arthritis, myalgias, arthralgias
    • Renal: hypertension,  renal failure
    • CNS: peripheral neuropathies, mononeuritis multiplex, stroke
    • GI: abdominal pain, cholecystitis
    • Skin: palpable purpura, ulceration
    • Lab findings :
      • Elevated ESR
      • Hepatitis B surface antigen (in 30% of cases)
  • Treatment:
    • Corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide
    • Anti-viral therapy for hepatitis B-related PAN

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient presents to the neurology clinic with weakness in both lower extremities, progressively worsening tingling and numbness, and difficulty getting up from the chair. He has had a history of having laxity in both ankles since his 20s. He also has a tendency for his feet to turn inwards, trip, and subsequently sprain his ankles. Family history also reports having hammertoes in immediate family members involving his mother, sibling, and daughter. On examination, palpable nerves are seen. A typical onion bulb appearance is noted on a biopsy of the nerve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Charcot Marie Tooth disease

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder due to the defective proteins involved in myelin sheath structure and function.
  • It results in foot abnormalities and motor/sensory deficits.
  • Concomitant sensory deficit leads to Gait ataxia.
  • Nerve biopsy: Classical onion bulb appearance seen in Charcot Marie Tooth disease.
  • Charcot Marie Tooth disease ( Hereditary sensorimotor neuropathy) manifests as:
  • Peroneal muscle atrophy leading to stork leg appearance as shown in the image provided in the question.
  • Thickened nerves
  • Nerve biopsy: Onion bulb appearance
  • Distal weakness
  • A summary of signs and symptoms is given below in the image:

Option B: Lambert Eaton Syndrome

  • Autoantibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated Ca2+ channels characterize Lambert Eaton Syndrome.
  • Clinical manifestations are:
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Autonomic dysfunction (constipation, dry mouth)
  • Absent deep tendon reflexes
  • Dysphagia and dysarthria also are seen.
  • Ocular symptoms are ptosis and diplopia due to cranial nerve (CN)involvement.
  • Repeated electrical stimulation enhances muscle power due to incremental response.
  • It is associated with small-cell carcinoma of the lung.

Option C: Neurosyphilis

  • Tabes dorsalis or Neurosyphilis is caused by tertiary syphilis.
  • It results from the degeneration/demyelination of dorsal columns and roots.
  • There is decreased sense of proprioception which leads to sensory ataxia (the patient cannot stand with closed eyes and falls to the ground).
  • There is also decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes.

Option D: Duchenne's Muscular dystrophy

  • It is a genetic mutation with dystrophin gene deletion from chromosome X, so it mainly affects boys.
  • Dystrophin is a structural protein present in muscle fibres, and its absence results in muscular abnormalities:
  • Clumsy and waddling gait.
  • Progressive proximal muscular weakness.
  • Thigh muscles atrophy
  • Hypertrophy of calf muscle (pseudo-hypertrophy to compensate for the thigh muscle weakness).
  • Kyphoscoliosis
  • It starts affecting in 3 to 4 years, and the child can become a wheelchair user by 12 years.
  • It can also cause pulmonary problems due to kyphoscoliosis

questions.text: A 19-year-old female was admitted to the hospital with a history of high-grade fever (39°C) accompanied by rigor and myalgia, which lasted for a few days. Doctors failed to find the cause after labs and other investigations. A provisional diagnosis of fever of unknown origin was made. Which of the following cytokine has endogenous pyrogenic activity?
questions.solution:
Option B: IL-6

  • As mentioned, the above given is a case of fever of unknown origin.
  • It has endogenous pyrogenic activity.
  • A cytokine produced by monocytes and macrophages causes fever and the production of several acute-phase reactants.
  • Due to its short half-life, it can be used to monitor patients with severe inflammatory reactions and sepsis.

Option A: IL-8

  • Neutrophil chemotactic factor.
  • A cytokine produced by macrophages.
  • Major functions include phagocytosis and inducing chemotaxis of neutrophils and other granulocytes.

Option C: TGF-β

  • A growth factor is involved in cell migration, proliferation, and differentiation through binding to the epidermal growth factor receptor.

Option D:  IL-3

  • It is a cytokine that supports the growth and differentiation of hematopoietic stem cells.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presented with a long history of upper abdominal discomfort, anorexia and two episodes of recent gum bleeds without fever or other bleeding manifestations. Examination revealed moderate hepatosplenomegaly. On investigation, he was found to have extreme thrombocytosis and leucocytosis. He was investigated for CML and found to be positive for BCR-ABL by reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR). Vitamin B12 level in this patient would be?
questions.solution:
Option A: Elevated

  • Vitamin B12 is markedly increased in CML
  • The increase in circulating Vitamin B12 levels is predominantly caused by enhanced production of haptocorrin.
  • The haptocorrin is also known as transcobalamin-1 (TC-1) or cobalophilin.
  • It is a unique glycoprotein produced by the salivary glands of the oral cavity in response to the ingestion of food.
  • The essential function of haptocorrin is the protection of the acid-sensitive vitamin B12 while it moves through the stomach.

Option B: Decreased (slightly)

  • The level of vitamin B12 is markedly increased in CML.
  • The level of LAP (Leukocyte Alkaline Phosphatase) is decreased in CML.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Normal

  • The level of vitamin B12 is markedly increased in CML.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Markedly decreased

  • The level of vitamin B12 is markedly increased in CML.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman, G3P2 at the gestation of 12 weeks has come to the hospital. She has a history of conisation one year back, and currently, she is on follow-up with no recurrence of cervical abnormalities on the Pap smear. She also has a history of preterm births at 30 and 32 weeks during her last 2 pregnancies. Which of the following would be the next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Cervical cerclage

  • Conization, also known as a cone biopsy, is a surgical procedure in which a cone-shaped wedge of tissue is removed from the cervix or other part of the body for examination and treatment of abnormal cells or lesions.
  • Given the history of conization and previous preterm births, cervical cerclage may be considered. Cervical cerclage is a surgical procedure where a stitch is placed around the cervix to provide support and prevent cervical insufficiency. This can be a preventive measure to reduce the risk of preterm birth.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Termination of pregnancy

  • History of conisation and history of 2 preterm births is indicative that the patient has cervical insufficiency due to a short cervix. Women with a history of conization have a shorter cervical length.
  • Termination of pregnancy is not indicated here, as strengthening the cervix can benefit the patient.

Option C: Complete bed rest

  • Complete bed rest is advised; however, cervical cerclage is more definitive, which should be followed by rest.

Option D: Ecosprin + LMWH

  • Ecosprin with LMWH is indicated in recurrent abortions due to antiphospholipid antibody syndrome.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to OPD complaining of painless bloody diarrhoea with a frequency of 10 episodes/ day, generalized weakness, puffy eyes, and swelling over both ankles. A colonoscopy reveals lesions in the rectum. A biopsy is taken, and a microscopic examination of tissue shows inflammation limited to mucosa and submucosa only. Which of the following is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation in this disease?
questions.solution:
Option B: Faecal lactoferrin

  • The above case scenario is indicative of Ulcerative colitis.
  • Faecal lactoferrin, a glycoprotein in activated neutrophils, is a sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation in ulcerative colitis.
  • Faecal calprotectin levels can also be elevated in cases of acute diarrhoea.

Option A: CRP

  • It is used to monitor disease activity in autoimmune diseases.

Option C: Faecal calprotectin

  • Faecal calprotectin levels correlate well with histologic inflammation, predict relapses, and detect pouchitis

Option D: Leukocytosis

  • The degree of white blood cell elevation does not correlate with the number of white blood cells in the intestine.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presented to us with c/o epigastric pain and weight loss. He also gave a history of dyspepsia and progressively increasing jaundice with clay-colored stools with no history of fever or pruritus. On physical examination, there was evidence for icterus without any palpable neck lymphadenopathy. Abdominal and chest CT scan confirmed the presence of a tumor measuring 50 mm in the head of the pancreas. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) also indicated that the tumor was in contact with both the SMA and the SMV, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy revealed adenocarcinoma. On the basis of these clinical findings, the patient was diagnosed with Unresectable Locally Advanced Pancreatic cancer. Which of the following drug can be prescribed to the patient to increase his survival rate?
questions.solution:
• Gemcitabine is currently the standard of care for patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer
  • Gemcitabine was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for use in pancreatic cancer in 1996.
  • In patients with unresectable pancreatic cancer, gemcitabine results in symptomatic improvement, improved pain control and performance status, and weight gain.
  • Prior to gemcitabine, 5-fluorouracil was used as the standard treatment for unresectable pancreatic cancer.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old female complains of blurry vision, foreign body sensation, and photophobia in her right eye. Her symptoms are sudden in onset and progressively worsening for one week. On inspection of the eye, the following findings are noted:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis

  • The given image shows a Fascicular ulcer which is seen with phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis.

PHLYCTENULAR KERATOCONJUNCTIVITIS

  • Nodular affection is an allergic response by conjunctival and corneal epithelium in response to endogenous allergens to which they have been sensitized.
  • Delayed (Type IV) hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous allergens
    • Staphylococcal  > Tubercular proteins
    • Others - Moraxella, worm infestations
  • Predisposing factors
    • 3-15 years of age
    • Girls > Boys
    • Malnourishment
    • Overcrowded, unhygienic conditions
    • Spring, summer seasons
  • Characterized by the stage of nodule formation leading to ulceration (at the apex of the nodule). Other findings are granulation with healing (without scarring).
  • Clinically varieties:
    • Simple: localized typical pinkish raised nodule with surrounding hyperemia on bulbar conjunctiva, usually near the limbus
    • Necrotizing: more marked necrosis and ulceration at the apex of the lesion
    • Miliary: multiple phlyctens.​​​​​​​
  • Management
    • Usually, self-limiting healing within 10 days with rare recurrences.
    • Local therapy
      • Topical Steroids
      • Topical antibiotics
      • Topical lubricants
      • Topical mydriatics (in corneal involvement).
    • Specific therapy for underlying septic focus (Staphylococcal), tubercular infection, or worm infestation.
  • General measures: correct malnutrition, including a high protein diet, Vitamin A and Vitamin D supplementation.​​​​​​​

Option A: HSV keratitis

  • The hallmark of HSV keratitis is the presence of multiple small branching epithelial dendrites on the surface of the cornea.​​​​​​​

Option B: Spring catarrh

  • Also known as vernal keratoconjunctivitis.
  • A stringy rope-like discharge is seen.
  • Cobblestone appearance due to enlarged papilla (hallmark)
  • Maxwell Lyon sign - Coagulated ropy discharge forming pseudomembranes seen on the eversion of the eyelid.
  • Horner trantas spots
  • DOC is Sodium cromoglycolate

Option C: Riboflavin deficiency

  • Riboflavin deficiency leads to cheilosis and corneal vascularization.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient with a known case of diabetes mellitus for 9 years presented with complaints of sudden drooping of his left eyelid and double vision in the left eye. On examination, the pupil of the left eye had a sluggish reaction to direct light and measured 6 mm, compared with 3 mm in the right eye with a normal reaction to light. The cover test revealed that the patient could not adduct, supraduct, or infraduct, his left eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Oculomotor palsy

  • This patient is experiencing oculomotor (CN III) nerve palsy. The oculomotor nerve innervates most extraocular muscles, including the superior rectus, medial rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles.
  • CN III palsy should be considered an emergency; it is critical to obtain imaging looking for an aneurysm or tumour, including a mass causing uncal herniation.
  • CN III has both motor (central) and parasympathetic (peripheral) components.
  • Depending on the nerve fibres affected, initial symptoms and signs may differ. Motor (central) components tend to be affected primarily by vascular diseases such as diabetes and hypertension, while parasympathetic (peripheral) components are first affected by compression, often by aneurysms or uncal herniation.
  • In this case, CN III nerve palsy is a consequence of vascular disease because of diabetes mellitus.
  • It is important to mention that internuclear ophthalmoplegia is a purely horizontal motility issue, whereas a CN III palsy can involve vertical muscles and the eyelid.
  • The diagnostic work-up includes visual field measurement and CT and MRI scans of the brain.
  • The treatment includes managing the underlying condition responsible for the symptoms.

Option A: Lateral rectus palsy

  • Lateral rectus palsy results from a lesion of CN VI. However, in this case, the pupils would be equal and reactive. Further, the extraocular movements would reveal a complete lack of abduction in the left eye with a large left esotropia.

Option B: Myasthenia gravis

  • It is an autoimmune neuromuscular disease characterized by generalized muscle weakness.
  • The pathophysiology of myasthenia gravis involves autoantibodies directed against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors (AchR), which induce T-cell-mediated destruction of those receptors.
  • Clinical manifestations include eye muscle weakness.
  • The most common initial manifestation is a triad of ptosis, diplopia, and blurred vision.
  • Further, bulbar muscle weakness, slurred speech, difficulty chewing or swallowing, and proximal limb weakness are also seen. 
  • Muscle fatigue worsens throughout the day and with increased activity.
  • These features are not present in this patient, so we can exclude this option.

Option D: Presbyopia

  • This is an age-related decrease in the power of accommodation of the eye caused by decreased elasticity of the crystalline lens and increased weakness of the ciliary muscles.
  • Presbyopia typically leads to an inability to focus on nearby objects. These features are not present, so we can rule out this option.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented to the casualty complaining of swelling in the right side of the neck region. After reading some information online, he is worried that he has anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. A small, solitary nodule in the right lobe of the thyroid was noted on physical examination, and FNAC reveals follicular adenoma. Which of the following is the best surgery for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Right hemithyroidectomy

 

  • A follicular tumor malignancy occurs with a long history and is more prevalent in goiters. It is most common among females and those between their fifth and sixth decades. The patient has a sudden increase in swelling size and little to no pain around edema. No evidence of lymphatic spread (So lymph nodes need not be removed during surgery). It spreads mostly through hematogenous.
  • Follicular adenoma and follicular cancer cannot be distinguished by FNAC. Therefore, when a single thyroid nodule is diagnosed as a follicular adenoma, hemithyroidectomy is first performed, and a specimen is sent for histopathology. If there is proof of vascular invasion or capsular invasion, a complete thyroidectomy is performed.

 

Option A: Enucleation 

  • The removal of the nodule alone by enucleation is associated with a greater risk of bleeding and/or spillage and spread of the tumor. Therefore, the most effective removal is done by thyroidectomy (hemithyroidectomy to remove the specimen and diagnosis)

Option B: Sub-total thyroidectomy

  • Removal of the majority of the thyroid gland, leaving behind 4 - 8 g of the thyroid.

Option D: Near-total thyroidectomy 

Removal of the entire thyroid gland except < 1 gm of thyroid tissue

questions.text: School health refers to a state of complete physical, mental, social and spiritual well- being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity among pupils, teachers and otherschool personnel. Which of the following committee gave the concept of school health first?
questions.solution:
BHORE committee

School Health ·

  • Concept first laid by BHORE committee (Recommendation 1946)
  • Guidelines were laid down in detail by RENUKA ROY committee (Recommendation 1961)

BHORE Committee

Contribution of BHORE committee as follows:

  • School health
  • Primary health care
  • Health survey and development
  • Social Health
  • Comprehensive Health care
  • Social physician

RENUKA ROY committee

  • Renuka roy committee gave the first comprehensive school health.

Kartar Singh committee

  • Kartar Singh committee is the committee on multipurpose workers under health and family planning.

Mukherjee committee

  • Mukherjee committee suggested that Basic health should be provided at block level

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman visited our hospital with her son because she had developed feelings of anxiety and sleep disturbance. She could not cook, make telephone calls, and shop without assistance for two years. She has no history of psychiatric disorders. She is given Donepezil 5 mg/day and returns for follow-up visits with her daughter once a month. Feelings of sleep disturbance and anxiety showed improvement at the three-month follow-up visit. Which of the following statements are true in her condition?

choices.text: Onset before 45 years of age is rare
Long-term memory is affected before short term memory
Staining shows Tau protein in senile plaques
MRI shows atrophy in frontal and parietal lobes

questions.solution:
Option A: Onset before 45 years of age is rare

  • It is a true statement.
  • Onset before 45 is rare as it is usually after 65 years of age.
  • Alzheimer's disease is a neurodegenerative disease that starts slowly and worsens progressively. It is the cause of the majority of cases of Dementia.
  • One of the most common early symptoms is difficulty in remembering recent events. As the disease advances, symptoms may include problems with language, disorientation, mood swings, decreased self-neglect, motivation, and behavioral issues.
  • As the disease progresses, they often withdraw from family and society. Gradually, bodily functions are lost, leading to death.
  • The leading genetic risk factor is an APOE4 allele. Risk factors include a history of head injury, depression, and hypertension. The disease process is mainly associated with amyloid plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and loss of neuronal connections in the brain.
  • The diagnosis is based on the history of the disease and cognitive testing with medical imaging and blood tests to rule out other common causes. Initial symptoms are commonly mistaken for normal aging. An examination of brain tissue is needed for a definite diagnosis, but this can only happen after death.
  • Good nutrition, physical activity, and getting engaged in social activities are known to be of benefit generally in aging. They can help in reducing the risk of cognitive decline, and Alzheimer's.
  • Treatments can be further divided into pharmaceutical, psychosocial, and caregiving.​​​​​​​

Option B: Long-term memory is affected before short-term memory

  • It is a false statement.
  • Long-term memory gets affected in advanced stages only.

Option C: Staining shows Tau protein in senile plaque

  • It is a false statement.
  • Senile plaques contain amyloid bet (Aβ) and not tau proteins.

Option D: MRI shows atrophy in the frontal and parietal lobe

  • It is a false statement.
  • In diseases of the temporal and parietal lobe, MRI usually indicates atrophy in the temporal and parietal lobes. Although, the frontal cortex does get implicated in the advanced phases.

questions.text: A 63-year-old obese woman presents to the clinic with a history of chronic leg swelling for several years. She reports that her legs get intermittently red and swollen. When this happens, she applies a combination of lanolin and Neosporin. She further explains that one week ago, she applied the same drug combination, and her legs got inflamed, and she developed blisters, oozing, and severe pruritus within a few minutes. Which of the following condition has likely caused her skin symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option A: Allergic contact dermatitis

  • This patient has obesity which puts her at risk of varicose veins.
  • Her leg swelling is most likely caused by varicose veins. Her symptoms that include inflamed legs, blister development, and severe pruritis after application of topical drugs most likely suggest allergic contact dermatitis.

Following are the essential features of allergic contact dermatitis:

  • Complication of dermatitis of lower legs.
  • Clinically this may present as an eczematous eruption with a sharp, linear cut-off matching the application of topical therapy, wound dressing, or compression hosiery.
  • Common complication of venous eczema, possibly because of the large number of antigen-presenting cells in the inflamed skin and also because of prolonged contact with topical therapies and compression hosiery.
  • Allergens include topical antibiotics, topical steroids, preservatives, fragrances, and rubber accelerators.

Option B:  Bullous Impetigo

  • Bullous impetigo begins with small vesicles that become flaccid bullae which contain a clear or yellow fluid that eventually progresses to become purulent or dark.
  • Surrounding erythema and edema are typically absent.
  • This patient's symptoms which developed after applying an allergenic medication, most likely suggest allergic contact dermatitis.

Option C: Cellulitis

  • Cellulitis presents with a poorly demarcated, warm, and erythematous area with associated edema and tenderness to palpation.
  • It is caused by bacterial infection, most commonly by gram-positive bacteria. Fever is often present.

Option D: Erysipelas

  • In erysipelas, there are areas of skin erythema that are sharply demarcated with raised edges.
  • The patient usually complains of burning, tenderness, and itchiness at the site. It is caused by gram-positive organisms.

questions.text: During Orchiopexy for undescended testes, accidental ligation of which artery compromises the blood supply to the testes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Internal spermatic arteries:

  • The anatomy of the adult testis reflects its embryonic development.
  • Testis arises from portions of the Wolffian bodies on the genital ridge below the kidneys at around the 10th thoracic level; therefore, the major blood vessels for the testes arise high up the retroperitoneum from the aorta below the renal arteries and are called the internal spermatic arteries or testicular arteries.

Secondary blood supply to the testes arises from the artery of the vas deferens and a small branch from the epigastric artery termed the external spermatic artery or cremasteric artery, which forms during the descent of the testes from the abdomen to the scrotum.

  • The surgical importance of this phenomenon is that operations involving the region of the renal arteries may sacrifice the internal spermatic artery.
  • The vascular and genital ductal structures leave the testis from the mediastinum in the posterosuperior portion and travel through the scrotal neck into the inguinal canal.
  • The venous drainage of the testicle initially begins as a pampiniform plexus coalescing into the gonadal or testicular veins.
  • On the right, the vein drains directly into the vena cava, and on the left, the vein drains into the left renal vein.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hypogastric arteries:

  • Hypogastric arteries are not the main blood supply to the testes.
  • Hypogastric arteries supply the pelvic viscera.

Option B - Pudendal arteries:

  • The internal pudendal artery supply to the posterior scrotal region.
  • The main supply to the testes is via the testicular artery, which arises from the aorta.

Option D - External spermatic arteries:

  • External spermatic arteries mainly supply to the spermatic cord.
  • The external spermatic arteries are the 2nd blood supply of the testes.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate next step in managing a 39-year-old woman with irregular menstrual bleeding, a negative pregnancy test, and a 2 cm diameter, well-defined, homogeneous polypoid lesion with a single vascular pedicle in the endometrial cavity on transvaginal ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Hysteroscopy biopsy

  • The above given is a case of endometrial polyps.
  • Hysteroscopy allows direct visualization of the endometrial cavity and the identified polypoid lesion.
  • A biopsy can be performed during hysteroscopy to obtain tissue for histological examination.
  • It provides a more accurate assessment of the nature of the lesion, helping to rule out malignancy and establish a definitive diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Doppler

  • Doppler sonography can detect the presence of polyps establish increased vascularity and identify a pedicle, however, the diagnosis can be confirmed best with hysteroscopy

Option C: CT scan

  • CT scan can detect an endometrial polyp but definitive diagnosis can be made with hysteroscopy.

Option D: Endometrial aspiration

  • Endometrial aspiration is an office procedure, wherein endometrial cells are aspirated and sent for histopathology, however, it is a blind procedure and thus cannot visually diagnose a polyp

questions.text: A 4-day-old newborn baby is brought to the pediatric emergency by his mother with complaints of difficulty breathing, constant crying, and a barrel-shaped chest. The patient is vitally stable. A chest X-ray of the baby is done, which reveals a congenital diaphragmatic hernia. The patient is posted for surgery. The doctor would explain to the parents that this condition may result from failure of which the following?

choices.text: The dorsal mesentery of the esophagus develops

questions.solution:
Option B: Abnormal fusion of  Pleuroperitoneal membranes 

  • This is a case of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
  • The diaphragm is formed through the fusion of tissue from four different places.
  • The pleuroperitoneal membranes usually fuse with the 3 other components during the 6th week of fetal development.
  • Abnormal fusion of one or both of the pleuroperitoneal membranes causes an abnormal opening between the abdomen and thorax through which abdominal viscera may herniate.
  • The most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia is a Bochdalek hernia.
  • Other types include diaphragm eventration, Morgagni hernia, and defects of the central tendon of the diaphragm.
  • Malformation of the diaphragm results in the abdominal organs pushing into the chest cavity, thus, disturbing proper lung formation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Septum transversum to develop

  • Kupffer 's cells and blood cells are formed from the mesoderm of septum transversum.
  • Ventral mesentery is a derivative of septum  transversum

Option C: Pleuropericardial membrane to develop>

  • Thoracic cavity is divided into pericardial cavity and two pleural cavities for the  lungs by pleuropericardial membrane.

Option D: Dorsal mesentery of the esophagus to develop.

  • Dorsal mesentery extend from lower portion of esophagus to the rectum as a continuous sheet of tissue attached to the posterior abdominal wall provide a pathway for blood vessels, lymphatics , and nerves to the gut and its derivatives.

questions.text: A 26-year-old army man presented to our hospital with complaints of breathlessness, mostly on exertion, dry cough and episodes of hemoptysis for the past 18 months. A digital chest radiograph was labelled normal from the outside. Still, on careful observation, bilateral lower lobe infiltration was observed, and then HRCT was advised, which showed early bronchiectatic changes in both lungs. Pulmonary function testing demonstrated a decrease in lung capacity with mild airflow. These characteristic Bronchiectatic features with dry cough are most commonly seen with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Tuberculosis

  • Bronchiectasis is defined as permanent abnormal dilation of bronchi and bronchioles.
  • The hallmark of this disease is a copious amount of productive cough and, i.e. the copious amount of sputum, which is yellowish-green in color.
  • The cause is persistent infection by opportunistic organisms in the dilated bronchial tree.
  • On the other hand, bronchiectasis sicca or dry bronchiectasis is a rare condition that comprises all bronchiectasis features but the absence of a copious amount of sputum.
  • The most important causes are airway obstruction, cigarette smoking, rheumatic and systemic diseases, pulmonary infections (e.g. tuberculosis), cystic fibrosis, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.
  • Other infectious organisms associated with bronchiectasis sicca are P. aeruginosa, H. influenza, S.pneumoniae, and S. aureus.
  • Common clinical manifestations include cough, hemoptysis, fever, pleuritic chest pain, and fatigue.

  • HRCT chest shows abnormal dilation of the tracheal and bronchial tree; it is present without infective sputum and occurs due to tuberculosis.
  • A dry cough with hemoptysis is the typical presentation.

Option B: Pertussis

  • Pertussis is an acute respiratory infection characterized by severe spasmodic coughing, not seen in this case.
  • The complications of pertussis are bacterial pneumonia, seizures, brain inflammation, and death.

Option C: Cystic fibrosis

  • Cystic fibrosis can result in bronchiectasis and bronchiectasis sicca, but it is more commonly found in younger adults or children.

Option D: Kartagener syndrome

  • Kartagener syndrome can result in bronchiectasis and bronchiectasis sicca.
  • It comprise of a triad of bronchiectasis, situs inversus and sinusitis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of failure to conceive. She has been married for 10 years and has a baby of 8 years. She is undergoing infertility evaluation for secondary infertility. Her past pregnancy was spontaneously conceived 8 years back. A few blood tests evaluate ovarian reserve, including inhibin B, considering her age. Serum inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells starting at which stage of the menstrual cycle.
questions.solution:
Option B: Preantral follicle stage

  • Inhibins are heterodimeric protein hormones released by granulosa cells of the ovary in females and Sertoli cells of the testis in males.
  • Inhibin selectively decreases the secretion of pituitary follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
  • They have local paracrine actions in the gonads.
  • Serum inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells starting at the preantral follicle stage and therefore reflects the size of the growing follicular cohort.
  • It is thus used as a measure of ovarian reserve in women with infertility, especially in those of advanced age, as the ovarian reserve is known to decline with age.
  • In normal fertile women, reduced inhibin B levels are seen with aging.
  • Inhibin B alone has poor predictive value for an ovarian response but improves the predictive value when added to the CCCT (clomiphene citrate challenge test).
  • Tests for ovarian reserve
    • FSH: the early follicular phase
    • Estradiol levels
    • Progesterone levels: mid-luteal
    • Inhibin B level
    • Anti-mullerian hormone
    • Ultrasound: antral follicle count, ovarian volume and ovarian blood flow
    • Clomiphene citrate challenge test
    • Ovarian biopsy

Stages of follicular development

  • Folliculogenesis is divided into various stages according to follicular characteristics regarding the number and appearance of granulosa cells, development of theca cells and formation of a fluid-filled structure called the antrum.
  • Preantral follicles: include primordial, primary and secondary follicles.
    • Primordial: 0.03-0.05 mm formed by a primary oocyte arrested in Prophase 1, surrounded by 1 layer of granulosa cells.
    • Primary: 0.1 mm, cuboidal granulosa cells develop FSH receptors.
    • Secondary: 0.2 mm, multilayered granulosa cell, theca cells develop from the stroma.
  • Antral follicles: tertiary and preovulatory follicles.
    • Tertiary: 0.2-5 mm and later 10-20 mm, formation of the antrum.
    • Preovulatory: > 20 mm

Option A: Tertiary follicle stage

  • Serum inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells starting at the preantral follicle stage

Option C: Early antral stage

  • Serum inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells starting at the preantral follicle stage, so it's a false statement.

Option D: Preovulatory stage​​​​​​​

  • Serum inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells starting at the preantral follicle stage, so it's not a true statement.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male race-course farrier presents to his family doctor complaining of persistent pain and numbness, fatigue, and frequent cramps extending bilaterally throughout the upper limbs (especially on the right side). Colour flow Doppler USG is prescribed, which reveals bilateral functional stenosis of the axillary-subclavian vein, which is more severe on the right side. A subsequent angiography-assisted CT scan shows the presence of right subclavian venous thrombosis. What is likely the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: IV anticoagulants + Rest should be advised as the provocative factor is his occupation
Anticoagulation therapy followed by catheter-directed Thrombolytic therapy

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anticoagulation therapy followed by catheter-directed Thrombolytic therapy:

  • In this case, as the patient is farrier, he overuses his arm. History of overuse of the arm and functional stenosis of the axillary-subclavian vein suggests the diagnosis of Axillary-subclavian venous thrombosis (ASVT). 
  • Treatment:
    • Once ASVT is diagnosed, anticoagulation therapy should be initiated in order to prevent pulmonary embolism (PE) and decrease symptoms. 
    • Patients diagnosed with acute symptomatic primary ASVT are candidates for catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IV anticoagulants + Rest should be advised as the provocative factor is his occupation:

  • Rest and elevation of the limb are the initial management for ASVT.
  • As in this case, the patient's symptoms are severe; only rest cannot cure the damage. 

Option B - Treated with IV anticoagulants alone:

  • Anticoagulants are blood thinners and prevent blot clot formation. But already present blood clots are treated by Catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy.
  • Catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy is used to treat acute ASVT. It dissolves the blood clot that can travel to the lungs and can cause shortness of breath and chest pain and lead to death. 

Option D - Ultrasound-guided embolectomy:

  • Ultrasound-guided embolectomy is performed when the blood clot has reached lungs and causes pulmonary embolism.
  • As the patient has not reached this stage, catheter-directed thrombolysis will be used for the treatment.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male is brought to the emergency room with colicky pain in the lower abdomen. He also complains of absolute constipation. After performing a physical examination, an X-ray is ordered. The abdominal X-ray findings are given below:



Which of the following is the preferred treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Colonoscopic detorsion:

  • Given Abdominal X-ray: Coffee bean sign / Omega sign / Bent inner tube suggestive of Sigmoid volvulus.
  • Treatment of sigmoid volvulus:
    • Colonoscopic detorsion
    • After 3 days of sigmoid colectomy (as the risk of recurrence is high)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Barium enema: It is an incorrect option.

Option B - Elective sigmoid colectomy:

  • Elective sigmoid colectomy is done only after the colonoscopy detorsion

Option C - Air enema:

  • Air enema is helpful in intussusception cases but not in the case of volvulus

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents with a complaint of fever and headache that had lasted for 2 days, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The doctor suggests a blood culture, upon which the condition is diagnosed as meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis and treated. 4 months ago, the patient had a similar Neisserial infection. Which of the following complement deficiency can cause the disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: C8

  • It is the case of meningitis which can occur due to the gram-negative encapsulated bacteria known as Meningococcus or Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Meningitis is the inflammation of the protective membrane covering the brain or the spinal cord. Bacterial meningitis is rare but is a more dangerous infection.
  • The complement system and its pathway are essential for the innate immunity of the body. Deficiency in the complements can cause various abnormalities and diseases.
  • C8 has a vital role in forming membrane attack complexes (MAC). The deficiency of this complement increases the chances of recurrent bacterial infections. One of the most prominent includes Neisseria meningitidis.

Option A: C4

  • The deficiency of early components C4 causes SLE and other pyogenic infections. The chances of infection significantly increase with this.
  • C4 is a critical player in innate immunity and immediately eliminates invading pathogens. It also has a role in both the lectin pathway and the classic pathway of the complement system. C4 deficiency constitutes a 75% risk of causing an auto-immune disease.

Option B: C1 esterase inhibitor

  • Inherited deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor causes Hereditary angioneurotic oedema. Hereditary angioedema is an autosomal dominant disorder and is more common in females than males.
  • C1 esterase inhibitor is otherwise in the fluid part of the blood that controls the C1 complement and prevents the spontaneous activation of the complement system.

Option C: Decay accelerating factor (DAF)

  • This protein of the complement system prevents and hinders the activation of the C3 complement, which protects the red blood cells from complement-mediated cell lysis. It also causes the dissolution of the C3 convertase.
  • The deficiency of DAF can cause paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), a rare life-ending disease of the blood.

questions.text: The incubation period is the time elapsed between exposure to a pathogenic organism, a chemical, or radiation, and when symptoms and signs are first apparent. Which among the following gives the correct meaning of the Median Incubation period?

choices.text: Time taken for 50% of cases to occur
Time between primary case and secondary case
Time between onset of infection and period of maximum infectivity
Time interval between onset of disease till its first detection.

questions.solution:
Option A: Time taken for 50% of cases to occur

  • The median incubation period is the time taken for 50% of cases to occur.

Option B: Time between primary case and secondary case

  • The time interval between the primary and secondary case is called the Serial Interval.

Option C: Time between onset of infection and period of maximum infectivity

  • The time interval between the entry of the organism into the body till its maximum infectivity is called the generation time.

Option D: Time interval between onset of disease till its first detection.

  • The time interval between disease initiation to the disease detection is called the Latent period.
  • The Latent period is used in non-communicable diseases.

questions.text: A 26 yrs. old patient presented to ER after five days of alleged ingestion of rodenticide used for pest control at farms. Clinical manifestations seen were abdominal pain and Luminous vomiting followed by a depressed sensorium. Features of acute liver failure including coagulopathy were present. ER doctor confirmed it is a case of Smoky stool syndrome. Smoky stool syndrome is characteristically seen in poisoning with?
questions.solution:
Option D: Phosphorus

  • Smoky stool syndrome is characteristically seen in poisoning with Phosphorus.
  • Clinical manifestations include abdominal pain and Luminous vomiting followed by a depressed sensorium. Features of acute liver failure including coagulopathy were present.

Option A: Iodine

  • Inhalation produces glottic and pulmonary edema. Swallowed in the solid form, it acts as an acid corrosive poison. There is burning pain extending from the mouth to the stomach, intense thirst, salivation, vomiting, purging, giddiness, cramps or convulsive movements of the limbs, and fainting.
  • The urine is scanty or suppressed, red-brown in color, and contains albumen; metabolic acidosis, nephritis, and renal failure occur. Pulse is slow and weak, skin cold and clammy and there may be skin rashes.
  • Chronic Poisoning (Iodism): The symptoms are pain over the frontal sinus, running of the nose, conjunctivitis, bronchial catarrh, salivation, nausea, vomiting, purging, emaciation, lymphadenopathy, parotid swelling (iodide mumps), wasting of breasts, testes, etc. and acne or erythematous patches on the skin, urticaria, etc.
  • Iodine rarely causes poisoning, but cases may occur from overdose and idiosyncrasy. Iodine is converted to an iodide ion in the body. The normal iodide content of the blood is 2 to 5mg./100 ml.

Option B: Bromine

  • Bromine: Non-metallic, inorganic irritants. Bromine causes necrosis of the skin and tissues.
  • Certain people are sensitive to certain drugs and even articles of diet. Iodine, bromine, opium, belladonna, cocaine, aspirin, penicillin, and mercury are common examples of drugs to which many people are allergic.
  • Chronic Bromide poisoning (Bromism): Skin rashes in the form of red papules (Bromine rash), similar to acne vulgaris, which may transform into a pustular lesion/ ulcerate at the hair roots (Bromoderma), on the face, neck, and upper part of the chest.

Option C: Fluorine

  • Fluoride interacts with proteins, particularly enzymes, and usually inhibits enzyme activity at concentrations in the millimolar range
  • Effects of Fluoride toxicity:
    • Acute effects: Nausea, vomiting, Hypocalcemia, Tetany of hand and feet, Hypotension, hypersalivation, Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis, coma and convulsions leading to death
    • Chronic effects: Dental fluorosis, Skeletal fluorosis, Hypersensitivity reactions, Dyspepsia, gastric irritation, insufficiency of renal system, numbness, muscular spasm, birth defects and cancer

questions.text: Which study design is shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cross-over trial:

  • The study design layout involves participants progressing through trial phases, receiving multiple interventions in sequence with a washout period to minimize carryover effects.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Concurrent parallel trial:

  • Two randomly assigned study and control groups are compared. Study subjects remain in the same group (study or control group) for the total duration of the investigation

Option C - Two-by-two factorial design:

  • The subjects are first randomized to treatment arm A or B to address one hypothesis and thereafter within each group, there is further randomization to treatments X or Y for evaluation of the second hypothesis.

Option D - Two-by-two-by-two factorial design:

  • It is an extension of the two-by-two study design in which each subgroup is further randomized into two more groups.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with a mass in the lower abdomen involving the umbilicus and the hypogastrium for 10 days. On examination, it is hard and mobile mass. The examiner cannot insinuate fingers between the mass and the pelvic bone. On radiological investigation, it is a cystic mass. What is the likely diagnosis with this given history?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ovarian cyst

  • It is the correct option.
  • A mass involving the lower abdomen where the fingers cannot be implanted between the mass and pelvic bone implies a mass arising from one of the pelvic structures. The only pelvic mass in question is an ovarian cyst, which is fairly common. Mobile, but the examiner cannot insinuate fingers between the mass & the pelvic bone as it is a pelvic mass.

 

 

  • Features of Ovarian cyst:
  • Usually, ≤ 7 cm in diameter.
  • Usually, asymptomatic.
  • Spontaneous regression occurs.
  • Unilocular.
  • Usually contains clear fluid.
  • Lining epithelium corresponds to the functional epithelium of the unit from which it arises.

 

 

Classification of ovarian masses

Non – neoplastic

Neoplastic
  • A follicular cyst (commonest functional cysts)
  • Corpus luteum cyst
  • Theca lutein & granulosa
  • Lutein cyst.
  • PCOD
  • Endometrial cyst
  • Epithelial tumor
  • Sex cord tumor
  • Germ cell tumor
  • Unclassified
  • Lipid cell tumor
  • Secondaries

 

Option A, B, C: Mesentric cysts, duplication cysts and omental cysts are all abdominal masses and hence fingers can be insinuated between mass and pelvic bone. Mesenteric cyst have only length wise mobility not side-wise

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the paediatrician with complaints of fever and a sharp cough for 1 week. He gives no history of any chronic illnesses. The patient is vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals mild conjunctivitis with some pus. An x-ray chest of the patient was done, which confirmed pneumonia. No organisms are seen on the Gram stain of the pus. What is the most likely causative agent in this case?

choices.text: An obligate intracellular organism unable to make its own ATP
A diplococcus that has a high potential to cause blindness as well as the pneumonia
An organism that has no peptidoglycan or other cell-wall polymer
An obligate intracellular organism with infective vascular endothelium

questions.solution:
Option A: An obligate intracellular organism unable to make its own ATP

  • This is a case of pneumonia along with mild conjunctivitis, most likely due to chlamydia trachomatis, in which the patient presents with complaints of fever and a sharp cough for 1 week.
  • This obligate intracellular organism is unable to make its own ATP.

Predisposing factors for pneumonia:

  • Extremes of age
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
  • Chronic bronchitis
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Congestive heart failure
  • IV drugs users, alcoholics, seizure disorder:

Clinical Manifestations Symptoms:

    • Cough with sputum
    • Fever with chills
    • Chest pain
    • Shortness of Breath
    • Rusty sputum
    • Currant Jelly sputum

Option B: A diplococcus that has a high potential to cause blindness as well as the pneumonia

  • A diplococcus that has a high potential to cause blindness, as well as pneumonia, is most like Gonococcus.
  • It should have been eliminated on Gram stain, and most would have been intracellular but not in phagosomes.

Option C: An organism that has no peptidoglycan or other cell-wall polymer

  •  An organism that has no peptidoglycan or other cell-wall polymer is most likely mycoplasma, which is not intracellular and rarely causes pneumonia in neonates.

Option D: An obligate intracellular organism with infective vascular endothelium

  • An obligate intracellular organism with infective vascular endothelium would be Rickettsia, which is both unlikely and not a good fit for the disease.

questions.text: A 7 Yr old girl child with a known case of Non-Hodgkins lymphoma on Cyclophosphamide now presents with sudden onset fever and petechiae. Bone marrow examination revealed Hypercellular Lymphoblastic cells. Which of the following Lymphoid malignancy described here arise from thymic cells?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pre – T cell ALL

  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia/lymphomas (ALLs) are neoplasms composed of immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells, which are referred to as lymphoblasts.
  • About 85% are B-ALLs, which typically manifest as childhood acute "leukaemias."
  • The less common T-ALLs tend to present in adolescent males as thymic “lymphomas.”
  • ACUTE LYMPHOBLASTIC LEUKEMIA:
    • The most frequent type of leukaemia in children.
    • Usually presents with sudden onset of Fatigue/fever/petechiae with Hepatosplenomegaly, Lymphadenopathy, and Sternal Tenderness (+).
  • DIAGNOSIS:
    • Bone marrow examination (IOC)
    • Blood investigations
    • Immunophenotyping.

Option A: Hairy cell leukaemia

  • In a particular kind of malignancy known as hairy cell leukaemia, the bone marrow overproduces lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). Cancer of the blood and bone marrow, hairy cell leukaemia.
  • Signs and symptoms of hairy cell leukaemia include infections, tiredness, and pain below the ribs:
    • Weakness or feeling tired.
    • Frequent infections.
    • Easy bruising or bleeding.
    • Shortness of breath.
  • In hairy cell leukaemia, a CBC test may show all levels of these cells are too low. Another type of blood test might involve looking at your blood under the microscope.
  • Treatment options for hairy cell leukaemia include the following:
    • Watchful waiting, if feasible.
    • Rituximab.
    • Vemurafenib

Option B: Burkitt lymphoma

  • A rare, fast-growing type of leukaemia (blood cancer) in which too many white blood cells called B lymphocytes form in the blood and bone marrow.
  • Symptoms of Burkitt's lymphoma include:
    • Swollen lymph nodes in the neck, armpit, or groin.
    • Fever.
    • Night sweats.
    • Nausea.
  • Diagnoses of Burkitt's lymphoma and Burkitt's leukaemia may involve biopsies and imaging tests, such as CT scans or MRI scans.
  • The central nervous system form of Burkitt's lymphoma may be treated with intrathecal chemotherapy. The fluid between the membranes of the spinal cord and the brain is where doctors inject this treatment.

Option C: Pre – B cell ALL

  • Pre-B cell ALL is the most common type of leukaemia to present with renal infiltration as the presenting sign.
  • Symptoms include:
    • Bone or joint pain
    • Limping
    • Fever
    • Pale skin
    • Red or purple spots called petechiae on the skin
  • In the early stages of development in the bone marrow, B-lymphocytes are where ALL develops in 75–80% of adult cases. Therefore, the condition is known as precursor B-cell ALL or Pre-B-cell ALL.
  • Immunotherapy (monoclonal antibodies or CAR T-cell treatment) may be possible for patients with B-cell ALL.

questions.text: Iran has returned the body of the 35-year-old man who was executed on charges of drug trafficking. The body has been embalmed prior to repatriation. Although it is usually still possible to identify the presence of drugs, the constituent chemicals in embalming fluids affect not only the detection but also the rate of decay of the majority of both pharmaceutical and illicit drugs in blood and many other bodily tissues, making forensic evidence unsafe and, therefore, usually inadmissible in courts of law. Which tissue sample will the forensic team prefer in this case for toxicological analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Skeletal muscle:

  • In the embalmed body the best specimen may be skeletal muscle from the buttock.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bile: It is best removed by puncturing the gall bladder in situ. Narcotic drugs, cocaine, methadone, glutathione, barbiturates and some tranquilisers.

Option B - Vitreous: Alcohol, chloroform, cocaine, morphine, tricyclic antidepressants.

Option C - Spinal cord: Spinal cord entire length: strychnine and gelsemium.

questions.text: A 30-month-old deaf boy whose development is slower than normal is being followed for congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in your clinic. The child's mother is pregnant again and is worried about her new baby. Which of the following is advisory information to be given to the patient?

choices.text: The mother has antibodies to CMV that is passed to the fetus
The mother’s infection cannot become reactivated
The new infant should be isolated from the older child

questions.solution:
Option A: The mother has antibodies to CMV that are passed to the fetus

  • In case of reactivation of CMV infection during pregnancy, maternal IgG antibodies pass transplacentally and protect the baby against infection.

Option B: The mother's infection cannot become reactivated

  • The mother's infection can be reactivated during secondary pregnancy.

  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Termination of pregnancy is advised

  • Termination of pregnancy is not advised because most infants infected during this secondary maternal infection are asymptomatic, but about 10% of them eventually manifest hearing and neurologic problems.

  • The symptomatic congenital disease usually occurs when the mother has a primary CMV infection in the first trimester of pregnancy. Many of these babies die, and those who survive are severely affected.

Option D: The new infant should be isolated from the older child

  • Some recommend keeping a child with congenital CMV infection away from susceptible pregnant women because CMV excretion can persist for months to years.

  • If infected shortly after birth, the younger sibling will probably be asymptomatic since he or she has maternal IgG antibodies in circulation

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman has been brought in for admission in a semiconscious state. She was found by her roommate in her hostel room with some bottles of alcohol and some drugs by her side. On observation, the patient's hands were seen moving in a pill-rolling pattern. Occasionally she was also threading imaginary needles.This is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Datura poisoning:

  • Carphologia is seen in Datura poisoning.
  • Typical pill-rolling movements, Patients hallucinate imaginary needles and threads
  • Other signs and symptoms: Dry mouth, irrelevant slurred speech, dry and hot skin, dilated pupils.
  • Treatment: Physostigmine is the drug of choice.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Digitalis poisoning:

  • Toxic symptoms are due to overdose or by a cumulative action.
  • In Digitalis poisoning: Nausea, vomiting, pain in the abdomen, burning sensation, diarrhea, Bradycardia, CNS Headache, fatigue, confusion, anxiety, depression, disorientation, drowsiness, hallucinations, delirium, Transient amblyopia, blurring, photophobia, Urticaria can be seen.
  • The patient becomes drowsy and the condition may deepen into coma. Convulsions may precede death. Death occurs from cardiovascular collapse

Option C - LSD overdose:

  • Signs and symptoms (Acute intoxication) of LSD:
    • Somatic or physical: Dizziness, dilated pupils, nausea, flushing, hyperthermia, paresthesia, hyperactive reflexes and tremors.
    • Perceptual: Altered changes in vision and hearing, like floating feeling, illusions, sensation of synesthesia, i.e., 'seeing' smells and 'hearing' colors.
    • Psychic or changes in sensorium: Delusional ideation, body distortion, suspiciousness to the point of toxic psychosis, depersonalization, and loss of sense of time.

Option D - Alcohol withdrawal:

  • Tremulousness or shakes or jitters (most common sign), weakness, pain in the muscle, cold sweat, insomnia, loss of appetite, vomiting, diarrhea, restlessness, exaggerated reflexes, raised temperature, fluctuating BP, hallucinations, loss of memory, and delirium tremens.

questions.text: A healthcare delivery system is an organization of people, institutions, and resources to deliver healthcare services to meet the health needs of a target population. Three – Tier system of Health care delivery in rural areas in India is based on the recommendations of which of the following committee?
questions.solution:
Option C: Balwant Rai Mehta committee

  • Balwant Rai Mehta Committee: Recommended 3-tier rural Health infrastructure "Panchayat - Panchayat samiti - Zilla Parishad".

Option A: Bhore committee

  • Bhore Committee (1946Q): Also known as ‘Health Survey and Development Committee.
  • Prepare Social Physicians: (3 months of training in preventive and social medicine in medical education).

Option B: Chadha Committee

  • Constituted to study arrangements necessary for the ‘Maintenance Phase of the National Malaria Eradication Programmme (NMEP).
  • 1 Basic Health Worker per 10,000 population (for malaria vigilance, collection of vital statistics, and family planning).
  • Family Planning Health Assistants to supervise 3-4 basic health workers.

Option D: Mudalair committee

  • It is also known as ‘Health Survey and Planning Committee.
  • 1 PHC per 40,000 population maximum.
  • Constitution of ‘All India Health Service’.
  • Strengthen district hospitals with specialist services.
  • Regional organizations in each state.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presents with a 6-day history of a painful sore on his left hand. Physical examination reveals a 0.6-cm abscess on the extensor surface of the left hand that drains a thick, purulent material. Diapedesis of leukocytes into and around this patient's infected wound occurs primarily at which of the following given anatomic locations?
questions.solution:
Option B: Post-capillary venules

  • The leukocyte migration through the vessel wall occurs through the post-capillary venules.

Leukocyte migration:

  • The process of leukocyte recruitment is the migration of the leukocytes through intact endothelium, called transmigration or diapedesis.
  • Transmigration of leukocytes occurs mainly in post-capillary venules.
  • Chemokines act on the adherent leukocytes and stimulate the cells to migrate through interendothelial gaps toward the chemical concentration gradient, that is, toward the site of injury or infection where the chemokines are being produced.
  • Several adhesion molecules in the intercellular junctions between endothelial cells are involved in the migration of leukocytes.
  • These molecules include a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily called CD31 or PECAM-1 (platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule).
