  • After traversing the endothelium, leukocytes pierce the basement membrane, probably by secreting collagenases and enter the extravascular space.
  • After leukocytes pass through, the basement membranes become continuous again.
  • The cells that have exited the vessel then migrate toward the chemotactic gradient created by chemokines and other chemoattractants and accumulate in the extravascular site.
  • The most telling proof of the importance of leukocyte adhesion molecules in the host inflammatory response is genetic deficiencies in these molecules, which result in increased susceptibility to bacterial infections

Option A: Lymphatic capillaries

  • The lymphatic capillaries return the excessive fluid leak out of vessels.
  • This prevents oedema formation.

Option C: Precapillary arterioles

  • The precapillary arterioles are intact during the inflammation.
  • There is no leukocyte diapedesis through this area.

Option D: Small dermal arteries

  • The arteries are not involved during the diapedesis.
  • Venules contain significant gaps that aid in migrating leukocytes out of vessels.

questions.text: From where does the posterior superior alveolar artery, which supplies upper premolar and molar teeth along with the maxillary sinus, originate?

choices.text: Nasal branch of the maxillary artery
Pterygopalatine part of the maxillary artery

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pterygopalatine part of the maxillary artery:

  • The posterior superior alveolar artery arises from the pterygopalatine part (3rd part) of the maxillary artery just before it enters the pterygomaxillary fissure.
  • The posterior superior alveolar artery supplies the upper premolar and molar teeth, as well as the maxillary sinus
  • The maxillary artery is divided into 3 parts in relation to the lateral pterygoid muscle. Each part leads to its specific branches:
    • Branches of the 1st (mandibular) part: Deep auricular artery, Anterior tympanic artery, Middle meningeal artery, Accessory meningeal artery, inferior alveolar artery.
    • Branches of the 2nd (pterygoid) part: Deep temporal artery, Lateral pterygoid artery, Medial pterygoid artery, Masseteric artery, Buccal artery.
    • Branches of the 3rd (pterygopalatine) part: Artery of pterygoid canal, Pharyngeal artery, Greater palatine artery, Posterior superior alveolar artery, Sphenopalatine artery, Infraorbital artery

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nasal branch of the maxillary artery:

  • The sphenopalatine artery is a branch of 3rd part of the maxillary artery.
  • The sphenopalatine artery terminates into
    • Posterior lateral nasal artery
    • Posterior septal branches
  • The sphenopalatine artery is mostly responsible for severe epistaxis

Option C - Mandibular artery:

  • The mandibular artery arises from the maxillary artery in relation to the lateral pterygoid muscle.

Option D - Inferior alveolar artery:

  • The inferior alveolar artery is a branch of the first (mandibular) part of maxillary artery.
  • The inferior alveolar artery supplies the lower teeth.

questions.text:
In the graph below, Curve A is obtained for liver glucokinase, while Curve B is for muscle glucokinase under similar conditions.

 



Which is the correct statement regarding the relationship between these enzymes?

choices.text: A is the same enzyme as B but in the presence of a competitive inhibitor
B has a greater affinity for glucose than A.
At maximal substrate concentrations, both enzymes display first-order kinetics.
B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than A.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than A:

  • B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than A.
  • Km is determined from substrate concentration at half of enzyme's Vmax.

  • The graph indicates B's higher Km as it has higher Vmax compared to A.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A is the same enzyme as B but in the presence of a competitive inhibitor:

  • A is the same enzyme as B but with a competitive inhibitor. If so, both would have equal Vmax, contrary to the graph.

Option B - B has a greater affinity for glucose than A:

  • B has greater glucose affinity than A. Affinity relates to lower Km; hence, A's lower Km implies higher affinity for glucose.

Option C - At maximal substrate concentrations, both enzymes display first-order kinetics:

  • Both enzymes display first-order kinetics at maximal substrate concentrations. Yet, at this point, enzyme binding sites are saturated, suggesting zero-order kinetics, not first-order.

questions.text: The rationale for adding dextrose in spinal anaesthesia is to:

choices.text: Reduce plasma levels of local anesthetic to prevent toxicity

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Increase specific gravity:

  • The rationale for adding dextrose to Bupivacaine is to increase specific gravity.
  • Baricity is defined as the ratio of the density of the local anaesthetic to the density of CSF.
  • The significance of baricity is actually the ability to influence the distribution of local anaesthetic spread based on gravity.
  • Adding dextrose makes local anaesthetic hyperbaric and prevents uncontrolled ascending of local anaesthetics because of the more predictable spread and less interpatient variability.
  • The local anaesthetic solutions are made hyperbaric by the addition of glucose or hypobaric by the addition of sterile water.
  • A hyperbaric solution of local anaesthetic is denser (heavier) than CSF, whereas a hypobaric solution is less dense (lighter) than CSF.
  • Hyperbaric solutions tend to move to the most dependent area of the spine. With the patient in a head-down position, a hyperbaric solution spreads cephalad, and a hypobaric anaesthetic solution moves caudally.
  • A head-up position causes a hyperbaric solution to settle caudally and a hypobaric solution to ascend cephalad.
  • An isobaric solution tends to remain at the level of injection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increase the duration of action:

  • By adding dextrose, make local anaesthetic hyperbaric and prevent uncontrolled ascending of local anaesthetics.
  • It will not increase the duration of action.

Option B - Reduce plasma levels of a local anaesthetic to prevent toxicity:

  • Adding 8% dextrose in Bupivacaine 0.5% will increase the specific gravity of the solution and make it hyperbaric.
  • It will not reduce the plasma level of the local anaesthetic.

Option D - Make the drug Hypobaric:

  • The local anaesthetic solutions are made hyperbaric by the addition of glucose or hypobaric by the addition of sterile water.
  • Adding 8% dextrose in Bupivacaine 0.5% will make the solution hyperbaric

questions.text: A 7-year-old female child was brought with complaints of abdominal distension with a history of intermittent fever, recurrent lung infections, difficulty in walking in the form of repeated falls, difficulty in coordinating movements, an inability to move the eyes vertically, poor muscle tone, severe liver disease, and interstitial lung disease and multiple episodes of tonic-clonic seizures since last 1 year. She also had a younger sibling having similar complaints of abdominal distension and developmental delay. On examination, the patient had hepatosplenomegaly, a global developmental delay with mild mental retardation. A bone marrow examination was done, which showed characteristic lipid-laden foam cells. Lysosomal enzyme studies confirmed the Deficiency of an enzyme. Identify which of the following is responsible for the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acid Sphingomyelinase

The given clinical features and diagnostic tests confirm the diagnosis of Niemann pick disease.

Deficient enzyme

Disease

Acid Sphingomyelinase

Niemann pick disease

Hexosaminidase A

Tay-sachs disease

Ceramidase

Farber disease

Arylsulfatase B

Maroteaux – Lamy syndrome
  • Niemann-Pick disease is an inherited disease that affects lipid metabolism.
  • It is divided into four main types: type A, type B, type C1, and type C2
  • Types A and B occur when acid sphingomyelinase (ASM) isn’t properly produced in the white blood cells. ASM is an enzyme that helps remove fats in all the cells of your body.
  • Sphingomyelin, the fat that ASM removes, can build up in your cells when ASM isn't properly breaking it down. When sphingomyelin builds up, cells begin to die, and organs stop functioning correctly.
  • Individuals with Niemann-Pick disease types C1 and C2 have problems with speech and swallowing difficulties that worsen over time. Affected individuals often experience a progressive decline in intellectual function, and about one-third have seizures. People with these types may survive into adulthood.

Option B: Hexosaminidase

  • Tay–Sachs Disease is caused by a deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A, which leads to a build-up of GM2 ganglioside within cells. Notably, the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside leads to the destruction of nerve cells. Signs and symptoms include neurodegeneration, developmental delay, and the appearance of onion-skin lysosomes on EM biopsy.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option C: Ceramidase

  • Acid ceramidase deficiency is a spectrum of disorders that includes a rare lysosomal storage disorder called Farber disease and a rare epileptic disorder called spinal muscular atrophy with progressive myoclonic epilepsy.

Option D: Arylsulfatase B

  • A deficiency of arylsulfatase B is associated with skeletal and growth malformations, termed the Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome. The characteristic skeletal dysplasia includes short stature, dysostosis multiplex and degenerative joint disease. Other clinical findings may include cardiac valve disease, reduced pulmonary function, hepatosplenomegaly, sinusitis, otitis media, hearing loss, sleep apnea, corneal clouding, carpal tunnel disease, and inguinal or umbilical hernia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old African-American woman presented with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, and icterus for 3 weeks. On history taking, she was found to be an IV drug user. On molecular examination of the sample, a single-stranded enveloped RNA virus was found to be the causative agent. Which of the following statements is associated with the given condition?

choices.text: Hepatitis B is the causative agent
The most common indication for liver transplant
Does not cause co-infection with Hepatitis B

questions.solution:
Option B: The most common indication for liver transplant

Hepatitis C Virus

  • HCV (Hepatitis C Virus) is a single-stranded enveloped RNA virus, and it’s the most likely causative agent in this scenario.
  • HCV belongs to the family Flaviviridae.
  • HCV infection is seen only in humans.
  • Incubation Period: 15-160 days, with a mean of 50 days.

Clinical Presentation

  • It may present with fever, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, loss of appetite, yellowish discolouration of skin and sclera, dark coloured urine.
  • About 20% of people develop acute hepatitis. Acute illness is mild and anicteric.
  • About 75-80% directly develop the chronic disease; out of which:
    • 60-70% develop Chronic hepatitis.
    • 5-20% develop Cirrhosis.
    • 1-5% develop Hepatocellular Carcinoma. (HCV accounts for 25% of total liver cancer patients.)

Transmission

  • Infection is mainly by blood transfusion and other modes of contact with blood and blood products.
  • IV Drug abusers, transplant recipients, and immunocompromised patients are at high risk.
  • It can also spread via sexual contact.
  • Infection may spread from mother to baby. (Vertical transmission)

Laboratory Diagnosis

  • The standard method of identification is Antibody Detection via ELISA
  • PCR for HCV RNA is the most specific and sensitive.

Prophylaxis

  • There’s no vaccine available.
  • It can be prevented generally by avoiding the usage of used IV needles and direct contact with blood or blood products.

Treatment

  • Interferon alpha, alone or in combination with antiviral like Ribavirin.

Indications for Liver Transplant

  • Any metabolic diseases or infection that leads to acute or chronic liver failure and hepatic malignancies are the indications for a liver transplant.
  • The most common indication for liver transplantation is Cirrhosis due to chronic Hepatitis C infection.

Option A: Hepatitis B is the causative agent

  • Hepatitis B is the only DNA virus among Hepatitis viruses.
  • Hence it cannot be the causative agent.
  • Hepatitis C is an RNA-enveloped virus.

Option C: Does not cause liver cancer

  • 1-5% of patients infected with HCV develop Hepatocellular Carcinoma. (HCV accounts for 25% of total liver cancer patients).
  • HCV is one of the most important causative factors for hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option D: Does not cause co-infection with Hepatitis B

  • HCV may cause co-infection with HBV and co-infection with HCV.
  • HBV increases the rate of development of Cirrhosis and the risk of HCC compared with infection with either virus alone.

questions.text: A 22-year-old boxer was brought to the Emergency department by an ambulance. He had a boxing match prior to his arrival. The attending physician did a thorough physical checkup and suspected an orbital floor fracture. He immediately ordered an X-ray of the orbital floor. What is the most appropriate view of X-ray for this patient?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Water’s view

  • An angled posteroanterior radiograph of the skull with the patient looking slightly upwards is known as the occipitomental (OM) or Waters view.

  • In addition to acute sinusitis, it can be used to check for facial fractures.

  • It is the view of choice for visualizing fractures of the orbital floor.

Option B: Caldwell’s view


  • Caldwell's view is a caudally angled radiograph, and its posteroanterior projection exposes the orbits to the least amount of radiation possible.

  • The paranasal sinuses, particularly the frontal sinus, are easier to visualize at this angle.

  • Assessing four inflammatory disorders, including sinusitis, secondary osteomyelitis, and sinus polyps or cysts might be helpful.

  • This view also enables the identification of superior orbital fissure fractures.

Option C: Rhese view

  • The optic canal can be visualized by using the Rhese view of the X-ray.

  • In this view, the patient is positioned with the orbit to be studied such that the cassette should be touched by the zygoma, nose, and chin.

Option D: Towne view

  • The Towne view is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull that shows the posterior clinoid processes, the dorsum sellae, and the petrous section of the pyramids, which are all visible in the foramen magnum's shadow.

  • This projection is utilized to assess for Paget disease, neoplastic alterations, and medial and lateral displacements of skull fractures.

  • The inferior orbital fissure of the orbit can also be visualized via this view.

questions.text: A 66-year-old male presented to the local hospital with complaints of urinary retention with severe pain and burning sensation in the lower urinary tract since yesterday. He also has a poor urinary stream, nocturia, and post-void dribbling. The vital signs and Laboratory tests were normal. On digital rectal examination, there is a palpable, hard, nodular prostate with an obliterated median sulcus. Ultrasound reports showed an enlarged prostate of weight 93 grams. His ratio of free: total PSA is estimated as 20%. The ultrasound of this patient is given below. What diagnosis does the doctor suspect in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Benign prostatic hyperplasia:

It is a suspected case of benign prostatic hyperplasia due to urinary symptoms such as urinary retention, poor urinary stream, nocturia, and postvoid dribbling in the old male.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is a benign enlargement of the prostate that occurs after 50 years, usually between 60 and 70 years. BPH affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma. 
It is involuntary hyperplasia due to disturbance of the ratio and quantity of circulating androgens and estrogens.

•On digital rectal examination, a palpable prostate with smooth muscle hypertrophy is the typical finding of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

•The free: total prostate-specific antigen ratio discriminates between prostate carcinoma and benign prostate hyperplasia. If it is < 18%, it is suggestive of carcinoma; if it is > 18 %, it suggests benign prostate hyperplasia, as it is 20% in this patient, indicating benign prostate hyperplasia.       

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tuberculous prostate:

  • As there is no history and symptoms of tuberculosis, this disease does not correlate with the patient's condition.
  • It is diagnosed by urine examination for ZN staining and culture of tubercle bacilli from the first morning urine sample. 

Option C - Acute prostatitis:

  • It is the inflammation of the prostate due to any lower abdominal trauma or secondary to urinary tract infection.
  • On palpation, there is a warm and tender prostate. Leukocytosis is the typical lab finding.

Option D - Carcinoma of the prostate:

  • The free: total ratio of PSA is the differentiating point between carcinoma and benign prostate hyperplasia.
  • If it is > 18%, it is suggestive of benign prostate hyperplasia as this patient has a 20% ratio, so it excludes carcinoma of the prostate.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with hematuria. A renal biopsy demonstrates focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis with crescent formation. The patient gives a history of intermittent hemoptysis and intermittent chest pain of moderate intensity. A previous chest X-ray had demonstrated 90 multiple opacities, some of which were capitated. The patient also has chronic cold-like nasal symptoms, joint pain, fatigue, weight loss, skin sores, and blood in the urine. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Wegner's granulomatosis

  • The patient has the involvement in the following:
  • Upper respiratory tract: chronic cold symptoms suggestive of sinusitis
  • Lower respiratory tract: intermittent hemoptysis due to bilateral lung cavitation.
  • Kidney involvement: Hematuria with necrotizing vasculitis.
  • Therefore, the diagnosis favors granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's Granulomatosis).
  • It is a vascular necrotizing vasculitis and is granulomatosis with polyangiitis.
  • It involves:
    • A: upper respiratory tract (sinusitis, crusting rhinitis, saddle nose deformity),
    • B lower respiratory tract (lung nodules, alveolar hemorrhage) and
    • C kidney involvement (glomerulonephritis).
  • Diagnosis
    • For diagnosis, c-ANCA will be helpful, along with biopsy findings of vasculitis.
    • The cytoplasmic immunofluorescence pattern (c-ANCOPTION A: is caused by PR3-ANCA and has a high specificity of>90% for granulomatosis with angiitis.

Option A: Aspergillosis

  • It is an infection caused by a type of mould (fungus)
  • It usually affects the Respiratory system and leads to shortness of breath, fatigue and coughing up blood
  • Involve lungs in invasive aspergilloma, but multiple cavity formation is not seen, and neither is glomerulonephritis, as in this case.
  • Symptoms include chills and a fever
      • Hemoptysis
      • breathing difficulty
      • joint or chest ache
      • Eye issues or headaches
      • Skin lesions

Option B: Polyarteritis Nodosa

  • It is a disorder that causes damage to small and medium-sized arteries.
  • Such as those supplying the skeletal muscles, neurological system, heart, kidneys, and gut.
  • This may result in hypertension, aneurysm of an arterial wall, thrombosis, and necrosis in certain affected areas.
  • They were ruled out as lung and pulmonary artery involvement is not seen in this option.
  • It is unknown what specifically causes polyarteritis nodosa.
  • The majority of patients have no known predisposing factors. Unknown viral or bacterial infections could be the reason. Drug abusers, particularly those who use amphetamines, and hepatitis B patients have been shown to have polyarteritis nodosa.
  • An allergic response to certain medications and immunizations has also been connected to this condition.

Option C: Renal cell carcinoma metastatic to the lung

  • RCC metastasizes most frequently to the lungs.
  • In such cases, the most common manifestation is solitary or multiple lung nodules.
  • Ruled out since it is mentioned that renal biopsy shows segmental necrotizing glomerulonephritis and no presence of lung nodules is indicated.
  • Pleural effusions are a symptom of advanced renal cell carcinomas.
  • Pulmonary emboli are a symptom of RCC because of a hypercoagulable condition.
  • RCC's highly vascularized nature in metastatic foci may result in arteriovenous fistulas.
  • Additionally, paraneoplastic symptoms, including cough and diaphragm paralysis, might be a symptom of RCC.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with pre-existing seropositive rheumatoid arthritis presents in the emergency department with complaints of progressive difficulty in breathing. He works as a crane operator near a construction site. On examination, joint findings were consistent with chronic rheumatoid arthritis, and Rheumatoid nodules were appreciated. Hence, a chest X-ray was performed, which is shown below. What is your most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Caplan syndrome

  • There are many manifestations of respiratory illnesses in patients diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), and a variety of respiratory problems may be seen. 
  • Pulmonary fibrosis, pleural effusion, pulmonary nodules, bronchiolitis obliterans, complications of drug therapy, infections (possibly atypical) secondary to immunosuppression.
  • Caplan's syndrome is diagnosed as massive fibrotic nodules with occupational coal dust exposure in RA patients. 
  • CXR of this patient is suggestive of – Pneumoconiosis, and on examination, Rheumatoid nodules are also present, which points to the diagnosis of Caplan syndrome.
  • Caplan syndrome: Coal worker pneumoconiosis + Rheumatoid nodules.

Other options

Option B: Felty’s syndrome

  • There are many systemic complications of RA, and Felty's syndrome is a rare complication comprising (RA + splenomegaly + low white cell count).

Option C: Bronchiolitis obliterans

  • Bronchiolitis obliterans is obliterative bronchiolitis that constricts the smallest airways of the lung (bronchioles) because of continuous inflammation. It is also known as popcorn lung disease because of the patchy involvement of the lung.
  • It can present with dry cough, shortness of breath, and wheezing.

Option D: Lung cancer

  • Lung Cancer presents with mass effects and different symptoms than in the scenario mentioned above.
  • The sign and symptoms in patients with lung cancer include: hemoptysis, dyspnoea, chest pain, weight loss and anorexia, hoarseness
    • It can be seen with Pancoast tumours pressing the recurrent laryngeal nerve
    • superior vena cava syndrome
    • On the radiograph, Lung cancer will be appreciated as a mass, excluding the small cell lung cancers, which are very small to be appreciated on the chest X-ray.

questions.text: What would you warn the patient about before starting carbamazepine in the case of trigeminal neuralgia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hyponatremia:

  • Carbamazepine increases antidiuretic hormone (ADH) levels.
  • Elevated ADH activity leads to increased expression of aquaporin 2 channels in renal tubules.
  • Increased ADH causes water retention by the kidneys, diluting serum sodium concentration.
  • Carbamazepine predisposes individuals to hyponatremia.
  • Used as the drug of choice (DOC) for focal seizures and trigeminal neuralgia.
  • Adverse effects include release of ADH (leading to dilutional hyponatremia), especially in the elderly, agranulocytosis, and aplastic anemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hypokalemia:

  • Carbamazepine causes the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH), which leads to low sodium, not low potassium.

Option C - Hyperkalemia:

  • Beta-blocker overdose can cause hyperkalemia by inhibiting potassium entry into cells.
  • Carbamazepine does not cause hyperkalemia

Option D - Hypernatremia:

  • Carbamazepine causes the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), which leads to hyponatremia, not hypernatremia.

questions.text: Eight years old male came to the hospital with complaints of frequent nose bleeding and difficulty breathing through the nose. On M.R.I. investigation, the below image is depicted. A biopsy of the mass is done, and the histopathological examination depicts that the mass is found to be arising from the olfactory epithelium. Which of the following classification is useful for the above diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Kadish Classification

  • The above-given case is the diagnosis of olfactory neuroblastoma.
  • Aka Esthesio-neuroblastoma.
  • Also called an olfactory placode, a tumour arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of the nose. Bimodal incidence peaks at 10–20 and 50–60 years are seen. The most common symptoms are unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis. Other symptoms like proptosis, headache, epiphora, diplopia, and blurred vision can also arise when a tumour invades orbit and the surrounding structures. Lymph node metastases in the neck can occur in 10–15%.
  • Rare.
  • Arises from the olfactory epithelium.
  • Most common  site: Roof of the nasal cavity.
  • Histology shows neurofibrillary stroma and neurosecretory granule.
  • Kadish classification is used for staging the olfactory neuroblastoma
    • Initially proposed by Morita et al. (1993) – Kadish A: tumour confined to nasal cavity.
    • Kadish B: tumour involves the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses.
    • Kadish C: tumour spread beyond nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses, including involvement of the cribriform plate, base of the skull, orbit, or intracranial cavity.
    • Kadish D: tumour with metastasis to cervical lymph nodes or distant sites.
  • Treatment
    • Endoscopic excision followed by radiotherapy.

Option A: Enneking Classification

  • The Enneking surgical staging system is based on tumour grade, local spread and metastatic disease of malignant musculoskeletal tumours and also for benign bone tumours, not for olfactory epithelium nasal cavity tumours.

Option C: Dingman Classification

  • Dingman classification for Fractures of the mandible. Condylar fractures are the most common, followed by the Angle, Body and Symphysis of the mandible. Remember CABS.

Option D: Ohngren's Classification

  • Ohngren's Classification is for maxillary carcinoma.
    • Ohngren's Classification: An imaginary plane is drawn, extending between the eye's medial canthus and the mandible's angle. Growths above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it (infrastructural).

questions.text: A few Doctors Without Borders physicians on a 6-month African village posting encounter a pale foreigner complaining of extreme fatigue since arrival. He's a diabetic on insulin with controlled bronchial asthma. Despite malaria prophylaxis, he struggles with food adjustment and erratic blood glucose. If suspecting a pharmacogenetic condition, what might explain his current state?
questions.solution:
Option D: Primaquine-induced hemolytic anemia

Pharmacogenetics:

  • Pharmacogenetics deals with genetic variation in the expression of enzymes that metabolize drugs.
  • These genetic differences can cause a drug response to deviate from the expected response and increase the risk of side effects.
  • If the enzyme in question is responsible for the breakdown of a drug, the following effects are possible:
    • A hyperactive variant of the enzyme decreases the drug response.
    • A hypoactive variant of the enzyme can cause cumulative drug effects and thus increase the risk of side effects.
  • The reverse is true if the enzyme is responsible for the activation of a drug. E.g. CYP2D6 polymorphism 
    • There are hyperactive and hypoactive variants.
    • CYP2D6 is involved in the metabolism of many drugs (e.g., the breakdown of antiarrhythmics and tricyclic antidepressants; the activation of codeine).
    • Gender-specific differences in CYP2D6 have been observed (e.g., CYP2D6-mediated breakdown of beta-blockers (such as metoprolol) is greater among women).
  • Primaquine is an oxidant drug. It can cause hemolytic anemia in subjects having a deficiency of the G6PD enzyme.
  • This condition is genetically determined.

Option A: Hypoglycemia by insulin

  • Hypoglycemia due to insulin can occur due to the following conditions:
  • Insulin excess
    • Accidental overdose of insulin or noninsulin drugs (e.g., sulfonylureas, meglitinides)
    • Wrongly timed medication
    • Drug interactions
    • Factitious disorder
  • Increased sensitivity to insulin
    • Weight loss
    • Increase in activity/exercise
  • Decreased insulin clearance
    • Renal failure
  • Hypoglycemia is unlikely to cause chronic fatigue and pallor.
     

Option B: Tachycardia by salbutamol

  • Tachycardia by albuterol is the dose-dependent adverse effect of Albuterol and can happen in any individual.
  • It is unlikely to cause pallor and fatigue

Option C: Metoclopramide-induced muscle dystonia

  • Metoclopramide is a D2 receptor antagonist and increases the resting tone, contractility, lower esophageal sphincter tone, and motility and promotes gastric emptying.
  • It is used in diabetic and postoperative gastroparesis as an antiemetic and persistent GERD.
  • Metoclopramide disrupts central dopaminergic signaling. Thus it may produce rare movement disorders, such as acute dystonic reactions.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presented to medical OPD with low-grade fever, fatigue and unexplained weight loss for the last six months. On examination, an enlarged supraclavicular lymph node was palpated. The image depicts the histology of her lymph node biopsy. The tumour cells express B cell antigens and are Epstein-Barr virus-positive (EBV). The patient is HIV positive and is on antiviral medication. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Large B-Cell Lymphoma

  • The patient presented with an enlarged supraclavicular lymph node and unexplained weight loss. She is also HIV and EBV positive, and histology shows large neoplastic cells with round nuclei and prominent nucleoli, including giant tumour cells. All of these factors favour the diagnosis of diffuse large-cell B-cell lymphoma.
  • Most lymphomas in patients with AIDS are high-grade B-cell lymphomas, including Burkitt lymphoma and diffuse large-cell B-cell lymphoma.
  • Diffuse Large B- Cell Lymphomas are commonly EBV-positive and associated with immunodeficiency.
  • The median age of presentation is 60 years, but it can occur in any age group.
  • It is also seen in AIDS with HHV-8.
  • Its histology depicts large B cells (3 to 4 times the normal size) with Round nuclei with prominent nucleoli and dispersed chromatin, a relatively small amount of pale cytoplasm, a multilobular vesicular nucleus in some cases and occasionally tumour giant cells similar to Reed Sternberg cells.
  • It is Positive for CD20, CD79a, and CD15 negative, and background cells are predominantly T cells.
  • 30% of cases have BCL2 protein overproduction resulting from (14;18) translocation.
  • It is fatal if not treated in time.

Option A: Follicular Lymphoma

  • It is usually present in the adult population as painless generalised lymphadenopathy.
  • Its histology shows distinct nodular proliferation with numerous large centrocytes having angular 'cleaved' nuclei with rare mitosis and apoptosis.

Option B: Hodgkin Lymphoma

  • It is characterised by the presence of Reed Sternberg cell, classically having two mirror-image nuclei giving owl eyes appearance.
  • It is not associated with AIDs and EBV.

Option D: Mantle Cell Lymphoma

  • Its cell resembles the naïve B cells found in the mantle zone.
  • It involves lymph nodes in a diffuse/ vague manner.
  • Tumour cells are only slightly larger than normal cells.

questions.text: In a population of 1000, there are 200 eligible couples. Among the eligible couples, 30 use condoms, 20 use IUCD, 20 use OC pills and 70 have undergone female sterilization. The rest of the couples do not use any method. Calculate the Couple protection rate.
questions.solution:
Option D: 70%

  • Values given are:
    • Total eligible couples = 200
    • Eligible couples protected by any of the approved methods = 30+20+20+70 =140
  • Couple protection rate (CPR) = Total number of eligible couples protected by any of the approved methods / Total number of eligible couples in the community × 100
  • CPR =140/200 X 100= 70%

Therefore, other options (A, B, and D) can be ruled out.

questions.text: Expressed breast milk should be stored under which of the following conditions?

choices.text: EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 6 hours and 24 hours in a refrigerator
EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 24 hours and 6 days in the refrigerator
EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 18 hours and 1 month in the refrigerator
EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 6 hours and 6 days in a refrigerator

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 6 hours and 24 hours in a refrigerator(2° to 8°)

  • It is important to use or properly save breast milk within four hours, especially if the room is warm.
  • Before expressing milk, hands should be properly washed.
  • Express milk in a clean, capped food container or hard plastic container.
  • The container should be BPA free.
  • Plastic bags especially designed for milk storage should be used.
  • Expressed breast milk can be stored in a deep freezer for 12 months
  • Firstly, thaw the oldest milk.
  • Mother should place the milk in the refrigerator one night before use.
  • Milk can also be thawed by placing it under running water.
  • Do not microwave milk or warm it directly on the stove.
  • If the baby does not finish the bottle, the remaining milk must be used within 2 hours

Incorrect Options:

Option B - EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 24 hours and 6 days in a refrigerator:

  • EBM cannot be stored at room temperature for 24 hours.
  • It can be stored at room temperature for only 4-6 hours.

Option C - EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 18 hours and 1 month in the refrigerator:

  • EBM cannot be stored at room temperature for 18 hours.
  • It can be kept for only 6 hours.
  • It can be stored in the refrigerator for 2-3, not for 1 month.

Option D - EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 6 hours and 6 days in a refrigerator:

  • EBM can be stored in the refrigerator for 2-3, not for 6 days.
  • EBM can be stored in insulated coolers containing icepacks for 1day

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the neurology outpatient department, who is a diagnosed case of low-grade astrocytoma, with complaints of recurrent headaches and frequent seizure episodes secondary to his brain tumour. Which of the following anticonvulsant drug is suitable for treating epilepsy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Levetiracetam

  • In epilepsy caused by a brain tumour, the drug of choice is those drugs that do not induce the hepatic microsomal enzyme system.
  • Following are the drugs that can be used:
  • Levetiracetam
  • Topiramate
  • Lamotrigine
  • Valproic acid
  • Lacosamide.

Option B: Phenytoin

  • The most common cause of drug interactions with phenytoin is the induction of the cytochrome P-450 isoenzymes CYP2C, CYP2D, and CYP3A subfamilies and UDP-glucuronosyltransferase.

Option C: Carbamazepine

  • Carbamazepine is a powerful inducer of CYP3A, the most abundant family of cytochrome P450 enzymes.

Option D: Phenobarbitone

  • Phenobarbital is a potent cytochrome P450 enzyme inducer, leading to interactions with other drugs by increasing their clearance.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents in the outpatient clinic with the complaint of primary amenorrhea. She has short stature; on the examination, there is no breast development. Ultrasound reveals a hypoplastic uterus and streak ovaries. The doctor ordered hormonal assays, which showed high levels of FSH. Karyotyping is suggested to confirm the suspected condition, which is XO. What is the probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gonadal dysgenesis

  • The above scenario findings of short stature, hypoplastic uterus, streak ovaries and raised FSH suggest the diagnosis of Turner syndrome.
  • Turner syndrome is an XO genotype with either incomplete penetration or the absence of another X chromosome.
  • Turner syndrome is the most common cause of gonadal (ovarian) dysgenesis.
  • Features of gonadal dysgenesis
    • Hypoplastic uterus
    • Functional ovarian tissue absent
    • Thelarche is absent as it depends on ovarian steroids
    • FSH & LH are high due to absent negative feedback on the pituitary by ovarian hormones, i.e.Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism
    • Pubic and axillary hair present (Depends on Androgen)
    • External genitalia are female-like (Hypoplastic)
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by karyotyping.
  • Management is lifelong hormonal support.
  • Streak ovaries may be surgically removed to decrease the chances of malignancy.

 

Option B: Androgen insensitivity syndrome

  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome is a disorder in which the individual has a normal female phenotype in a genetic male.

 

Option C: Kallman syndrome

  • Kallman syndrome is a disorder in which the female suffers from hypothalamic amenorrhea. Since there is no GnRH, there is no FSH & LH.

 

Option D: Adrenal hyperplasia

  • Adrenal hyperplasiais the adult onset counterpart of CAH and can present with amenorrhea
  • However here the uterus will be present and FSH will be normal.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man known case of acute myeloid leukemia presents to the hospital. He is receiving chemotherapy through an implantable central venous catheter and has developed fever and headache for the last 1 week. His blood is sent for culture. His blood culture shows the growth of gram-positive cocci, which are catalase-positive and coagulase-negative. Which is the most likely etiological agent associated with this condition and findings?
questions.solution:
Option B: Staphylococcus epidermidis

  • The patient discussed here is suffering from acute myeloid leukaemia.
  • The most likely etiological agent is staphylococcus epidermidis (catalase positive, coagulase-negative).
  • All the above options are gram-positive cocci.
  • Out of them, both staphylococcus aureus and staphylococcus epidermidis are catalase positive. The coagulase test can differentiate them.
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis:
    • Catalase positive
    • Coagulase-negative
    • Phosphatase negative
    • Normal commensal of skin epidermidis:
        • Associated with interventions - IV cannula, CSF shunts, prosthetic valve surgery, and catheters.
        • Causes early prosthetic valve endocarditis [<1yr].
        • Biofilm formation is seen → helps in adherence and antibiotic resistance.
        • Novobiocin sensitive.

Option A: Staphylococcus aureus

  • It is catalase positive.
  • It is also coagulase-positive and phosphatases positive as well.

Option C: Streptococcus pyogenes

  • It is catalase negative.
  • Streptococcus pyogenes is a bacterium frequently found in the throat and skin.

Option D: Enterococcus faecalis

  • It is also catalase negative.
  • Enterococcus bacteria are commonly present in the gut and bowel but can also live in the mouth and vaginal tract.

questions.text: A 41 year old woman presents to the OPD with a paps smear report suggestive of 'LSIL' (Low grade squamous intraepithelial lesion). The gynaecologist explains that this report means that there are some suspicious changes seen in the lining of the cervix involving?

choices.text: Whole thickness except the superficial layers

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A:

  • A paps smear report depicting 'LSIL' (Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion) is suggestive of suspicious changes in the form of dysplasia seen in the lining of the cervix involving up to lower 1/3rd.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Dysplasia involving the basal half to two-thirds would be described as a high-grade lesion, CIN II.

Option C: Dysplasia involving the whole thickness of cervical epithelium except superficial layers is CIN III, high-grade lesion.

Option D: Dysplasia involving the whole thickness of cervical epithelium with involvement of the basement membrane is invasive carcinoma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male is brought to the orthopedic emergency department after a fall from a height while working on a high roof. The patient is in severe pain. There is tenderness on the greater trochanter, and the patient cannot walk. The lateral border of the foot touches the bed. The senior resident is expecting some fracture of a bone on the lower leg. He orders an X-ray to confirm. What is the most common complication in the affected area in the given clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Malunion:

Femur fracture:

  • The given clinical scenario depicts the fracture of the femur's neck (intertrochanteric).
  • Extra-capsular (inter-trochanteric) fracture is more common than intra-capsular.
  • A most common complication of extracapsular fracture of the neck of the femur is malunion.
  • In inter-trochanteric fractures, there is usually gross deformity and pronounced lateral rotation.
  • The complication of inter-trochanteric fractures is avascular necrosis and non-union.

Femur fracture:

Fractured neck of femur presents with the following clinical features:

  • Painful movements of the hip joint
  • Shortening and external rotation of the affected limb

A plain radiograph of the fracture neck of the femur may show the following features:

  • Fracture in the neck of femur
  • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent Displacement of the greater trochanter
  • Break in the trabecular stream
  • Break in Shenton's line
  • Intracapsular fracture of the femoral neck is treated by anatomical reduction (preferably closed) and cannulated cancellous lag screw fixation.
  • Malunion of these fractures has been described in the coronal plane (coxa valga or coxa vara).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Non-union:

  • In Intra-capsular (neck of femur fracture)
    • Most common complication is avascular necrosis > non-union.

Option B - Avascular necrosis:

  • In Intra-capsular (neck of femur fracture)
    • Most common complication is avascular necrosis > non-union.

Option D - Pulmonary complications:

  • Pulmonary complications like ARDS may occur in a fracture of the femur shaft.
  • Pulmonary embolism can also occur.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man who had been diagnosed with Young Onset Parkinson's disease reported back for a follow-up visit. He informed the doctor that he had taken the medication regularly and has experienced an improvement in his symptoms. His tremors and rigidity had noticeably decreased but one complaint he had was that his sexual desire had increased. What is an excessive sexual desire in men termed as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Satyriasis:

  • Morbid, insatiable sexual need or desire in a man.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nymphomania:

  • Nymphomania: Abnormal, excessive, insatiable desire in a woman for sexual intercourse.

Option C - Frigidity:

  • Frigidity: It is the inability to initiate or maintain the sexual arousal pattern in females (absence of desire for sexual intercourse or incapacity to achieve orgasm).

Option D - Fetishism:

  • Fetishism
  • It is a disorder characterized by satisfaction with inanimate objects (bra and underpants) of the opposite sex.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the OPD with dry skin and dry eyes. On serological examination Vitamin. A deficiency was reported. What is the daily requirement of Vitamin A by an adult man?
questions.solution:
Correct answer

Option B: 900 mcg

  • 900 mcg or 3000IU The recommended daily amount of vitamin A is 900 micrograms (mcg) for adult men and 700 mcg for adult women.

Other options

Option C: 600 mcg

  • Incorrect answer.

Option A: 350 mcg

  • Incorrect answer.

Option D: 2000 mcg

  • This amount is significantly higher than the recommended daily requirement for Vitamin A in an adult man. Consuming such a high dose of Vitamin A regularly can lead to toxicity and potential health problems.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in a rural PHC. A 26-year-old male presented with complaints of a burning sensation over the chest, usually after eating, associated with regurgitation of food or sore liquid. You prescribed him PPI & advised the patient for follow-up. All of the following statements are true regarding the above condition, except?

choices.text: Occurs during transient relaxation of LES
Bicarbonate secreted by oesophageal mucosa neutralizes the acid
Erosive esophagitis at the esophagogastric junction is the hallmark of GERD

questions.solution:
Option C: Bicarbonate secreted by oesophagal mucosa neutralizes the acid

  • The primary function of the mucosal bicarbonate secretion is to neutralize acid diffusing into the mucus gel layer and to be quantitatively sufficient to maintain a near-neutral pH at the mucus-mucosal surface interface.
  • Bicarbonates are secreted from pancreas not from esophagus.
  • The above clinical history leads to the diagnosis of GERD.
  • Mechanisms of GERD:
    • Transient LES relaxations
    • LES hypotension
    • Anatomic distortion of the esophagogastric junction inclusive of hiatus hernia ·
    • The acid can lead to chemical tracheitis → nocturnal cough, and bronchospasm.
    • Erosive esophagitis at the esophagogastric junction is the endoscopic hallmark of GERD.

Option A: Occurs during transient relaxation of LES

  • Transient lower oesophageal sphincter relaxation (TLESR) is defined as lower oesophagal sphincter relaxation that is induced spontaneously without swallowing.
  • TLESR is a physiological mechanism that enables the venting of gas from the stomach.
  • The lower oesophageal sphincter (LES) remains tonically contracted at rest.
  • It relaxes during various reflex activities, including swallowing, allowing antegrade flow and belching and gastroesophageal reflux allowing the retrograde flow of gastric contents.

 

Option B: Can present with nocturnal cough

  • Nocturnal cough can be due to a disease of the upper airway, lower airway, gastrointestinal system, or cardiovascular system.
  • A viral respiratory tract infection is the most common cause of acute/subacute cough—upper airway cough syndrome.
  • Causes of a nocturnal cough can be categorized as respiratory, non-respiratory, and systemic.
  • A chronic cough's most common respiratory causes include postnasal drip, postinfectious, and asthma.
  • Environmental factors include smoking, both active and passive; this is the most frequent environmental factor.

Option D: Erosive esophagitis at the esophagogastric junction is the hallmark of GERD

  • Esophagitis is inflammation that may damage tissues of the oesophagus, the muscular tube that delivers food from mouth to stomach. Esophagitis can cause painful, difficult swallowing and chest pain.
  • The abnormal reflux of gastric contents causes gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in the oesophagus.
  • GERD can be divided into two groups, erosive esophagitis and non-erosive reflux disease (NERD).
  • Erosive esophagitis is severe reflux esophagitis characterized by mucosal breaks, such as erosions or ulcerations on endoscopy. There is little correlation between endoscopic and histologic findings in patients with GERD.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female comes for an antenatal check-up. She is 7 weeks pregnant and had a missed abortion 2 years ago. She is really worried and wants to know the well-being of the fetus. Which of the following is the best modality to detect fetal cardiac activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D:

  • Transvaginal ultrasound involves inserting a probe into the vagina to obtain images of the pelvic organs, including the developing embryo. It is more sensitive in early pregnancy and is the preferred modality for detecting fetal cardiac activity in the first trimester.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 

  • While abdominal ultrasound is commonly used during pregnancy, especially in later stages, it may not be as sensitive in the early weeks. In the first trimester, particularly at 7 weeks, the fetus is still quite small, and transvaginal ultrasound provides a closer and clearer view.

Option B:

  • Doppler ultrasound is often used later in pregnancy to listen to the fetal heartbeat. While it is a valuable tool, it may not be as sensitive as transvaginal ultrasound in the early stages.

Option C:

  • Fetal echocardiography is a specialized ultrasound that focuses on the detailed assessment of the fetal heart. It is typically performed later in pregnancy and more specifically is for evaluating cardiac structures. It is not the primary modality for detecting fetal cardiac activity in the early weeks.

questions.text: The following graph indicates the clearance of which molecule?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Inulin:

  • The graph shows the clearance of inulin, which is a substance that is only cleared from the blood by glomerular filtration and is neither secreted nor absorbed from the peritubular capillaries. Consequently, the inulin clearance rate remains constant and is irrespective of plasma concentration. As the concentration of inulin in plasma increases, so does its filtration rate, resulting in a constant ratio that is reflected in the graph.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D: The given graph doesnot match with clearance of PAH, creatinine and Glucose.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of abdominal cramps along with diarrhoea associated with mucus for 4 days. He has no history of any chronic illness. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The treating physician wants to process the stool culture for the isolation of Campylobacter jejuni. Which of the following is a correct growth requirement for the organism involved in the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Incubate at 42ºC, microaerophilic

  • This is a case of acute gastroenteritis in which the patient presents with abdominal cramps along with diarrhoea associated with mucus for 4 days.
  • It is caused by Campylobacter jejuni.
  • Campylobacter jejuni is a microaerophile, i.e. it needs only 5% O2. It grows at 42ºC.

Causative agents of predominantly dysentery:

  • Shigella species
  • Campylobacter jejuni
  • Enteroinvasive E. coli
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus

Causative agents of predominantly inflammatory diarrhoea:

  • Salmonella species
  • Yersinia enterocolitica
  • Listeria monocytogenes
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Aeromonas hydrophila
  • Plesiomonas shigelloides

Characteristics of Campylobacter jejuni:

  • Motile gram-negative bacteria.
  • It is associated with poultry bird product contamination.
  • Gull wing-shaped bacteria.
  • Motile
  • Causes inflammatory diarrhoea - Fecal leucocytes are present
  • In children, C. jejuni leads to Guillain Barre syndrome.
  • Cultures did on Charcoal based media:
  • Campy bap
  • Bitzler
  • Skirrow→ incubate at 42oC

Option A: Incubate at 37ºC, microaerophilic

  • Campylobacter jejuni is microaerophilic.
  • But it doesn't incubate at 37ºC.
  • It incubates at 42ºC.

Option C: 5% CO2 is required

  • It doesn't require 5% carbon dioxide.
  • It only requires 5% oxygen.

Option D: Incubate at 37ºC and 10% capnophilic

  • Campylobacter jejuni is not capnophilic.
  • It is a microaerophile.
  • It incubates at 42ºC, not at 37ºC.
